entry.title: shh! netsh
entry.content:
Here's a little secret - you may already know that a quick and easy way to set your IP address without having to type it into that silly GUI is to use NETSH.EXE:

netsh int ip set addr lo static 192.168.0.23 255.255.255.0 192.168.0.1 1

netsh int ip set dns lo static 4.2.2.4 primary

netsh int ip set addr lo dhcp

netsh int ip set dns lo dhcp

(I use have a set of batch files that use commands like these for commonly used ip addresses).

...but did you know that when you're having problems with your IP address, the diags mode in NETSH.EXE simply rocks:

netsh diag ping gateway

netsh diag ping dns

netsh diag ping mail

So if you're ever on a box and want to ping the gateway, don't bother looking it up with ipconfig and then typing it manually. Just pull out NETSH.EXE and rock on.

entry.title: Identity theft
entry.content:
Today I was reading a thread about identity theft on a private MVP security board, and it got me thinking: just how safe am I from identity theft? It's been hitting closer to home: I've heard horror stories from students, and even some of my aquaintences have been hit. Stats I've seen indicate that one out of six people have been victimized. That's a shockingly large number.

During my search, I surfed to Equifax and Transunion's websites and found that for only $40, I could get all three of my credit reports, instantly! What's up with that? I thought I was allowed to get a free copy of my credit report every year. Well, they sure don't advertise that option. They are also offering insurance against ID theft. For the low cost of 10 bucks per month, they will notify me when new stuff gets added to my credit report. How kind of them! Given that it's my information to begin with, and that I'd really rather they weren't keeping that data in the first place, this really seems to add insult to injury.

So I chatted with one of the other security MVPs who seemed to have some first hand knowledge of the issue. He agreed that the 10 bucks a month plan was ludicrous, and so I asked him just what *he* thinks one should do to protect one's identity. Here's the list he gave me:

1. Look at every CC and bank statement.

2. Lock your mailbox and only put outgoing mail with checks and personal info in the post office internal mailboxes.

3. Fight tooth and nail everyone except your employer and institutions that pay you taxable income who asks for your SSN.

4. Get the name of the individual who is requiring your SSN and let them know that you will be holding them personally responsible. They get more careful when they get nervous.

5. Shred (get a cross-shredder) everything with your name and other information on it.

6. Teach your family secure behavior.

7. Pray, or sacrifice a goat as needed.

We do (1) regularly, and (2) our mailbox is locked and we usually pay bills online. I've always been really picky about (3), although I've never done (4). We have an industrial strength shredder (5) that we use for any paper that even remotely identifies us or our friends. My wife has listened to me bitch enough about security that (6) is pretty much covered. I'm not a religious guy, so I guess I'll be buying a goat for (7) ;-)

A bit of googling brought me to a really informative government site[1] that goes even further, suggesting novel ideas like giving out a password instead of your mother's maiden name, etc. A particularly good FAQ can be found there at [2].

I've been fortunate that my family has never been attacked in this way, and if you're reading this, consider what actions you can take today to secure your family from this nonsense.

[1] http://www.consumer.gov/idtheft/

[2] http://www.consumer.gov/idtheft/consumertopics_bk.html

entry.title: Pragmatic Unit Testing
entry.content:
I've been reading Pragmatic Unit Testing over the last couple of evenings (it's a quick read if you're not a newbie to unit testing), and really enjoyed some of the insights this book offers.

One of the most compelling reasons (I thought) for getting people to do unit testing progressively as they write new code is that it's simply more efficient. I will spend much less time today writing a unit test for the code I'm working on today than I would at the end of the project when I need to go back and relearn that code in order to properly test it.

The focus on boundary conditions also should help with documentation. Thinking â€o will I test this?â€bfore jumping in and hacking together a class or method naturally leads you to ask â€ut what the hell is this code supposed to do, anyway?â€Ad that tends to lead to better factored code: code that does one thing well, and that one thing is easier to document now that you have thought carefully about what you're trying to achieve, and the boundary conditions you're willing to accept (is it OK to pass an empty array or a null reference for parameter X, for example).

Writing secure code is 90% about simply writing robust code (well, throw in a heap of distrust for user input), and unit testing is a great tool for achieving these goals.

Thanks to authors Hunt and Thomas for their good work, and thanks to the Denver Pragmatic Practitioners for pointing it out to me in the first place.

entry.title: CodeRush rocks, I think...
entry.content:
John Lam introduced me to Mark Miller, Chief Architect of Developer Express, and he gave me a tour of their product, CodeRush (apparently the company used to be called Eagle Software, and this was a tool popular in the Delphi space). Anyway, CodeRush is now a Visual Studio .NET plugin that makes writing code a ton more fun, and really increases your productivity (I've been using EMACS lately but this might just switch me back). Their smart use of graphic elements like things so simple as a little imploding circle that draws your attention to where the cursor is whenever they move it for you really brings the world of text and graphics together in a way I've never seen before. It's very impressive. Because I was a speaker, I got a free copy.

Here's the problem. The product doesn't run properly unless you're an administrator. Bah! I've sent mail to Mark and hopefully he can get the problems resolved, because I'd love to give this product a try. Sadly I can't say how good this product is because it's pretty much unusable for me at the moment.

entry.title: re: CodeRush rocks, I think...
entry.content: If you add the troubled account to the Power Users group, CodeRush should work. CodeRush requires a few permission settings to work properly in a given account. First, it needs registry read/write access for several keys and then it needs read/write access for several folders below its binary folders. Many of these will be corrected in the next release.

entry.title: Teaching with Ted
entry.content:
Ted Pattison was here in Denver teaching one of his famous Sharepoint classes, so he gave me a ring and asked me to come over and talk about security a bit with his class. Turns out the security lecture was the last talk of the day, and I got there just in time to tag-team it with Ted. Damn that was fun - brought back great memories of teaching Guerrilla Windows with Ted and Mike and Fritz, years ago for DevelopMentor. I even got to heckle him ;-)

We spent a lot of time talking about the difference between an impersonation/delegation model for authorization versus a trusted subsystem model. There are definitely pros and cons of each, and if you're interested in learning more about the issues, check out the “What is delegation” item in my book. Somebody then asked about dealing with custom authentication front ends, where you end up storing Windows account names and passwords in the middle tier so you can connect to back end servers using Windows authentication, even though on the front end you're using something else (Kerb doesn't work well over the Internet due to typical firewall configurations). So that got me talking about protocol transition. I think the class really had fun - I so love talking about security.

And heck, I even learned something about Sharepoint while I was there! Thanks for the invite, Ted.

Jim Newkirk was kind enough to give me a complimentary copy of his TDD book.

entry.content: Version 1.5.0.4 adds support for sorting by frequency of usage. After using it for awhile, it'll track how often you use each password, so if you run it in “Sort by frequency” mode, you'll find that your most commonly used passwords will float to the top over time. Enjoy!

entry.title: Internet Explorer and authentication
entry.content:
A former student (let's call him Joe) sent me mail the other day. He was wondering why sometimes when he surfs to an internal website he is prompted for credentials, when the site is configured for integrated authentication. “Shouldn't it just happen automatically?” he asked. Apparently after he types in his Windows user name and password (the same account he's logged in with, by the way), things work great.

If you ever see one of those popups and you're surprised like Joe was, glance down at the status bar (you may have to turn the stupid thing on again if it's been turned off on you, but that's another post). Look and see what zone that website is in. If it's the Internet zone, you're most likely just running into a security feature that IE implements to help protect your anonymity when surfing the web.

Bring up the Internet Options dialog and flip to the Security tab. Select the Internet zone, then press “Custom Level...” to see the details of the protections IE provides you when surfing Internet sites. If you scroll down a bit, you'll probably see something like this:

So why would a website inside of Joe's company be lumped in the “Internet” zone? Probably because Joe accessed it via a DNS name that had a dot in it (for example, http://www.pluralsight.com or http://192.168.0.22 as opposed to http://webbox). This is one heuristic that IE uses to figure out what's probably not in the “Local Intranet” zone. Anything that cannot be categorized in any other zone is automatically dropped into the Internet zone for safety sake.

If you have an internal website that use a lot and want to avoid being prompted for credentials, simply tell IE that this site should be considered part of the Local Intranet zone. You can do this by going to back to the Security tab and selecting the Local Intranet zone then pressing the “Sites...” button. If you look at the security settings for the Local Intranet zone, you'll see that it will automatically log you in without a prompt (of course if the website is using Basic authentication, this isn't possible because the website needs your cleartext password and you'll still be prompted).

For external websites that you trust, you can also add them to the “Trusted Sites” zone in the same fashion.

entry.title: re: Internet Explorer and authentication
entry.content: So, given what you have said, which will be more secure to internal networks, intranet or trusted sites if you use a wild card setting? Thanks,

entry.title: re: Internet Explorer and authentication
entry.content:
Not sure what you mean by a wild card setting, but you can compare the two levels and decide which is more appropriate for your scenario. They differ in different dimensions. Trusted Sites allows download of signed ActiveX controls without prompting, while Intranet requires a prompt by default.

But .NET Code Access Security policy grants downloaded apps in the Intranet zone more freedom (medium trust) than apps in Trusted Sites (low trust). Go figure.

You can adjust all this stuff to suit your needs though. Just tweak the zone security settings by selecting "Custom Level".

entry.title: re: Internet Explorer and authentication
entry.content:
OK, this make sense for Intranet Zone. Now tell me, what if Joe looks down at his status bar and sees "Trusted Site"? All other sites under "trusted sites" will open without prompting for authentication (using windows credentials). And the real kicker is that Joe has been to this site many times before and it never asked for his credentials then, but it is now. (entering his credentials manually grants him access to the page until he restarts his browser)

What would you tell Joe?

entry.title: re: Internet Explorer and authentication
entry.content:
I'd tell Joe that the website has likely flipped to using Basic authentication instead of Integrated. You see, your logon session does not cache your full password when you log in to Windows - it hashes it and keeps that hash as a secret that can be used to do integrated authn.

But Basic requires the cleartext password. Your browser asks you for this, then remembers the password as long as you keep the browser open.

Anyway, that's what it sounds like to me.

entry.title: UserNameToken and cleartext passwords
entry.content:
Aaron mentioned a gripe I have with UserNameToken. The approach recommended by the UserNameToken profile, namely the one-time hash that is designed to counter replay attacks,

Password_Digest = Base64 ( SHA-1 ( nonce + created + password ) )

requires that the server store the client's cleartext password if simple passwords are being used - note that the profile also supports password being a one-time key or other secret such as that generated by a SecurID token. But the implementations and frameworks being built today (namely WSE) are taking this quite literally and using cleartext passwords for password by default.

My main gripe with this simple implementation is that if an attack on the server leads to cleartext passwords being recovered, this is catastrophic! Passwords are generally used when humans are involved, and humans generally use the same password wherever they go. It's not a good practice, but it's one that the vast majority of people use today. No security-concious developer wants to be storing secrets on his machine. Especially secrets that in real life will often have a scope beyond her own application!

Given that password in the above function need not be a real cleartext password according to the profile, I see no reason why we cannot simply identify a scope over which a given password will be valid and identify a unique string or URI for that scope (this could be done through policy, perhaps). Then, we can start with

Password_Digest = Base64 ( SHA-1 ( nonce + created + validator ) )

and we can then calculate validator as

validator = Base64 ( SHA-1 ( scopeURI + cleartextPassword ) )

which means the server would only need to store validator, as opposed to the cleartext password itself. If an attack on the server leads to these validators being compromised, the user's cleartext password is still safe. It's a simple idea, and I'd love for someone to explain why this isn't in the profile or implemented in WSE. Perhaps Aaron could comment on whether this notion of a scopeURI would be feasible - I'm sure he knows much more about policy than I do.

entry.title: WSE 2.0 Authentication: How To Avoid ClearText Passwords With UsernameToken
re: UserNameToken and cleartext passwords
entry.content:
Interesting Keith. I am thinking scopeURI effectively becomes a salt, so scopeURI could be anything known at both sides. So may as well do:

Password_Digest = Base64 ( sha1( nonce + created + v )

v = Base64(sha1(password + salt))

salt = Base64(sha1(userName))

That way you don't have a lot of debug issues with what URI should I use, etc. As a bonus, we can do this today. And this would work with both SendPlainText and SendHashed. I blogged a c# implementation at http://spaces.msn.com/members/staceyw

--William

entry.title: SQL Server and delegation
entry.content:
Say you're building the typical three-tier system and you want to use integrated security all the way through, from Internet Explorer through IIS back to SQL Server. And you'd like to have IIS use the client's credentials to talk to SQL Server, so you turn on impersonation in the web server and connect to the database.

There's a rather tricky thing that you need to know in order to make this work. Unless your SQL Server is running as SYSTEM (ugh) or Network Service, you will need to do BOTH of the following things:

a) Ensure that you use a DOMAIN account to run SQL Server (not a local account or Local Service).

b) Ensure that this domain account has an appropriate SPN assigned to it.

Of course you really need to be using domain accounts throughout the entire system (your IIS AppPool needs to be running with domain credentials as well; this includes Network Service and, ugh, SYSTEM). Your clients will need to be using domain accounts as well, and you'll need to turn on delegation for the account your IIS AppPool is using. But that is all covered pretty thouroughly in other places.

What's not covered so well is the form of the SPN. After doing some network tracing today, I noticed that the SQL client libraries go to the domain controller looking for a ticket with an SPN that takes the following form:

MSSQLSvc/foo.bar.com:1433

...assuming a connection string of

integrated security=sspi;server=foo.bar.com; ...

So apparently the SPN MUST include the port number, even though this is the default port for SQL Server! Say you were running SQL Server under a domain account of BAR\Bob. You'd need to run the following command to add an SPN to the Bob account so that Active Directory will issue tickets for Bob when asked for a ticket for MSSQLSvc/foo.bar.com:1433

setspn -A MSSQLSvc/foo.bar.com:1433 bar\bob

It also wouldn't hurt to also register an SPN without the port, in case you're using an earlier client stack that relies on the default port syntax:

setspn -A MSSQLSvc/foo.bar.com bar\bob

You should always use the full DNS name of the server in your connection string (don't assume that your client library will convert a netbios server name in your connection string to a DNS name for the SPN - my stack seems to be doing this at the moment, but nothing says yours will!), so prefer

server=foo.bar.com

to

server=foo

in your mid-tier connection strings if you want delegation to work properly. It's possible to get it to work with netbios names in SPNs, but netbios names aren't necessarily unique throughout the domain, and if you accidentally end up with a duplicate SPN, guess what? Yea, authentication fails.

Delegation can be tricky, but this particular gotcha (the port number in the SPN) is pretty painful to debug, so I hope this saves somebody some headaches. If you want to know what this whole “SPN” business really means, read the following items in my book online, in the following order:

Item 59: What is Kerberos?

Item 60: What is a service principal name (SPN)?

Item 62: What is delegation?

UPDATE (22 Aug 2006): fixed links

entry.title: re: SQL Server and delegation
entry.content:
Lee: yes, the paper you point to does include the port number (although I didn't see that it was stressed - it was just listed). But there's so much misinformation out there to confuse people. Take the SQL Server Books Online (which one would reasonably expect to be correct):

To create an SPN for SQL Server, enter the following code at a command prompt:

setspn -A MSSQLSvc/Host:port serviceaccount

For example:

setspn -A MSSQLSvc/server1.redmond.microsoft.com sqlaccount

Where's the port in the example? I remember reading this and thinking that the default port syntax was ok. Too bad the books online doesn't have a link for feedback; I'd certainly tell the guy in charge of that page to fix it otherwise.

Søren: I'll post another blog entry talking about connection pooling in a bit.

entry.title: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Søren points out that delegating client credentials to SQL Server breaks connection pooling. Yes, you'll get much less use from pooled connections using this technique than if you simply used a fixed identity to communicate with SQL Server, because the credentials used to establish two connections must be the same for them to be considered interchangeable (poolable). But consider the tradeoffs.

Using a fixed identity to talk to SQL Server, you've created a “trusted subsystem” model. There's nothing inherently wrong with this, but you've shifted the burden of authorization from SQL Server to some middle tier component (perhaps a web server or application server, depending on how complex your system is). SQL Server now always sees the same user making all requests, and the middle tier (say the web server) holds these credentials 24/7. So what happens if the web server is compromised? That's right, the database is immediately compromised. The attacker simply uses a connection from the web server's pool, and because that connection has to be powerful enough to accomplish any task that any user coming through the web server could accomplish, the attacker immediately has broad reach into the database. Sure, he may not be able to drop tables, and in the best cases maybe he might not even be able to modify data (if the web interface to the data is read only, you should be connecting with a fixed identity that is granted read only access to the database; it's the principal of least privilege). But he will be able to read any data that any user could read, for certain, and that may include lots of personally identifiable information.

On the other hand, using delegation to talk to SQL Server, the web server doesn't need to have a login to SQL Server at all. The web server must wait until a user comes along, impersonate that user, and use her credentials to access the database. And how much of the data can that one user see? Hopefully only a very small slice; her own personal information, perhaps. In this scenario, the database does not trust the web server and instead performs its own authorization. An attacker will need to wait until clients come along and hijack their connections to access the database. Over time, the attacker will gain more and more access to the database, but the key here is that this happens over time. If you've built any sort of detection and reaction countermeasures into your system, this gives them time to kick in and discover that an attack is in progress, and take appropriate action to halt it.

So sure, you can use a fixed identity to get connection pooling. But consider whether the tradeoff is worth it for the system you are building. Does that system really need the scalability that connection pooling is touted to provide?

That brings me to another point. What is this dogma that we all seem to believe that without connection pooling our applications will shrivel up and die? Theoretically, connection pooling was more useful in Windows NT 4 than it is in Windows 2000. Why? Because a connection implies authentication, and domain authentication on NT 4 was rather expensive for the server. During every connection the client made to the server, the server was required to “pass through” authentication back to the client's domain controller. If the client and server were in different domains, this meant the database was forced to wait for two domain controllers to respond. But Windows 2000 with Active Directory and Kerberos changed all that.

With Kerb, it's the client who contacts the domain controllers, not the server. And she caches the result of that communication for the entire workday (assuming she doesn't log out). Now in a multi-tier system, technically the web server is acting on the client's behalf, and so the web server will need to contact the domain controller to obtain a ticket for the client (and that ticket won't be cached because the client's logon session on the web server is only temporary), but that still removes a lot of the burden from the database. It's easy to add another web server if load increases; not so easy to add another data server.

Of course if the connection protocol between the client and server is chatty, then connection pooling is still going to buy you something. But I'd argue that if it's chatty, Microsoft should focus on making it less so. It's certainly not security that's making it chatty - Kerb authentication can be done in a single round trip as far as the database is concerned, and this roundtrip can be piggybacked on top of the normal application-level protocol that has to happen anyway.

If you are in a situation where your load is so great that you must use connection pooling, so be it. But if you can afford to delegate client credentials through, you'll have a less brittle system from a security standpoint (note that this might *cost* more as well, due the licensing model of SQL Server, but security isn't usually free).

What I am saying is don't simply assume your application must have connection pooling. Prove it. You can get better security by avoiding the use of a fixed identity. For another idea on building a hybrid of the two systems, check out my discussion of delegation in the book.

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
I totally agree - connection pooling is a perf optimization, and as such shouldn't be done prematurely. However, I wouldn't be surprised to find out that connections take a long time to make. I don't have SQL Server numbers, but a few years ago when I measured on Oracle, it was taking like half a second - holy crap!

I do remember that SQL Server was significantly faster, and obviously integrated security is a much less likely scenario against Oracle, but I thought the data point was interesting in the context of your post.

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content: This is an interesting airing of end-to-end integrated security through middle-tier. You have written on MSDN and in your latest book on protocol transition, what's your view on using it in the middle-tier? I'm thinking particularly of transition from say an ASP.NET based membership authentication. Thanks!

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Well, I talk about protocol transition quite a bit in the new book. My opinion is that it should be used anytime you would have stored user names and passwords on a gateway box and called LogonUser to establish a logon for use with back end services.

With protocol transition, you can avoid storing passwords on the web server and get better constraint on the use of credentials (you can say exactly what back end services the middle tier gateway is allowed to talk to using transitioned credentials). I personally think it's a great feature, but of course it only works if you're in a W2K3 domain and the gateway is also running W2K3, so for some folks it's only a far off dream :-(

You can read/buy the book at http://www.pluralsight.com/keith/book/

entry.title: Connection Pooling vs. Delegation
re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Thanks for the insights. Very useable.
I guess the hybrid solution you discuss in your book, combined with security on the stored procedures and using the COM+ identity option (at least that gets away with the password in the app code) would be preferable for us who don't dwelve in protocal transistion Windows2003 nirvana.

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Keith, I've met many a good developer who's just as convinced that giving up connection pooling is the surest route to a "low-performance" server app.

I would love to be able to show them convincing evidence that performance does not *have* to suck, but if all I have to offer is "you need better security, so you better prove the site *needs* pooling", the conversation usually ends there.

Any further guidance on scenarios in which you've found pooling to not make much difference, authentication protocols that are slower or faster, or levels of throughput that make pooling necessary?

BTW, isn't it true that if the service on the server isn't running as LocalSystem, it'll have to contact a KDC to validate the contents of the service ticket it's received from the client?

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Great article, I am going back and forth with developers on the connection pooling issue right now.

Are there any other words of wisdom that have come to light since the article was written?

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Although there are some good thoughts and possibilities mentioned in several of the blog articles by Keith and he finds ways of overcoming certain problems, as a very experienced Microsoft web consultant I would be horrified if several of the technical solutions became the recommended approach for real world enterprise, scalable systems!

I feel I should make a comment since some contributors seems to be taking these suggestions as gospel and pushing this approach to development staff. I believe Keith is demonstrating what can be achieved, but several of the approaches require much more management and have a significant overhead than if standard best practise was followed.

This review is not meant as a criticism of the articles but I strongly encourage the reader to apply them sensibly to the real world scenarios they face. Security and risk management in general should be taken as a whole and the potential exploit mentioned as justification for this approach is not something that would seriously be considered in such an application.

If you plan to do so in a small environment or a test lab then fine, but don't expect such a system to scale well or even work reliably in a large enterprise!

Ian

entry.title: re: Connection Pooling: Dogma or Holy Grail?
entry.content:
Nope, this is just conjecture. Pooling saves most developers from their lame code; and it prevents most after-the-fact needs to re-scale an application when load increases. I don't believe your conclusion without some serious test results first.

I will stick to what is proven to scale; it has to scale (and I don't reject security requirements, I understand they are serious) but not what isn't proven - at least until there's proof. ;-)

Good food for thought though. Need some evidence.

entry.title: Anonymous callbacks in Windows XP SP2
entry.content:
I spent the day today doing some research for a client who needs to survive the transition to Windows XP Service Pack 2. They currently have a solution that requires anonymous callbacks to Windows XP clients. The picture isn't looking very pretty at the moment. Here's what you have to do to enable anonymous callbacks to a base COM client process:

1) Call CoInitializeSecurity in the usual way to turn off authentication requirements.

2) Put the application on the SP2 Security Center “exception” list.

3) Put port 135 on the same list.

4) Add a grant for ANONYMOUS LOGON to the machine-wide DCOM access limit DACL, granting remote access.

Both (1) and (2) aren't too big of a deal, as they only impact a particular application (although if the application doesn't code expecting malicious input, it could be very bad indeed). But (3) and (4) cause the user to walk away with a much less secure computer overall. If we could be certain the client computers were in a domain, we'd have a bit less trouble, as there are two profiles for domain machines - one when it's on the domain network and one when it's on any other network, but that is probably not an option here. (3) can be solved by using a static port - the only reason port 135 is necessary is for OXID resolution, which only happens if you use dynamic ports.

It turns out if you are communicating with RPC, you can programmatically allow anonymous calls into your process, because (4) doesn't apply to you. There is no machine-wide DACL for RPC servers. So by simply exposing an interface that uses a static endpoint (to avoid 3), and by registering your interface with a security callback (RpcServerRegisterIfEx with the RPC_IF_ALLOW_CALLBACKS_WITH_NO_AUTH flag), all you end up having to do to allow anonymous callbacks is to whitelist your executable.

The moral of the story here is that if you have a system that relies on anonymous callbacks to clients who will be running Windows XP Service Pack 2, you've got some serious thinking to do.

entry.title: Thanks to the volunteers
entry.content:
The book-in-a-wiki project is almost complete. All 75 items have been doled out to various people. To those who sent me mail volunteering to help, thank you so much - this new format will be much more amenable to change.

Be sure to subscribe to the RSS feed for the book once it stabilizes (once the port is complete, which should take a week or two really to settle down). I plan on continuing to add items to the Wiki, leading towards a second edition.

If there's anyone who still wants to help, feel free to take an item or two that's already done and just poke around looking for things that need fixing. For example, many function calls in the prose are PascalCased and show up as WikiWords. You can fix this by surrounding the word with @ symbols: @SomeFunctionCall@. This will make the word show up in a fixed font, and will remove the dashed underline, which really doesn't belong. For other words that shouldn't be made fixed font, just double-double quote them: ""ACL"" for example.

Figure captions should be italicized, so surround those lines with underscores like this:

_Figure 25.1 Blah blah blah_

Thanks again, and make sure you add a PortedBy note at the bottom of your items! You should get some credit for your help.

entry.title: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
Filet Mignon for the price of a pack of gum?

http://www.forbes.com/home/commerce/2004/07/29/cx_ah_0729rfid.html

Forbes has an interesting discussion of hacking the Radio Frequency ID tags that will soon be used to identify and check out items at big grocery chains. I'm not sure why the RFID consultant they interviewed thought someone carrying an RFID reader would “likely be detected” - this sort of theft will be real, I think. I doubt they'll get the crypto right given that they are currently using “eight-bit encryption” - you won't quite need to lug in a Cray to crack that ;-)

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content: Is there any reason RFID chips that are used in this way should be read/write? Why not make them read-only? Have fun hacking that... If the RFID chips are made part of the packaging, much like barcodes are now, I don't see how the tech-savvy customer can fool the merchant...

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content: I think one idea behind RFID is to have a unique ID for each item as opposed to simply identifying classes of items as UPC codes do now. So they'd have to be at least write-once, unless there was some innovative way to bestow a unique identifier during manufacturing, which seems infeasible.

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
There are currently both write-once tags and tags that are written with a unique number during manufacturing. The latter are probably just a special case of "write-once" where the writing equipment can't easily be used after deployment.

A larger concern -- and I haven't read the Forbes article to see if this is mentioned -- is the use of RFID for credit and debit information like the various toll collection and gas station systems. With sufficient standardization and without sufficient security, it will be trivial to steal people's credit card numbers.

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
FYI there is more information and more links about this over here:
<a href="http://www.rfidbuzz.com/news/2004/rfdump.html">http://www.rfidbuzz.com/news/2004/rfdump.html</a>

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
Technically not a new kind of theft... today you could swap product barcode labels to achieve much the same effect.

This at least is a reasonably well understood problem, which is why the automated checkouts today (at least the ones in Wal-Mart) weight the items in your bag... so you could only swap barcodes off of things that weighed the same amount.

This "register phreaking" ought to be easy for stores to work around, at least if they're networked to the store's main computer, as they could check the product's tag price to the master price, or ignore the tag price completely.

That would also allow them to use write-once tags (something they couldn't do if the tags held the price to be charged, as prices change...)

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
> This at least is a reasonably well understood problem, which is why the automated checkouts
> today (at least the ones in Wal-Mart) weight the items in your bag... so you could only swap
> barcodes off of things that weighed the same amount.

Hmmm... cheap bottle/cask/case of red wine, expensive bottle/cask/case of red wine - weight difference: negligible.

So I can't rip off the price of cheap items like toothpaste or toilet paper, but I can do the high end stuff which tends to be sold in standardised packaging.

Out of curiousity, what're the most expensive items in your local store - over Christmas my local supermarket sells some pretty expensive bottles of single malt in standard 750ml bottles... guess I should expect these to come in a fancy gift wrapped box with special tumbler included just to make it weigh more...

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
I don't know much about the current grocery automated checkout lanes, but I'd be amazed if the registers were looking for a particular weight for items. Think of how much work it would take to maintain such a database, and consider that many items don't always weigh exactly the same (like a prepackaged bag of garlic, for example).

I always assumed the reason for weighing items was to ensure that you were scanning each item. In the stores I've seen, there is an employee of the store watching four of those kiosks, making sure people are following the procedure (scan item, put in bag which is connected to the scale). The combination of the human and the register tracking the increasing weight as items are scanned reduces the chance for someone to avoid scanning an item. The scale and cashier serves as a detection countermeasure, while the cashier doubles as a reaction countermeasure.

entry.title: re: RFID Hacking
entry.content:
No, I have gone to Wal Mart and used the automated lines to purchase something very heavy. The system knew. Can't say that every store does this, but do to shipping a estimated weight can be expected.

What is really interesting to me is automated anonymous tracking and human behavor. If the tag is in some clothing, You and a group of friends could track a person in a city.

entry.title: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
Is it just me or have you guys noticed that auditing support on Windows has gotten worse as the versions have moved on. I remember working with Windows NT 4 and it seemed like everything I asked to be audited actually got audited.

But when Win2K shipped, I noticed that sometimes I'd establish a logon, I wouldn't get a successful logon audit. I don't remember the exact details, but it just seemed like auditing got less reliable in Win2K.

Now I'm working with W2K3, and I'm trying to import an IPSEC policy, and I'm told “A required privilege is not held by the client”, which basically means that the OS tried to enable a privilege that wasn't in my token. No problem, I figure. I'll just go turn on auditing of privilege use and audit failures in order to figure out exactly which privilege I'm missing. Of course after I did this and retried the import, I got the same error, and no audit was generated.

If anybody on the security team at MS is reading this, guys, it'd be really helpful if auditing could be made more robust...

entry.title: re: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
I'm not alone! :-)

Occasionally, I find the local policy(ies) on the machine are restricting the audit trail for certain events/objects (i.e. Audit logon events). Rarely, the problem can be attributed to something a little deeper, such as a full event log that is not configured to overwrite events on an as-needed basis.

Do you have any tips/tricks to resolve auditing issues like the ones you describe (above)? If so, what are they?

entry.title: re: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
In my case, I'd just cleared the security event log, so it wasn't full, and I'd ensured that auditing was turned on via the local policy (this particular machine is not a member of a domain).

There's really not a lot you can do when the operating system doesn't audit an event, besides perhaps firing up a kernel mode debugger to see what's going on. Thus my plea to MS ;-)

entry.title: re: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
I bet NT 3.5 was awesome at this, wasn't that the version that was orange book approved?
Logging and auditing is just one of those things that fall off the priority list pretty quickly, until you actually need it.

entry.title: re: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
There are two main causes for "missing" security events.

1. Log set to "retain X days". In this case, if the log is full and no events are older than X days, new events are discarded until the oldest event is at least X days old and can be overwritten.

2. Missing logoff events due to token leak. Under the hood, a logon event is created when a logon session is created (== call to logonuser or acceptsecuritycontext, roughly == token creation). A logoff event is created when a logon session is destroyed, which happens when the token reference count drops to 0 (no processes are using the token anymore)). There is a common class of bug, sometimes committed by MSFT developers, often by third parties, where a token is duplicated or otherwise referenced, but never properly dereferenced. It is almost the same type of coding error as a memory leak. A token leak causes the refcount to never decrease to 0, which causes the logon session never to be destroyed, which causes no logoff event to be generated. Look at the field "caller process ID" in 528/540 on Windows Server 2003 when there's no 538 matching the logon ID: that is probably your culprit.

Unfortunately there's no easy fix to the token leak problem, but we're looking at alternatives. As a workaround we added a "begin logoff" event for Windows Server 2003, which can be used in place of the logoff event 538 when a token leak is present.

As far as priv use audits go, certain privileges are WAY too noisy and are never audited: SeDebugPrivilege, SeChangeNotifyPrivilege, etc. Look up "FullPrivilegeAuditing" in the Knowledge Base- it's a reg key that can override the default suppression.

Eric Fitzgerald
Program Manager, Windows Auditing
Microsoft Corporation

entry.title: re: Holes in Windows auditing
entry.content:
This is weird but I'm actually getting the opposite of the issue you all are having. My Win2k3 Server is auditing too much, generating 10-20 audit events every couple of minutes without anyone touching the system. They are all 538/540 logon/logoff events with a couple of 576 privelege use events thrown in for extra flavor. Also, all are using the SYSTEM account to generate the event. It is generating log files so huge that the system crashes after about 15 days unless the audit log is cleared before hand.

Has anyone encountered something like this or know or heard any information regarding a bug/fix for win2k3 servers regarding this audit mishap? It is driving me nuts having to clear it every two weeks to prevent a crash. If anyone has any info on this e-mail me at jason.pridgen@pw.utc.com. Thanks.

Jason Pridgen
Computer System Aministrator Associate

entry.title: Your Phishing IQ
Your Phishing IQ
re: Your Phishing IQ
entry.content:
The thing I found somewhat frustrating about this is that all the techniques I normally use for detecting frauds were unavailable to me simply because of the way the test was set up.

Or rather, using my normal tools, I came to the conclusion that every single one was a fraud, for several reasons. First, they're all hosted on mailfrontier.com despite purporting to be from somewhere else. Second, all of the links have been nobbled (by mailfrontier.com) and don't link where they purport to link to - they all open a popup instead. So clearly these are *all* fakes...

Of course both of those things were done so they could put the tests up on their web sites. But this means that my usual mode of self defense - viewing the source, checking headers, checking the origin of the data, checking the true target of the links - has been removed from me.

I'm curious to know what techniques other people have been using to try and work out whether they are real or not. The changes made to frame these as a test pinned my bogometer on every single one, but evidently the rest of you are all using different techniques to test from me.

Actually, what's particularly interesting is that if I make the assumption that the link target it tries to show me in the status bar is where it would have taken me, I can get full marks on the test.

But that's an extremely dangerous assumption - indeed, these samples *all* prove that you should *never* trust what your status bar tells you. (In fact I'm running Firebird, and it didn't display anything in the status bar when hovering.)

entry.title: re: Your Phishing IQ
entry.content:
Rjae: It's a good idea - building in tools that help average users perform the same sorts of analysis that geeks do every day...

Ian: I normally surf with FireFox, but the site seemed to run best using IE, so I used IE for the test. I hovered over the links and was able to see where they *would* have pointed to in the status bar, and did a view|source to look at the full link when I wasn't sure. I still missed one - the earthlink one used an interesting technique I'd not seen before. I think for the average user, who wouldn't know how to View|Source anyway, this would be a bit more interesting.

FWIW, so far I've gotten back five responses from my "non-technical" friends. The average score is 76. At least one of them admitted that since this was a test, he paid closer attention than he would normally.

Interestingly enough, my wife got the same score I did, missing the exact same one (but for different reasons).

entry.title: re: Your Phishing IQ
entry.content:
I got 9/10 correct, but not because of the reason stated by Mr. Howard. In the situation where he did "View Source", I had already seen suspicious behavior in IE and I only did "View Source" to see how it was done.

Here's the one I got wrong, and I think this was a low trick. The legitimate e-mail from Microsoft had a URL hosted on g.msn.com and the URL looked like it could be hosting anyone. I received dozens of spam e-mails containing URLs starting with g.msn.com. I have never received a legitimate e-mail containing a URL starting with g.msn.com. I reported to Microsoft dozens of spam sites being served by redirection from g.msn.com. Microsoft used to answer that g.msn.com wasn't an MSN account so Microsoft was not going to take any action. After a while Microsoft stopped answering. Microsoft NEVER said that they would take any action to discontinue the redirection service that they were providing to spamming partners. So naturally I was suspicious of any site hosted at g.msn.com. It looked to me like any phishing spammer could hold that URL.

For the PayPal e-mails I did "View Source" after not seeing anything suspicious in IE. For the remaining cases it was not necessary to do "View Source" because things were already obvious.

entry.title: Untrusted hardware
entry.content:
Have you ever thought about what *hardware* is trusted implicitly by commercial operating systems? The CPU obviously must do its job correctly: a mistake during an access check would open a security hole. The hardware that implements virtual memory must not be corrupt or one process might be able to read or write another process's memory.

Your video card had better not lie to you, and you normally expect your printer to print the exact contents of the document you just received in the mail.

Your keyboard had better not lie or record what you're typing. Oh and while we're at it, the drivers behind all these devices are not usually subject to any security policy since they usually run in privileged mode (ring 0 on WIntel systems).

That's a lot of stuff to trust.

Just thinking about that should make you suspicious of hardware and driver vendors and anyone who gets remotely close (physically) to your hardware.

How real is the threat? Check out http://www.keykatch.com/ to see how easy it is for someone to compromise your keyboard. For many years I've kept one of these little doodads in my backpack to demo to my students. Most are blown away that such a thing exists. It's an eye opener - I just make sure it's not in my bag when I travel to foriegn countries or the NSA. ;-)

You all probably know how dangerous it is to use hardware you don't trust. Remember the guy who installed keyboard logging software on Kinkos' machines and used the stolen passwords in an attempt to make some extra $$$ on the sly? We all know it's dangerous, but it's never a bad thing to be reminded.

entry.title: re: Untrusted hardware
entry.content:
> The CPU obviously must do its job correctly

Intel has published a lot of errata. Intel has also kept secret a lot of errata. It is not rare for BIOSes to load microcode to fix CPU bugs at boot time.

> Your video card had better not lie to you

You'd be amazed. But of course most of the problems are BSODs from drivers (which are usually Microsoft-provided drivers) rather than security problems.

> I just make sure it's not in my bag when I
> travel to foriegn countries or the NSA. ;-)

You're already in a foreign country. And odds are that the thing was made in a different foreign country.

entry.title: Recovering lost windows
entry.content:
Given the way I use Windows, I often run into situations where windows will end up off screen and I need to get them back where I can see them. This is usually because of the way I use my dual monitors and switch one between machines. Regardless, this technique will come in handy if you've not used it before.

1) Activate the window. This may take some guesswork if the window doesn't show up on your taskbar. Either click it on your task bar, or ALT-TAB until you think you've activated the one you want.

2) Press ALT+SPACE followed by m (for “Move“). This will move the mouse to the center of the title bar of the window. You could use the keyboard to move the window if you wanted to, but we'll use the mouse instead. If you can see the window on your taskbar, you can right-click and select “Move“ instead if you prefer.

3) Carefully, without moving the mouse, click down to grab the window and drag it back to your desktop. As long as the window isn't ridiculously far away (i.e., the application is buggy and has placed your window millions of pixels away from where your desktop is, you'll be all set. For me, I usually know right where my lost windows are (over to the left where my second monitor would normally display them), so I just drag over to the right and I'm set.

If (3) isn't working for you, the window may be maximized. Press ALT+SPACE followed by r (for “Restore“). This will restore the window if it's maximized somewhere (another monitor perhaps). Then go to (2) and try again.

I hope this helps somebody.

entry.title: re: Recovering lost windows
entry.content: You can also use the arrow keys once you've done alt-space m to move the window.

You can also use the arrow keys *before* clicking the window, press ALT+SPACE, m, then use any of the arrow keys. Once you have done this, the mouse is locked to the window and will drag the window until you click the mouse.

You don't need multiple monitors to lose a window.

If the window's button in the task bar has also been lost, then another way to bring back the application is to open Windows Task Manager to its Applications tab, select the application, and click the Switch To button. In my experience this usually restores a minimized application and then shortly afterwards restores its task bar button.

Of course if the window is off the screen then you'll still have to proceed to the other tricks to bring it on screen. But I haven't had this problem very much in Windows XP.

entry.title: Cryptanalysis progress on SHA-1
entry.content:
Craig points to an article describing some cryptanalysis being done on hash functions. It's interesting to see this - Fergusen and Schneier, in Practical Cryptography, warn that hash functions have not received much cryptanalysis, and recommend choosing a strong hash from the SHA family.

For that reason, I've been pointing my students and clients toward SHA-256.

Perhaps this will show the wisdom of their suggestions. FWIW, cryptographers have known for a long time that MD5 was weaker than SHA-1, and the attacks described in the article above seem to strengthen that argument.

For more info, see Eli Biham's publication page.

Here's an excerpt from his paper, in the “breaking news” section:

...found a collision of 36-round reduced SHA-1, and near-collisions of 45-round reduced SHA-1. We expect to be able to find collisions and near-collisions of longer variants. At the current state of research, our attacks are not expected to break the full SHA-1.

entry.title: re: Cryptanalysis progress on SHA-1
entry.content: There's interesting discussion in CFRG maillist (http://www1.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/cfrg/current/index.html) on issue. Especially questions in mail by Jon Callas (http://www1.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/cfrg/current/msg00510.html)

entry.title: VPC tip
entry.content:
Wow, time flies when you've got deadlines (WinDev talks were due yesterday, and I'm also heads down working on Campsight materials)...

Anyway, I use Virtual PC all the time to model security systems. About a year ago, I built a pretty beefy machine that I dedicated to hosting VPCs: it's got 2G of RAM and about 250G of HD space arranged in RAID 0 for performance. I normally launch the VPCs I want and then use terminal server to connect to them from my laptop, which is the center of my world. I can then roam around the house using wireless, and I have a whole host of machines that I can use for testing.

Well today I am running three machines: a W2K3 domain controller, a W2K3 SQL Server box, and an XP dev box with VS.NET 2005. The XP box needs plenty of memory to run VS.NET so that it's usable, but the DC and the SQL box need very little memory. In fact, I've managed to allocate the minimum of 128M of RAM to those two VPCs.

What's nice about allocating the minimum possible RAM to a VPC is that it starts and saves very quickly. Compared to my dev image, the DC and SQL images start up almost instantaneously, and save just as fast.

So here's my VPC tip of the day: think carefully about how much RAM you need in each VPC. Try to find the minimum amount that works for you, especially for servers. You'll be happy you did!

entry.title: Geek Notes 2004-09-13
ACLing removable media
entry.content:
A fellow sent me mail the other day asking how to restrict access to removable drives. There's no UI option for this (the property page for a CD-ROM drive doesn't have a Security tab), but apparently it is possible to ACL access to these volumes programmatically by calling SetSecurityInfo.

Whidbey will make this much easier, given that security descriptors and ACLs are first class citizens now (yea!) but what it won't do is give you a nice little UI for setting up the ACL. One thing I'd really like to see wrapped in the .NET Framework is the ISecurityInformation interface. It'd be great to be able to easily incorporate a security property page into a GUI. If we had that, building a tool for ACLing volumes would be trivial.

So I am going to see how hard it is to implement ISecurityInformation purely in C#. This should be a considerable challenge given how the interface works (whoever designed it knew nothing about COM, I fear). I need to write another column for MSDN Magazine anyway, so if I'm successful, I'll write about it there.

In the meantime, if anyone knows of a managed implementation or wrapper for ISecurityInformation that already exists, let me know, would ya? I hate reinventing the wheel.

Might be easy to extend this library to support ISecurityInformation.

entry.title: FormatPermViewDecl
entry.content:
Listing declarative security permissions is a pain. At least in 1.1, you can't get at them via reflection, and PERMVIEW does a really lousy job of formatting its output. Honestly, why write a tool that spits out part XML and part text?

permview /decl mscorlib.dll

Assembly RequestMinimum permission set:
<PermissionSet class="System.Security.PermissionSet"
               version="1">
   <IPermission class="System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermission, mscorlib,
 Version=1.0.5000.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089"
                version="1"
                Flags="SkipVerification"/>

...

So I wrote a little filter that you can pipe this output through. It parses and builds well-formed XML, turning the goo above into something infinitely more usable:

<PermissionDeclarations>
<AssemblyPermissionRequest requestType='RequestMinimum'>
<PermissionSet class="System.Security.PermissionSet"               version="1">
  <IPermission class="System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermission, mscorlib,
Version=1.0.5000.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089"
     version="1"                Flags="SkipVerification"/></PermissionSet>
</AssemblyPermissionRequest>

...

You can optionally specify -noroot if you are going to use this in a shell script that enumerates a bunch of assemblies:

permview /decl %1.dll | formatpermviewdecl -noroot >> output.xml

I've now got a single XML file that has all security declarations for the entire .NET Framework 1.1. Using an XPath query tool like Craig's xpq, I can do searches (e.g., which methods/classes/assemblies require full trust?).

Anyway, I figured others might find a use for this thing, so I uploaded it to our tools page. Enjoy!

entry.title: re: The book ships
entry.content:
OK, the CAS book was available for a good price, along with an informative review saying why ONLY the CAS portion of that book should be believed. So I'm buying it AND yours.

Nonetheless Mike B's question surely deserves an answer. Why is .NET stressed in the title? For readers who are still new to .NET, we can read tons of stuff in either your wiki or your book and not be aware of what we're missing. If Visual Studio 2005 becomes sufficiently reliable then .NET will become very attractive to VC++ programmers. Surely both Win32 and .NET security are important.

entry.title: re: The book ships
entry.content:
Unlike years ago when I wrote my first security book, there are a whole bunch of books on security for .NET developers right now. Most of them focus on all the new stuff in the .NET Framework, and the few that say much about operating system security (what I term "Windows Security") often get it subtly or blatantly wrong.

There are even errors in the LaMacchia book in this regard. My goal was to provide a concise guide for .NET developers to operating system security features such as impersonation, logon sessions, etc.

And there is a weakness in the 1.1 framework class library: it does not wrap much at all of the functionality of windows security, so in many places I show how a .NET developer can access those features, and I talk about how things get better in v2.0.

So it's a guide to Windows security for .NET developers. Thus the title.

entry.title: AclUIAdapter
entry.content:
I finally got around to finishing up my managed adapter for ISecurityInformation. Turns out the cleanest way was to write a custom CCW in MC++. For those of you who are wondering what the heck I'm talking about, this allows you to add that nifty ACL editor GUI to your managed applications:

...along with all its accoutrements...

The sample application that comes with the adapter uses it to edit service ACLs (something the Windows administration tools don't provide except via group policy):

To use this adapter, write a class that implements ISecurityInformationManaged and pass an instance to AclUIAdapter.EditSecurity(). All this stuff is in a namespace called Pluralsight.Security.Adapters. You can download the code and sample application here. This will be featured in an upcoming article for MSDN Magazine.

Here's an excerpt from the sample app:

class ServiceSecurityModel : ISecurityInformationManaged {
    string machineName;
    string serviceName;
    public ServiceSecurityModel(string machineName, string serviceName) {
        this.machineName = machineName;
        this.serviceName = serviceName;
    }

    public ObjectInfo GetObjectInformation() {
        return new ObjectInfo(
            ObjectInfoFlags.EditAll | ObjectInfoFlags.PageTitle | ObjectInfoFlags.Advanced,
            machineName,
            serviceName,
            "Service Permissions");
    }

    public AccessRights GetAccessRights(Guid objectType, Pluralsight.Security.Adapters.ObjectInfoFlags flags) {
        AccessRights rights = new AccessRights();
        Access[] access = rights.Access = new Access[17];

        // summary page permissions (note use of AccessFlags.General)
        access[0] = new Access(SERVICE_ALL, "Full Control", AccessFlags.General | AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[1] = new Access(SERVICE_READ, "Read", AccessFlags.General); // 0x0002008D
        access[2] = new Access(SERVICE_WRITE, "Write", AccessFlags.General);
        access[3] = new Access(SERVICE_EXECUTE, "Execute", AccessFlags.General);

        // permissions specific to services (only show up on advanced page)
        access[4] = new Access(0x0001, "Query Configuration", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[5] = new Access(0x0002, "Change Configuration", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[6] = new Access(0x0004, "Query Status", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[7] = new Access(0x0008, "Enumerate Dependents", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[8] = new Access(0x0010, "Start", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[9] = new Access(0x0020, "Stop", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[10] = new Access(0x0040, "Pause or Continue", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[11] = new Access(0x0080, "Interrogate", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[12] = new Access(0x0100, "Send User Defined Control", AccessFlags.Specific);

        // standard permissions that apply to services (only show up on advanced page)
        access[13] = new Access(0x00010000, "Delete", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[14] = new Access(0x00020000, "Read Permissions", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[15] = new Access(0x00040000, "Change Permissions", AccessFlags.Specific);
        access[16] = new Access(0x00080000, "Take Ownership", AccessFlags.Specific);

        rights.DefaultIndex = 1; // default mask when you add a new ACE (GENERIC_READ)

        return rights;
    }

    public InheritType[] GetInheritTypes() {
        return null; // services are not containers
    }

    // these generic mappings taken from the service access rights documentation
    const int SERVICE_READ    = 0x0002008D;
    const int SERVICE_WRITE   = 0x00020002;
    const int SERVICE_EXECUTE = 0x00020170;
    const int SERVICE_ALL     = 0x000F01FF;

    const int GENERIC_READ    = unchecked((int)0x80000000);
    const int GENERIC_WRITE   = 0x40000000;
    const int GENERIC_EXECUTE = 0x20000000;
    const int GENERIC_ALL     = 0x10000000;

    GenericMapping ServiceGenericMapping = new GenericMapping(
      SERVICE_READ, SERVICE_WRITE, SERVICE_EXECUTE, SERVICE_ALL);

    public void MapGeneric(GenericAccess generic) {
        MapGenericMask(ref generic.Mask, ref ServiceGenericMapping);
    }
    public void SetSecurity(SecurityInformation providedInformation, byte[] binarySecurityDescriptor) {
        ServiceHelper.SetServiceSecurity(machineName, serviceName,
          (int)providedInformation, binarySecurityDescriptor);
    }
    public byte[] GetSecurity(SecurityInformation requestedInformation, bool wantDefault) {
        return ServiceHelper.GetServiceSecurity(machineName,
          serviceName, (int)requestedInformation);
    }

    [DllImport("advapi32.dll")]
    static extern void MapGenericMask(ref int mask, ref GenericMapping mapping);
}

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content: never mind: just found the InitializeSecurityDescriptor function! :)

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content:
First off, am i horribly misunderstanding the gernic to specific mapping, or are the SERVICE_* constants incorrect? I say this because they all have the 0x00020000 bit set. My understanding was that each of the specific permissions is supposed to be mapped to exactly 1 of the general permissions.

Second, i am trying to figure out how to properly propagate permissions to private child objects. I'm using the AclUIAdapter but not the ServiceHelper (can't get it to build using VS2005 with .NET version 2.0.50727). In any case, when SetSecurity() is invoked due to modifications in from GUI, i need to determine what change was made, and if it involves inheritable permissions. Do i have to examine each ACE separately, or is there some general way to determine if the modifications involve inheritable properties.

I don't wannt to just automatically traverse the entire subtree below the object that the changes were made to, particularly because that will optentially involve over 10 million private objects (stored in a database) under certain circumstances.

Thanks.

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content: I don't know of an easy way to tell other than traversing the DACL, no. That would be a very good optimization to make in your case though! AS for generic permissions, they will almost always map onto more than one standard/specific permission. Read http://pluralsight.com/wiki/default.aspx/Keith.GuideBook/WhatIsAPermission.html for more detail.

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content:
Well, i guess i may traverse the DACL's when changes are made.

As for my previous permission comment, i think that you read it backwards. I agree that each generic permission is made up of multiple specific permissions and thats fine. But, each specific permission should only be a part of one generic permission, but all of your SERVICE_* permissions use the 0x00020000 bit. Separated into their bits, the service permissions are:
SERVICE_READ = 0x00020000 | 0x00000080 | 0x00000008 | 0x00000004 | 0x00000001;
SERVICE_WRITE = 0x00020000 | 0x00000002;
SERVICE_EXECUTE = 0x00020000 | 0x00000100 | 0x00000040 | 0x00000020 | 0x00000010;

Also, i'd think that this should always be true:
SERVICE_ALL = SERVICE_READ | SERVICE_WRITE | SERVICE_EXECUTE;
(its not)

and that this should also be true:
SERVICE_READ & SERVICE_WRITE & SERVICE_EXECUTE = 0x00000000
(its not)

Thanks for your time.

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content:
Sean,

Where did you read that a standard or specific permission can only be in one of the generic permissions? I don't know of any such limitation.

If you look in winnt.h you'll find why I use 0x20000 in each of the generic permission mappings. This is the standard READ_CONTROL permission, which appears to be intended for all three generic permissions:

#define STANDARD_RIGHTS_READ (READ_CONTROL)
#define STANDARD_RIGHTS_WRITE (READ_CONTROL)
#define STANDARD_RIGHTS_EXECUTE (READ_CONTROL)

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content:
Thanks for the clarification. I hadn't read anywhere regarding the disjoint nature of the general permissions, it was more of an initial feeling about them. I'm new to ACL progarmming and wanted to make certain whether or not my intuition was correct.

I've got my app almost working, filling in the details for some of the lesser used features of the adapter...still need to deal with the sledgehammer :)

Anyway, one (hopefully) last question. In the definition of the SecurityInformation enum in Pluralsight.Security.Adapters there are 8 flags defined, but i sometimes get additional ones back from the adapter in the SetSecurity() method. For instance, when the propagate owner to subcontainers box is checked, i get back 257 for the SecurityInformation. Black box testing has convinced me that 256 is the flag for recursing the owner (1 is the existence of owner info in the modifications).

Just wondering if i can find a complete definition of those flags so that i don't have to figure them all out by trial and error.

Thanks a lot for your help, this project is really coming together for me now.

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter
entry.content: Happy to help. My adapter is a thin layer over ISecurityInformation. Just look that up in the help and you'll find everything you need.

entry.title: re: AclUIAdapter - Inherit Only
entry.content:
Hi Keith,
I have yet another question for you. I've gotten most of what i need to work properly in terms of propagating security modifications properly, etc. The thing that i still can't get to work properly is how to apply inherit only aces. When i get a modification descriptor back from the AclUiAdapter, i traverse the aces to determine what to do with them, apply, inherit, etc. But when i attempt to apply an inherit only ace to the object / container that is the root for that inherit only ace (doesn't apply to it, but will apply to the appropraite children), i can't get it to apply properly. I can see that it has the PropgateFlag 'Inherit Only', but when i attempt to add it to the existing ACL it applies as an effective ace. I assumed that the propagation flag would be applied.

I am using SetPrivateObjectSecurityEx() to merge the existing ACL with the new modified information.

Is this the wrong approach, or do i need to do some explicit bit flipping to get the new information as i need it?

Once again, thanks for your help.

entry.title: UrlAuthorization vulnerability in ASP.NET
entry.content:
Heads up, this is serious.

If you are relying on <authorization> sections in subdirectories (or via <location> in your web.config files), you should be aware of a canonicalization bug in ASP.NET that can allow an attacker to slip past the UrlAuthorizationModule by using a backslash instead of a forward slash. For example, an (unauthorized) attacker might be able to get to a secured directory as follows (note the backslash between “bar“ and “secure“ in the sample URL below):

http://quux.com/foo/bar\secure/securedPage.aspx

Microsoft has posted an article detailing steps that you can take to protect yourself in the meantime, while they work on a patch.

I worked with dominick on this one to see if we could reproduce it. I wasn't able to repro on W2K3 (apparently the built-in URLScan capability is fixing the URL before it gets to ASP.NET). Dominick was able to repro on earlier platforms.

entry.title: re: UrlAuthorization vulnerability in ASP.NET
entry.content: If one is already using URLScan tool(because of IIS Lockdown wizard), this is not a problem. Correct? [I have tested this yet, though].

entry.title: re: UrlAuthorization vulnerability in ASP.NET
entry.content:
That's my understanding, yes. I believe that's why I couldn't repro this on W2K3 (which has much URLScan functionality built right in).

But what worries me is that the MS response says W2K3 is vulnerable, and does NOT mention URLScan.

entry.title: ASP.NET Vulnerability: Where's Exactly?

http://dotnetjunkies.com/WebLog/stefandemetz/archive/2004/10/02/27441.aspx

entry.title: re: UrlAuthorization vulnerability in ASP.NET
entry.content:
One important point to take note is that - the exploit is at asp.net filter level (IMHO) and not the IIS server itself. The workarounds by MS are just 'prevention' or 'protection', it's far from FIXing the 'hole'. Hence with urlscan or IIS6 (without urlscan), I strongly urged you guys to apply the MSI package. and hope MS come out a real fix soon, as you never know other types of 'malform' url request may actually skip through those checking ... I don't know what type of malform requests it will be, but the bad guys will figure out soon :) for IIS 6 test result, you can view it at my blog.

Cheers.

entry.title: re: UrlAuthorization vulnerability in ASP.NET
entry.content: Good point, Bernard. This bug appears to have NOTHING to do with IIS. If you're running ASP.NET applications, you need to fix them NOW.

entry.title: Security Vulnerability in ASP.NET
C++/CLI
entry.content:
array<string^>^ a = gcnew array(10);

I use MC++ a lot when I need to wrap Win32 APIs for ease of use in managed code. For some reason, I have managed to remain completely ignorant of the changes coming in Whidbey (the new language is called C++/CLI). If the above looks unfamiliar, you're probably in the same boat.

I'm currently reviewing some chapters from Stan Lippman's upcoming book on this topic. It's great to see the CLR get first class treatment in one of my favorite languages.

See Stan Lippman's blog for some great discussions of the upcoming changes.

Now I am glad to know Stan Lippman's coming up with a book on this brand new and wonderful language. And who else could do it better!

entry.title: ASP.NET Vulnerability
entry.content:
Looks like the consensus is that no version of IIS protects you from this vulnerability. If you have an ASP.NET application, and you rely on Url authorization ( sections), you need to fix your application ASAP.

The fix is very simple - it's a few lines of code that reject requests that have backslashes or are not in canonical form. Here is the knowledge base article that you should read that provides the fix.

Get to it, folks!

entry.title: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content:
Yet another application that doesn't work under LUA (Least privilege User Account).

1) You can't install this program unless you're an administrator. This isn't surprising, and isn't really all that big of a deal, until you consider,

2) This program won't launch unless you're running under the same account you installed it under. LAME!

It's a sad day when the folks at Google blow it this bad.

Update: here's their solution. Add yourself to admin group, install, remove yourself. Seems to be working so far. You know, if they'd just defer launching the application - let you launch it under the account you plan on using it under, I think it'd be fine. This is an easy fix - hopefully they will fix it before the final release.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content: Yea, but once it's running, this app rocks! It's pathetic that MS can't find a way to search their own OS. Google got it right with tis one.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content:
Oh I won't argue with you about being shocked that Google beat MS to the punch here. I just had such high expectations from the Google guys. They've really let me down.

Of course this is beta software. I sent them an email detailing the problem, so hopefully they will remedy it before release.

entry.title: Yeah, except for the whole email thing
entry.content: If you install as Admin, and run it as Admin, but you run under another account, it doesn't find your Outlook mailbox. Which is just, well, lame.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content:
That's not surprising since the mailbox is part of your user profile. After you posted your comment, I updated this entry with instructions on how to get it working as non-admin. Try it - it's at least running for me now; not sure if it'll be able to index everything (it should, I think though).

Hopefully this will fix it!

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content:
Just out of curiosity, what should it do if you're not an admin? Should it maintain a seperate index DB for each user? What should it then index, every file it can access and just ignore the ones it can't access? Or should it just index files in the user's profile? Web history only?

I would of course agree that apps should allow non-admins to run, but there seem to be some tricky issues here.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content:
Steve,

They have to require higher privilege to install, but they should defer indexing until the application is actually launched by a user.

The problem is that as soon as you install it, they assume that same user is the one who will be using the program.

Indexing definitely needs to be done on a per-user basis, because a lot of the things they are indexing are in the user profile, and are not accessible to other users.

So they are close - their install/startup procedure just needs a little work.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content: I used the MakeMeAdmin.cmd shell from Aaron Margosis this morning to install Google Desktop on my laptop. I had a hunch that it would be specific to the Admin account and it appears I am right. Using Aarons shell script, I am able to temporarily set up a session where my non-Admin account is in the Administrator group and then install the app with all the references pointing to my non-admin account. Closing the session, I am no longer in the Administrator group.

entry.title: re: Google Desktop added to Hall of Shame
entry.content: I think you can't add software to the Hall of Shame until it's out of beta. You can throw a flag for sure, but Hall of Shame should be reserved for released products.

Windows Server 2003 belongs in the Hall of Shame as well. It doesn't (yet) give the same Firewall messages as WXPSP2 does, but it gives some other messages and other random failures. For example the automatic version of Windows Update automatically downloads .NET Framework 1.1 SP1 but can't install it. Windows Update does detect its own failure and then displays incorrect instructions in IE about how to supposedly retry the failed operation. In fact Windows Update remains broken until IE is closed and reopened. Fortunately Windows Update makes a partial recovery after closing and reopening IE, though this security update still fails.

Manually trying to download by following links from msdn.microsoft.com gives various IE error messages along the way and ends up at not being able to download the W2003 version of .NET Framework 1.1 SP1. After making a security change to IE, W2003 can download the thing but then can't install it.

One reason for failure seems to be an attempt to dereference a null pointer during installation. It's really comforting to see how .NET Framework 1.1 SP1 is supposed to improve security.

W2003 also makes other problems for MSDN and Visual Studio.

entry.title: Book on System.DirectoryServices
entry.content:
We need an updated book on programming Active Directory. The books out there now are either going out of print, or are generally focused on using VBScript or C++ to program with ADSI.

I don't know how many of you have used S.DS, but (besides it's lack of support for partial trust), it's a great way to interact with the directory system. A book on this topic, with samples in C# or VB.NET would really be timely, I think. Integrating with AD is a great leverage point for enterprise developers, and with S.DS, it's really gotten a lot more mainstream.

I'm talking with the editors at Addison Wesley to gauge their interest in such a title. Do any of you with a lot of experience programming AD have the cycles and interest to work on this? I'd be happy to help with the organization, overall story, and reviewing. I just don't have the cycles to be the author. Starting a new company takes a lot of attention :-)

If you're interested, contact me directly.

Keith
