entry.title: Is Protocol Transition practical?
entry.content:
Please note that this post is mainly directed at MS folks because it addresses a cross-team issue, and I want to be terse so it'll have a chance of being read.

Imagine a common scenario. Alice makes a call to Bob (Bob exposes some sort of interface, either a web app GUI or web service, it doesn't matter which). She uses a certificate to prove her identity. Bob validates Alice's certificate and looks it up in Active Directory and finds a user account via altSecurityIdentities. He then uses protocol transition to connect to Charlie, his SQL server, using Alice's credentials.

new WindowsIdentity(clientUPN).Impersonate();

SqlConnection conn = new SqlConnection(”server=charlie;integrated security=sspi”);

Here's the gotcha. If Bob isn't running with high privilege, the SQL connection will fail before it even leaves Bob's machine! The SQL client-side plumbing uses performance counters, which open registry keys. But the the token Bob is impersonating is an IDENTIFY level token, because S4U2Self gives you an IDENTIFY token unless you're running in the TCB. And IDENTIFY tokens cannot be used to open secure objects (like registry keys), so the request fails before it even leaves the box!

One “solution” is to make Bob's application run as SYSTEM. This will work because S4U2Self will issue an IMPERSONATE token. But this is a horrible idea, for obvious reasons.

Another solution is to factor out the code new WindowsIdentity(clientUPN) into a separate process (like a COM+ server) that runs as SYSTEM. I've done this and it works fine. But how many people know how to do this sort of thing?

My point here is that protocol transition will encourage people to run middle-tier apps with high privilege when they shouldn't have to. What's the solution? Perhaps the client-side plumbing (like System.Data.SqlClient) should be tested under S4U2Self security contexts, and made to work even when things like perf counters cannot be instantiated.

How many other common scenarios will run into the same problem? How can I use PT to connect to a COM+ server if I cannot load the proxy DLL while impersonating an IDENTIFY token? PT outside of the TCB simply does not seem practical.

Flame away!

entry.title: re: Is Protocol Transition practical?
entry.content:
> What's the solution? Perhaps the client-side plumbing (like System.Data.SqlClient) should be tested under S4U2Self security contexts, and made to work even when things like perf counters cannot be instantiated.

I am not sure whether this will help. For example SqlClient may cause calls to LoadLibrary because it needs additional DLLs, and it will fail because IDENTIFY tokens cannot be used to open files.

entry.title: re: Is Protocol Transition practical?
entry.content:
We are having an internal debate about constrained delegation and your opinion on this matter will be greatly appreciated.

Basically, we have a intranet application with web server that's trusted for Kerberos delegation. The idea that certain highly privileged users will pick items from a list on on the web server. The web page will then impersonate the user and use the user's delegated credentials to perform cetain actions on a backend server.

The backend server is firewalled (IPSEC etc.) such that only the web server can communicate with it.

However, what I find troubling is the fact that the backend server implicitly trusts the list of items it receives from the web server.
If the page that creates the list on the web server is compromised, it paves the way for the hacker to perform any action in context of the privileged user (a luring attack of sorts).

IMO, in such cases, it much better to NOT use delegated credentials and force the highly privileged users to authenticate explicitly to the backend server, confirm the list of actionable items and only then perform the actions using their credentials.

The tradeoff obviously is the risk of exposing some ports on the backend server to the entire intranet vis-a-vis the risk of a luring attack that could result from the compromise of the page on the web server (which is open to the whole intranet). Granted, the confirmation page on the backend server is subject to attacks too, but we have workarounds for it.

What do you think?

entry.title: re: Is Protocol Transition practical?
entry.content:
Can protocol transition be instigated without programmitcally calling the impersonate function - eg does the os do complete this process itself if all the required privelages are present?

I have a scenario where I want NTLM users to gain access to sharepoint and subsequently a document management app (meridio) - Meridio requires a Kerberos Service Ticket - I can't get it to work - I've assigned all the needed privelages to the service accounts - set the spn's etc.

I've seen PT working with the microsoft example code -

Help Appreciated

entry.title: re: Is Protocol Transition practical?
entry.content:
Sure, you can do S4U2Self without impersonating, but the programming model in Windows for getting a ticket for a *remote* service is to impersonate and make the request (deep under the covers, the Kerb SSP sees your impersonation token and uses the impersonated logon session to acquire the necessary service tickets using S4U2Proxy).

But if you're not talking to a Microsoft server, I'm not sure how you're going to authenticate, unless you were planning on programming to the GSSAPI. That's the interoperable way to talk to a non-MS Kerberized server app.

entry.title: WinDev
entry.content:
Here's a link to my security unit testing example. Hope it's helpful!

This blog has been neglected for the last month - I've been slammed getting ready for WinDev (being a track chair is just that much more responsibility) and preparing for Campsight.

Well, Campsight runs next week (I'm flying up to Redmond tomorrow morning, in fact). So life should get back to normal soon. BTW, we sold this event out at 50 people!

Thanks to all who attended my security talks at WinDev. Thanks to the speakers who kindly flew out to help as well:

Dominick Baier gave a great talk on Pen Testing and followed up with a discussion of authorization techniques (which I was sad to miss). Steve Johnson gave a fun talk on Cryptography - it was his first conference talk, and I think he did well! Robert Hurlbut showed how to sandbox code in secure appdomains (the most advanced topic of the week, I'd say) and also discussed one of my favorite topics - how to write least privilege apps. Brent Rector stopped by to give a talk on assembly obfuscation - it was great hanging out with Brent after all these years - he's still as funny as ever, and his product rocks. Fritz (one of the other track chairs) kindly threw in a talk on the ASP.NET 2.0 provider model, and I even got to monkey for him at the end. And Mike Woodring helped out with another really advanced topic, security in the face of multithreading. I think he scared most of the attendees with that title - he didn't get nearly the showing that talk should have gotten :-(

I picked up the rest of the slack, throwing in a few talks at the end when some of my speakers had to bow out for one reason or another. This was the first year we had a security track, and if the evals are any indication, we kicked some serious ass this week. Thanks for all the hard work, guys!

entry.title: Electronic voting
entry.content:
While eating breakfast this morning, I watched a section of 60 Minutes that talked about electronic voting. I saw a number of good points, and witnessed firsthand the naivete of the election officials. One official, when asked about recounts, seemed to think that the electronic systems would be better because you'd get the same count you got last time. She seemed to think that it was a problem that the Florida recounts actually led to different outcomes in 2000. Wow.

One section of the program talked about the leak of some older Diebold voting software that was analyzed at the Johns Hopkins University Information Security Institute. The technical director said, "It was far below state-of-the-art. I would say it was just, they had absolutely no idea what security is about." Diebold claims that the leaked software was a prototype and was never used in real voting machines.

During a discussion of tampering, they showed seals on the machine that would need to be broken in order for tampering to occur. So I guess if I want to tilt election results in favor of the Democrats, say, I break as many of those seals as possible on machines used in heavily Republican precincts. Call it a selective denial of service.

I guess the scariest part of the whole thing was the lack of understanding that people have about security with respect to these machines. So many officials seem to think that it's OK to not have any sort of paper trail. I think that's just insane. The fact that the machines don't incorporate some sort of paper trail leads me to believe that the people designing them aren't as smart as the people who design ATM machines, which do a fine job of providing a paper trail for each transaction. Look, the people designing electronic voting machines should be EXCEPTIONAL, not just average. One suggestion during the episode was that since these folks are building systems that effect national security (a presidential election, yea) they should even be required to have significant security clearances, which would at least ensure background checks on the participants.

As it stands now, the software (which will run the voting machines up to 45 million people will be using on Tuesday) is considered a trade secret, and not even the election officials using the machines are allowed to look at it. So you're trusting Diebold and friends to do the background checks that the government should be doing. Imagine the widespread vote fraud that would result if malicious code somehow found its way into the software that's installed on all these machines.

This is severely misplaced trust.

”The ideal voting system would minimize the number of translation steps, and make those remaining as simple as possible. My suggestion is an ATM-style computer voting machine, but one that also prints out a paper ballot. The voter checks the paper ballot for accuracy, and then drops it into a sealed ballot box. The paper ballots are the "official" votes and can be used for recounts, and the computer provides a quick initial tally. Even this system is not as easy to design and implement as it sounds.”

- Bruce Schenier, Cryptogram (Dec 15, 2000)

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content:
In the UK, we don't have a paper trail. We just have paper. No machines involved in the voting or counting, at any stage of the process (OK, after the ballot papers are printed). This allows a most important characteristic: human judgement. All candidates, their election agents, and their "counting agents" are allowed to attend the sorting and counting of the ballot papers; the supervising officer is a local council appointed official (usually the council's chief executive or town clerk), and the counting staff are volunteers. This should make it a lot harder to commit fraud. Even the largest districts in a general election have fully counted the ballots and recorded results within a day of polls closing, including regions like the Highlands and Islands where ballot boxes have to be carried by ferry to the mainland before counting.

I wrote up a whole entry at http://mikedimmick.blogspot.com/2004/10/inappropriate-uses-of-technology.html.

Obviously the UK process is a lot simpler: we have fewer directly-elected posts generally. We also are a lot smaller in terms of area (in terms of population, about one-fifth of the US population).

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content: Wow. Very insteresting stuff. I'm sure this will get pleny of attention once the post-election lawsuits begin. *sigh*

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content: I not sure why everyone focusses on the voting machines themselves. To my eye, the far bigger problem is that, with the Diebold system, votes are tabulated using a custom Microsoft Access application. What good is a paper trail when the results come from a unsecured Microsoft Access database?

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content: It doesn't help when these unauditable machines are made by a firm whose CEO is, quote, "committed" to delivering votes to Bush (http://www.thenews-messenger.com/news/stories/20030828/localnews/150004.html). Security clearances would be a start, sure, but history tells us that even those with the highest security clearances can still be willing to subvert democracy in order to save it. In order to trust the tallies of the Diebold machines, there should have been either an independently auditable paper trail (which can be verified by the voter at voting time) or the software and system itself has to be auditable and verifiable throughout the process. (Ideally both of course.) O'Dell's comments combined with the lack of verifiability open up yet another avenue of nasty and hard-to-resolve legal challenges if a state using Diebold machines is won marginally by Bush.

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content:
I live in the UK where paper is king, it’s simple and we do not get many problems with just putting a cross on a bit of paper.

I can see the case to automation for more complex counting systems, e.g. single transferable voting.

Why not have the machine print the persons vote on their voting slip, the vote should be printed both in English and a bar code. The counting machine could then just read all the bar codes from the paper, this will make the result easy to check, and be simple enough that all voter can understand why the vote was far.

You also need a legal system you can trust, e.g. own that is one owned by a single party.

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content:
Read this Scientific American article by Ted Skelker of MIT. He argues that paper trails do not improve authenticity.

http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?chanID=sa006&colID=1&articleID=00018DD5-73E7-1151-B57F83414B7F0000

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content:
If you read French, here is a pointer to a questions/answers
session in the Belgian parliament:

http://www.poureva.org/article.php3?id_article=36

Too long to translate, but to summarize: a deputy got a mysterious surplus of 4096 votes during the last elections, and this has been attributed to a cosmic ray.

entry.title: re: Electronic voting
entry.content:
One point that I've found is often overlooked or ignored in these discussions is the relative lack of security in the existing paper-based processes. I assume this varies from place to place, but I don't recall that I've ever been asked for so much as a driver's license when I've gone to vote--I give my address and then, since my name is unusual, I usually just end up pointing to the ledger, "it's that one, third from the bottom...there...thanks!" It's hard to imagine it would be difficult to misrepresent oneself with just a little prepartion and poise, and while this doesn't make it easy to add new ballots or change submitted ballots, the potential for abuse is clearly there.

This is not to suggest that I think the risks in electronic voting are being overblown, particularly because of the potential there for essentially invisible tampering on large scales, which would be logistically challenging with non-electronic systems.

Still, I don't think we should just use the current systems to set the bar, because that seems short-sighted as well.

entry.title: Do you have the latest version of Password Minder
entry.content:
Check the About box. The latest version (available here) is 1.5.0.4. Please make sure you're using the latest version.

The reason I mention this is that I just got my first email from a user who ran into a problem that caused him to lose data. He'd just changed a few passwords (auto-generated them) and before closing PWM (it saves all your changes when you close it down), he ran the export feature.

Well, it turns out that 1.5.0.2 (the version he was running) had a bug in the export function that caused an unhandled exception. So before his password file was updated, PWM crashed. He'd already changed his passwords at the sites though, so he'll have to go reset them now since the changes weren't stored to his password file.

This particular bug was fixed awhile back, and based on his feedback, I'm going to look into adding a top-level exception handler that offers to save your password file to a location of your choice if it's going to crash. But in the meantime, it'd be a good idea to use this as a reminder to download the latest version.

<crawls back into hole with tail between legs>

entry.title: Campsight - day three
entry.content:
We're about halfway through day three of our inaugural event in Redmond. This morning, Aaron started off by motivating Service Orientation and contract-first development, and yet again, we see many people who think contract-first is important.

After Aaron's talk, the attendees got some hands-on experience with the Whitehorse tools for designing service oriented systems. Neat stuff! I'll be happier when the tools start talking more about messages as opposed to methods.

After the lab, Bill Gibson (the lead program manager for the tool we just worked with) gave a talk on contract-first development, and it's clear that he and his team are committed to moving the tools in the right direction. Hopefully he'll be able to swing it. I liked his idea of using code-first to prototype, which gives you a great starting point for switching into contract mode, focusing on the messages, and building a real contract that has broad reach.

Later today, Aaron will give some practical advice on using ASMX and WSE, and I'll be delivering a talk on securing integrated applications, focusing on getting to Windows integrated security as soon as possible. I strongly believe that the quicker you can get to integrated authentication, the better off you are.

The security lab tonight is going to be the most challenging (infrastructure-wise) we'll be doing this week. We'll be switching everyone to run inside a domain (this of course means switching to a new DHCP server, DNS server, etc. for the entire classroom, joining all machines into the domain, and adding accounts for 50 students). With the students helping out, this should go quickly and smoothly. After that, the students will contact our integrated certificate authority to install certificates for their web servers, and obtain personal certificates for client authentication. We'll then use these certs to establish mutual authentication from a web browser to a web portal application which will convert the client cert into a Kerb logon using protocol transition, impersonate that logon, and connect to a remote SQL Server box. This is a really interesting lab because it shows one of the best ways of integrating external applications with Windows integrated security. It's also pretty tricky to setup in an ad-hoc classroom environment. Wish me luck!

entry.title: The Inaugural .NET Campsight (the day after)
The Inaugural .NET Campsight (the day after)
Campsight day five
entry.content:
Wow, what a great week. We have had such great feedback from our first fifty students that I'm really excited about the prospects for Pluralsight.

Today is really all about futures. We had the VSTS product team come in and talk about the new things happening in the tools space, and saw some amazing demos of how we'll be able to do configuration and deployments in the future. You have to see this stuff to believe it.

The IIS 7 team came by and gave a talk and answered questions - it's great to see the IIS configuration model being integrated with the ASP.NET integration model. Going to one place to configure that stuff will really help avoid a lot of the confusion we see today. Imagine configuring modules (both managed and unmanaged) from one config file -  no more ISAPI filters :)

While we were talking about HTTP.SYS, I found a good article on IIS 6 security that you might want to check out.

Don Box will be coming later to talk about Indigo as well.

entry.title: The Inaugural .NET Campsight (the day after)
The Inaugural .NET Campsight (the day after)
Username Token
entry.content:
Matt Powell asked me to write a piece on the Username token, given my interest in the subject. I threw together a really rough draft of my ideas for salting, and he sent it around for review inside the farm, and Hervey Wilson had some further ideas for broadening the scope of the paper.

Well, last week our Campsight was in Building 43, so I was able to walk across to 42 and meet with Matt and Hervey where we hashed out some really great ideas for building bulletproof systems that leverage the Username token. Given the weaknesses of password-based crypto, exposing signatures or ciphertext generated with keys derived from passwords is a really bad idea.

To make a long story short, I'm finishing up the paper this weekend, and it should be up on the MSDN web service dev center in short order. This is going to help a lot of people - I'm really excited about it.

entry.title: What's Keith up to?
entry.content:
November was pretty crazy getting ready for Campsight (which was a spectacular success), and I spent most of December either consulting for Microsoft or spending time with the family, who have been neglected way too much during the startup phase of this new company!

To begin the new year, I've got a number of projects underway:

I'm working on a new week-long security class (we should have a module outline up on the server real soon now).

I'm preparing for Campsight II, which is happening at the Redmond Town Center Marriott (it's an awesome venue if you've never been to Redmond - loads to do when you get done with class in the evenings). As usual, we'll be weaving security topics throughout the entire week, which covers contract-first web service development, BizTalk, ASP.NET 2.0 (we're adding coverage of SharePoint) among a host of other topics. But we'll also have some modules that are dedicated entirely to the topic of security, covering such tricky issues as Kerberos delegation and protocol transition in Windows Server 2003. The last event sold out, so sign up today!

I'm writing several security-related articles for the Smart Client dev center, and continuing to write Security Briefs for MSDN Magazine. The next column to be published focuses on some work I've done integrating the GUI ACL Editor into managed code.

During January, I'll undertake a brief consulting project that will attempt to integrate the .NET Framework into some rather low-level security plumbing in Windows. Due to an NDA, I'm not sure how much I“ll be able to talk about it, but it looks to be a very interesting little project. More on it later, if I can say anything.

Oh, and my security clearance for the US Govt. is about to go through, so pretty soon I'll be teaching classes for some agencies whose names I'm not yet even allowed to know!

With all the prospects we're looking at, Pluralsight is set for a very strong year. Thanks to all who have supported us so far!

entry.title: Deleting system DLLs
entry.content:
I spent part of the day today working on some system deployment tools, and I came across a case where I needed to delete a system DLL that's always in use. Since it seems that every year or so I find myself needing to know this, here's a good algorithm for doing it:

1) Rename the existing file (foo.dll --> foo.deleteme or something like that). This can be done while the DLL is in use, and it allows you to copy up the new file beside the old, locked one.

2) Copy the new file.

3) Call MoveFileEx(oldFile, null, MOVEFILE_DELAY_UNTIL_REBOOT) to schedule the old file for deletion at the next reboot.

4) Reboot the system.

Now there's one gotcha - if you are doing a remote deploy, MoveFileEx doesn't work with remote paths. But all MoveFileEx does is sets a value in the registry to schedule the deletion. Here's the key you should look for:

HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager

...and the value (which normally does not exist) is named PendingFileRenameOperations, which is a MULTI_SZ registry value. This value contains pairs of strings which represent the source and destination for the move. The destination is an empty string in the case of a delete. REGEDIT.EXE complains if you try to do this manually, by the way, but it works fine programmatically. Just be sure to preserve any entries that were there before you got to this key!

Also note the format of the filename in this registry value must be a local path (c:\windows\system32\foo.dll, for example) and it must be prefixed with a funky string: “\??\”. So an example entry for deletion would look like this:

string 1: “\??\c:\windows\system32\foo.dll”

string 2: “”

It's somewhat kludgy, but you can set this key remotely, and call InitiateSystemShutdown to remotely reboot the machine. Of course you must be able to be authenticated and authorized as an admin on the remote box to do any of this stuff!

entry.title: SetWindowLongPtr and /Wp64
entry.content:
Help, readers.

#include <windows.h>
void main() {
  LONG_PTR x = 0;
  SetWindowLongPtr(0, 0, x);
}

Ok, forget the fact that the above code doesn't do anything useful. But you'd expect it to compile without a warning, right? Well, compile it with the default Visual C++ options /Wp64 at a warning level of 4 and you're treated to the following:

cl -c -Wp64 -W4 test.cpp
warning C4244: 'argument' : conversion from 'LONG_PTR' to 'LONG', possible loss of data

I couldn't figure out why SetWindowLongPtr wouldn't actually take a LONG_PTR. Based on this warning it appears to take a LONG.

So I had a peek at the WINUSER.H header file at the actual function declaration. Turns out that there's two definitions, depending on whether a preprocessor switch (_WIN64) is defined. I'll summarize:

#ifdef _WIN64
LONG_PTR SetWindowLongPtr(
    HWND hWnd,
    int nIndex,
    LONG_PTR dwNewLong
);
#else
#define SetWindowLongPtr SetWindowLong
#endif

I searched all the header files in Visual Studio to see if any of them actually define _WIN64, but none do, so I'm assuming this is something defined at compile time by a 64 bit compiler.

Is it just me, or are the header files somewhat broken in VS.NET 2003? The /Wp64 switch is supposed to spit out warnings if you're doing stuff that would cause you trouble with a 64 bit compiler. But calling SetWindowLongPtr is the right thing to do for 64-bit compatibility.

Anybody else run into this? Did you just give up and turn off the /Wp64 switch, or did you find a cleaner workaround? Or am I just doing something really stupid?

entry.title: re: SetWindowLongPtr and /Wp64
entry.content:
Fritz pointed out in a private email that there's a discussion of this issue on the off-topic list:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/win_tech_off_topic/message/36066

Looks like I'm not alone...

entry.title: re: SetWindowLongPtr and /Wp64
entry.content:
Me too! Same issue.
I hit this.
Searched google with "SetWindowLongPtr" and found your blog.
If you found anything, be sure to update us on your blog.

Thanks,
Clement

entry.title: re: SetWindowLongPtr and /Wp64
entry.content:
Keith,

The website you pointed out already explains the cause of the problem, but here's another source that speaks about it:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/msdnmag/issues/01/08/bugslayer/
"The final new warning switch is /Wp64 to help you find 64-bit portability errors. I've found /Wp64 to be quite helpful, except that the SetWindowLongPtr/GetWindowLongPtr macros, which are supposed to aid 32- and 64-bit access, are defined wrong when doing 32-bit compiles. So with /Wp64, you will have extra warnings around them unless you turn them off with the #pragma warning directives."

I get around the issue merely by using #pragma warning directives to disable the warning for that single line of code. I break apart any lines of code with multiple function calls (such as SetWindowLongPtr being a parameter into another function) to ensure I surround ONLY that one line of code, so as not to hide another legit warning of the same type.

Take care,

Jason

entry.title: SAFER
entry.content:
Michael Howard recently published a couple of articles (first, second) that talk about running selected software with lower permission, such as email readers or browsers. A lot of people who normally run as an admin but feel bad about it got really excited about this (article rating 9 out of 9, good work Mike!). One thing that stood out in these articles was the use of the SAFER infrastructure (this is an internal codename for the Software Restriction Policies feature that was added in WinXP).

SAFER is a system for constraining unmanaged code that is similar in spirit to Code Access Security in the .NET Framework. Certain functions (like CreateProcess and LoadLibrary) have special code to check SAFER policy when loading executable code. They gather evidence about the code (hash value, authenticode certificate, URL, etc.), present it to SAFER policy, and decide what level of privilege should be granted to the code. Sound familiar, .NET programmers?

Well, the big difference has always been that (at least to my knowledge), SAFER only supported two levels of privilege: UNRESTRICTED and DISALLOWED. Pretty simple. Code either is allowed to run with all the permissions of the user who launched it, or it's not allowed to run at all.

And until Mike's article, as far as most of us knew, that was all there was to the story. But Mike details three additional levels, which are kind of like the partial trust model in the .NET Framework. I'll leave it to you to read his article for the details, but suffice it to say that there's more to SAFER than the SDK documentation lets on. Just look up SaferCreateLevel in the SDK docs to see what I mean - only the two levels I list above are documented as being usable, but Mike shows a way to get around this by using some other, somewhat less documented levels :-)

These levels cause new processes to be launched with restricted tokens, in particular, the Administrators group is marked DENY_ONLY, which basically makes the token act like the token for a normal user (assuming you're not also in the Power Users group).

I had always assumed that the reason these levels were never documented was due to the problem of luring attacks. Say I'm an email worm and I think I may be loaded into one of these programs that has been crippled by SAFER. What's to stop me from simply sending window messages to Explorer to lure it to do my dirty work for me?

The .NET Framework guys went to major lengths to mitigate luring attacks (I'm sure you've heard about CAS stackwalks), but they had the benefit of having a mechansim for verifying the type safety of code. The unmanaged world has no such luxury.

So I'm of mixed mind about this new information.

1) Did Microsoft really want this documented? If so, why doesn't the platform SDK tell us about it?

2) Are people who jump on this bandwagon going to get a false sense of security and just get nailed by the next generation of virus?

Practically speaking, I'm sure it's a fine idea to use these techniques in the short term, but unless I'm missing something, this really doesn't fix things in the long haul. If enough people start doing this, the bad guys are going to start using the 20 lines of code it takes to exploit one of the many the luring vulnerabilities that are lurking beneath the covers.

Until someone shows me how SAFER prevents luring attacks, I'm taking these undocumented levels (and the whole idea of restricted tokens) with a grain of salt. Pay close attention to Mike's first paragraph where he says the very best way to protect yourself is to run as a non-admin from day to day, and only log in as an admin for those few times when you need to install software or configure your machine in some way.

Of course it's harder than hell to do this, because most programs break when run as non-admin.

Sigh.

entry.title: re: SAFER
entry.content:
I think what you are calling lure attacks are better known as shatter attacks.

The Untrusted level puts new processes into an unnamed job object that uses the JOB_OBJECT_UILIMIT_HANDLES restriction. It prevents the restricted process from obtaining window handles owned by any processes outside the job, therefore protecting them from this type of attack. Try running spyxx as Untrusted; it won't be able to see any windows but its own.

Also, you can't install browser help objects without access of at least the current user. The untrusted level allows only basic well known groups (like Everyone and Users), but not the current user.

I suppose the Basic User and Constrained levels aren't too useful, but the Untrusted one is, since it allows only access that everyone normally has.

entry.title: LsaLogonUser - the function from hell
entry.content:
I always forget that this function requires special care when passing its main argument (the fifth argument, AuthenticationInformation), which is the logon request data structure. The documentation doesn't tell you that this data structure needs to be passed as a blob that contains self-relative pointers (i.e., all the strings for user, domain, password must be included in that blob as opposed to being allocated separately).

And when you get it wrong, you get ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER, which doesn't help much, since LsaLogonUser takes about a hundred thousand parameters (well, it seems to, anyway).

Here's some code that might help you if you try to call this function. It allocates an MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON data structure as an example.

int _stringLenInBytes(const wchar_t* s) {
    if (!s) return 0;
    return (lstrlen(s)+1) * sizeof *s;
}
 
void _initUnicodeString(UNICODE_STRING* target, wchar_t* source, USHORT cbMax) {
    target->Length        = cbMax - sizeof *source;
    target->MaximumLength = cbMax;
    target->Buffer        = source;
}
 
MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON*
_allocLogonRequest(const wchar_t* domain,
                   const wchar_t* user,
                   const wchar_t* pass,
                   DWORD* pcbRequest) {
 
    const DWORD cbHeader = sizeof(MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON);
    const DWORD cbDom    = _stringLenInBytes(domain);
    const DWORD cbUser   = _stringLenInBytes(user);
    const DWORD cbPass   = _stringLenInBytes(pass);
 
    // sanity check string lengths
    if (cbDom > USHRT_MAX || cbUser > USHRT_MAX || cbPass > USHRT_MAX) {
        LOG_CF(L"Input string was too long");
        return 0;
    }
 
    *pcbRequest = cbHeader + cbDom + cbUser + cbPass;
 
    // MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON is actually a variable length data structure
    // although the documentation does not specify this. The domain, user,
    // and password data must be bundled up in a single chunk along with the
    // MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON header and passed as a single unit.
    MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON* pRequest =
        (MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON*)LocalAlloc(LMEM_FIXED, *pcbRequest);
    if (!pRequest) return 0;
 
    pRequest->MessageType = MsV1_0InteractiveLogon;
 
    char* p = (char*)(pRequest + 1); // point right past MSV1_0_INTERACTIVE_LOGON
 
    wchar_t* pDom  = (wchar_t*)(p);
    wchar_t* pUser = (wchar_t*)(p + cbDom);
    wchar_t* pPass = (wchar_t*)(p + cbDom + cbUser);
 
    CopyMemory(pDom,  domain, cbDom);
    CopyMemory(pUser, user,   cbUser);
    CopyMemory(pPass, pass,   cbPass);
    
    _initUnicodeString(&pRequest->LogonDomainName, pDom,  (USHORT)cbDom);
    _initUnicodeString(&pRequest->UserName,        pUser, (USHORT)cbUser);
    _initUnicodeString(&pRequest->Password,        pPass, (USHORT)cbPass);
 
    return pRequest;
}

entry.title: re: LsaLogonUser - the function from hell
entry.content:
If a NULL pointer is passed into _allocLogonRequest() for the domain argument (or even user or pass), the _initUnicodeString() function will set:
Lenth to 0xfffe
MaximumLength to 0x0,
Buffer pointer to something other than NULL.

In this case the LsaLogonUser() on Windows 2003 returns a ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER error.

So is there a better we to handle a NULL domain pointer?

entry.title: re: LsaLogonUser - the function from hell
entry.content:
Hi Keith,

Thanks for your enlightling article!
Do you also happen to know how LsaLogonUser can be used with a KERB_SMART_CARD_LOGON structure? More specifically, the mysterious CspData / CspDataLength fields?

WinLogon seems to cache the PIN code for a smart card indefinitely; which poses a problem when you change your smart card's PIN code. As soon as your Kerberos ticket expires, Lsa will get a new one for you (under the sheets), use the old PIN, and therefore block your card. (It's not smart enough to invalidate its PIN cache when it receives SCARD_W_WRONG_CHV and keeps retrying anyway).

We figure a call to LsaLogonUser with the new PIN at the time the PIN is changed, might tell WinLogon to use the new PIN. _If_ that PIN is not stored per logon session, that is...

BTW, back in the previous millennium, I got you as an instructor at a Developmentor Windows Guerilla course. It was a great experience! I don't believe I even ever had a holiday that was so totally refreshing. :-)

Jan.

jan +a+t+ yantrax dotcom.

entry.title: New Article: Securing the Username Token with WSE 2.0
entry.content:
Back in November I worked with Hervey and Matt on a piece dedicated to the care and feeding of Username Tokens. If you're using the Username Token, you should read this article, which just went live at the MSDN Web Services Dev Center. The Username Token is so incredibly easy to abuse.

Thanks to Hervey and Matt for their input.

entry.title: re: New Article: Securing the Username Token with WSE 2.0
entry.content:
Thanks Keith. Nice article! Have been having a lot of debates with myself and others around these ideas as of late, so I toss some more spaghetti on the wall...

"We can make progress on both fronts by modifying our approach to creating the password equivalent. Instead of using SHA-1(password), we use SHAd-1(password + userName + scopeUri) as the password equivalent.

userName and scopeUri are salt values. By including the user name as a salt, we limit the scalability of an offline attack by forcing the enemy to attack one password at a time since each account has a different salt."

This allows us to not “have” to store any salt, as the userName and scopeUri are known for each request. However, it does not really add anything over using random salt which is recommended for salt. Instead we could generate 10 bytes (each byte in the 0-255 range) of true random salt and use that instead. That would also satisfy the requirement that the verifier is different on other sites as each salt is random. We also note that the only reason for salt is so that the same password will not result in the same verifier in the db – so this forces a new dictionary attack on each verifier. This does not really hurt me that bad if I am the attacker because I don’t really expect too many people will be using the same PWD anyway. If I do get one or two, that is nice, but no great bargain. So we want salt and we want pwd equiv to not be a simple SHA1(password) of the clear password. Therefore client can send SHA1(userName + password) password equivalent (PWE) to prevent simple dictionary attacks in the pipeline and use SHA1(DBSalt + PWE) as the verifier like (Note this still assumes encrypted channel as recommended):

Client Password Equiv (PWE) = SHA1(userName + password)
DBSalt = RandomBytes(10)
DBVerifier = SHA1(DBSalt + PWE)
Server Verify logic becomes: return ( DBVerifier == SHA1(DBSalt + PWE) );

At user creation, server generates random salt bytes and adds the PWE and hashes that. Verifier is stored along with the salt in the db. When a client sends PWE, the DB salt is pre-pended and hashed and compared to Verifier. This also eliminates the need for the client to request the salt and scopeUri before hand - so I don't have to publish either or worry about canonical forms for user names, etc.

"scopeUri is simply a string that is unique to your password database. This ensures that the password equivalents you are using are different from those that another site uses. Neither of these salts is secret. An attacker gains no additional benefit by discovering their values."

But if I am the attacker and have all the salts and the verifier, I gain great benefit by having all the inputs I need to perform the crack (minus the clear password). So it does not really slow my algo down much to append the salt(s). To this point, it could be interesting to *protect the salt by encryption. Thinking out load...Say you have a Salt Admin and a Salt Service/program. This elected person is not an Admin. A service on the machine runs under Salt admin account - this account pwd is super long and totally random. The service's one public API is to take a PWE and the encrypted salt string and return the Verifier bytes. The caller can verify returned bytes against DBVerifier as above. Now you need the salt admin and DB admin to get together to crack db passwords. Just a thought, could have various forms.

With all this discussion of user databases, I still wonder how great it is to require thousands of companies to build and maintain separate databases when we already have this cool thing called AD? We can leverage helpdesk, password policies, pwd change requests, etc. using existing AD tools that most people will already be familiar with. Naturally this does require we have the *clear pwd in our verify logic as we have to call Win32s LogonUser to verify username/pwd. Naturally, we will encrypt the pwd at the client using the server's public key or session key. And we have to somehow reduce the amount of code that has access to the clear pw in the server pipeline. Have some thoughts on that, but probably another discussion.

Considering all above, I would probably not allow UsernameTokens at all! But instead require SecurityContextTokens only. All methods will require at least a signed SOAP body that is signed with an *authenticated SCT (or Derived SCT) - nothing else is allowed. Now you can focus attention strictly on the mechanics of how the SCT is generated and securing the pwd within that negotiation period. I have a soap.tcp implementation of this at:
http://spaces.msn.com/members/staceyw/Blog/cns!1pnsZpX0fPvDxLKC6rAAhLsQ!273.entry . Anyway, this is all interesting stuff. Thanks again for your article. Cheers.

-- William Stacey [MVP]

entry.title: re: New Article: Securing the Username Token with WSE 2.0
entry.content:
This is an excellent article.

There is a potential problem with the method you describe in "A Non-Solution: Sending Username Tokens in the Clear":

>>>... You must also document a canonical form for user names, or silly things like case insensitivity will case some users to fail authentication.<<<

Doing something like translating the user name to lowercase is problematic since such a transformation is culture-dependent. I might be tempted to use String.ToLower(CultureInfo.InvariantCulture), but this is only defined on the .NET platform. For example, there would be no way to guarantee that you would produce the same lowercase representation using Java.

I suppose it might be possible to gather some bits from the user name in a culture-independent way, but my point is that the obvious solution might not work.

entry.title: re: New Article: Securing the Username Token with WSE 2.0
entry.content:
Andy,

Yep, the whole naming problem is something that I brought up when Hervey first suggested incorporating the user name into the hash. I immediately thought of the issues one would have canonicalizing the name: user names are almost universally not case sensitive, so I figured canonicalization would make that problematic, especially given localization issues.

That's why it's part of my "non-solution" ;-)

entry.title: Admin to Programmer
entry.content:
I've started a new wiki page called AdminToProgrammer where I'm soliciting feedback from system administrators.

Given that a big part of my job is to teach programmers how to build secure software, I recently asked for help from a community of sysadmins. I wanted to know, given their experience deploying, maintaining, and securing application software, what one thing could developers do to make their jobs easier?

This wiki page summarizes some of the feedback I received.

If you are a system administrator and have something to add, just double-click that wiki page to edit it, and speak your mind.

If you are a programmer and care to hear what admins are saying, surf to the page and enjoy.

I will be incorporating this feedback into my security classes.

entry.title: You can get around it.
entry.content: This photo just says it all, doesn't it? (from Schneier)

entry.title: AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute
entry.content:
There's a lot of confusion around this attribute, which is why I'd like to point out that Shawn Farkas has written a really helpful and accurate piece on the mechanics and concept behind this attribute.

He's also pointed out that in Whidbey, the error message you get on failure to load an assembly without this attribute has been reworded from “Security Error”, which was really quite unhelpful, to something considerably more useful: “That assembly does not allow partially trusted callers“.

entry.title: re: AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute
entry.content: Talking about Security, I wish Serialization could get a little enhancement. i.e. If the expected formatter isn't seen, I'd like to atleast deserialize to some information, if not all. That'd be a nice thing don't u think?

entry.title: re: AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute
entry.content: Thanks buddy, I was very confused about the usage of [assembly: AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers] in classes so far. The articles cleared up my doubts.

entry.title: Welcome Jim Wilson!

Jim Wilson has joined Pluralsight to help develop our smart client curriculum. Jim's been immersed in the compact framework for several years, and has a lot of great insight about building apps that can deal with “just-enough connectivity“, as he puts it. But read his new blog yourself to find out!

Subscribed.

entry.title: Welcome Jim
SHA-1 Broken
entry.content:
Thanks Craig for the heads up. Schneier points to a paper that demonstrates an attack against SHA-1 that “pretty much puts a bullet in it”.

If this pans out, a lot of people are going to be scrambling. We've been told by the experts for a long time to prefer SHA-1 over MD5. But Schneier warned years ago in Secrets and Lies that not much research effort had been put into examining cryptographic hash functions, so this “surprise” really shouldn't be all that surprising.

Over the last year, I've been recommending that folks use SHA-256 based on Ferguson and Schneier (if you are writing crypto code, please read this book). My guess is that a lot of folks will be moving in this direction soon.

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content: NIST requires the federal government to move to SHA-256 or SHA-512 by 2010. They have recommended that the migration start now for both vendors and clients, wherever possible.

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content:
Well, the book you mentioned says: "We don't want to recommend them, but we don't have much choice" this is hardly a glowing recommendation. It really is surprising just how little work seems to have been done into hash functions. The major problem with the longer functions is just how slow they are (you can typically AES encrypt a string in the same time it takes to calculate the SHA-512 hash).
Ah well...now to get my own supercomputer soi I can crack X-Box games (which use SHA-1 as a verification hash) :-)

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content: Incidentally, there's a nice table of hash functions along with attacks here: http://planeta.terra.com.br/informatica/paulobarreto/hflounge.html

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content: Ferguson mentions that hashing is theoretically much more complicated than encryption, so it's not surprising that a good hash function will take longer to compute than encrypting the same data. The industry has been using the high perf hash functions (MD5 and SHA-1), and it looks like it's coming around to haunt them now.

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content: I don't see how that would change things much. It stands to reason that there has to be collisions as 20 bytes can not hold all possible combinations of data in the wild. Trying to find another combination of data that would match to *your hash would still seem to be almost impossible (and the data would have to be some kind of reasonable input.) Am I missing something?

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content:
2^20 is an awful large search space to find a collision. A successful attack implies that this search space is significantly reduced.

Even an attack message that is complete garbage will likely do damage in many systems. A hash (or more specifically a MAC) often protects trusted data as it flows over the network. If the data is trusted, it may not be checked for wellformedness before being consumed.

Those who were paranoid about input, even from supposedly trusted sources, will reap benefits here.

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content:
"Those who were paranoid about input, even from supposedly trusted sources, will reap benefits here."

Amen!!!

entry.title: re: SHA-1 Broken
entry.content:
Another perspective:

http://www.intertwingly.net/blog/2005/02/16/SHA-1-Broken

entry.title: Fully trusted GAC
entry.content:
A lot of folks in the past have made the assumption that assemblies in the GAC are somehow special with respsect to security. In version 1.1 of the .NET Framework (and even up through beta 1 of Whidbey) this was in fact the case. The only reason GAC'd assemblies were granted full trust was a side effect of them being on the local machine. Default policy has always granted full trust to assemblies on the local machine.

In beta 2 this changes. GAC'd assemblies get full trust regardless of policy (although you can still run with partial trust using assembly-level attributes). Shawn Farkas explains the reasons why, and is looking for feedback for anyone who would be put off by this change.

entry.title: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
How many of you were incensed when the supermarket cards came to town?

I know I was. My premise has always been that the supermarkets raised their prices, then offered “discounts” to people who submitted to having their purchases tracked. I recently ran across someone who did a little study when those cards went into effect to see what sort of discount he was really getting (granted this guy has an agenda, but his results are not terribly surprising to me).

Which is why I really enjoyed this prank, where a guy has created a system to allow you to use his card instead of your own:

With these concerns in mind, I've made a habit of these simple steps to help keep my grocery-shopping anonymous: 1)  I sign up with an alias and 2) I swap cards regularly with friends.

Now I want to try something different. I want to take the credit for all of my shopping, and for your shopping too!

On a more serious note, recently a Washington firefighter felt the brunt of the supermaket card, when his purchase records were used by the police to charge him with arson. If you weren't thinking much about this invasion of privacy, perhaps you will after reading this fellow's story:

Lyons' arrest came after detectives learned a grocery store card in his name showed he had purchased several fire starters.

EDIT: The firefighter in this story was innocent!

entry.title: RE: Supermarket cards
entry.content: What DA uses his discount card to buy things he's going to use to commit a crime? He asked to be caught.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
I agree that a real perp would be an idiot to use a discount card. But you missed the point - this was a false positive.

The firefighter in question didn't commit the crime. His only crime was using his discount card to purchase groceries.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
I do not like supermarket cards as currently implemented, but I do see a use for something similar if it was a more opaque operation.
It is helpful for companies to have information on customers so that they can better target things to you. In this case it is an under the counter, sneaky operation where they are basically milking you without providing much of a benefit (actually, they are probably lowering the cost of annoying means of advertising to the point where they are justifiable).
However, if I was being offered more, I would find it valuable. For example, if my grocery store provided a download into Money 2005 that would provide me a detailed list of what I purchased that enabled me to evaluate how much I would save if I went to the generic brand, that would be a nice tradeoff for me. The collection of data also needs to be explicit. I would prefer that the information on me have certain privacy guarantees -- I would allow the generic information that did not identify me individually different restrictions than the selling of my address, etc.
The problem here is not the information, it is that the informtation is controlled by the wrong people and that the whole idea of what information is being collected for what purpose is done in a deceptive way.
WRT the fire-fighter, this is just another tool that law enforcement should have, given proper warrants and the like. This is a problem of an overzealous prosecuter, not supermarket cards. I would presume that you would not object to the prosecuter using receipts found in someone's house if they had been obtained with a proper warrant -- it is the misuse of that evidence that is objectionable.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
Agreed. Scary how we're willing to give up our "privacy" to save a few bucks. Scarier still is that the government has access to private records of the grocery store. Probably allowed because of the "war against drugs" and the "secret meth labs" .

At least we can still buy groceries without waiting in hour-long lines.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
"I agree that a real perp would be an idiot to use a discount card. But you missed the point - this was a false positive.

The firefighter in question didn't commit the crime. His only crime was using his discount card to purchase groceries."

You see the Yin but not the Yang. Suppose after more investigation the fire was started with charcoals and Mr. Fireman purchased fire logs. Now he could be cleared of the crime and the real criminal could be found more easily. If you are clean actor, this kinda thing would seem to work more in your favor and less for the criminal. Naturally, there will always be extreme examples.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
Costco sent me a letter saying they were recalling packages of imported almonds because of a suspected link to food poisoning. The next time I went to Costco, I brough back 3.5 packages of almonds and they gave me a refund for 4 packages. How would they be able to do that if they didn't have my registration information?

By the way the government didn't ban all imports of almonds from the same country, and other stores continue to sell almonds imported from the same country though of course not under Costco's house brand name. By the way the country of origin is the United States.

entry.title: Una storia interessante sulle carte di fedelizzazione...
re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
With respect to Costco - how did they do that before we had supermarket cards? They trust you, the shopper, to be honest, and most folks are. They would happily let the odd 'honest mistake' go by because they gained more from being perceived as offering good service.

And I think Keith's point is more about an invasion of privacy. I, for one, do not and never intend to have a supermarket card, it's another small breach of my privacy that I can well do without, added to the other small and larger amounts of data out there about us it, for one thing, makes identity theft much easier. This isn't an issue here in the UK yet but it is in the US, and getting worse all the time.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
Yep, Kev. Given the recent posts, there are clearly folks out there who believe that having databases full of information about people's behaviors can be a *good* thing. I respect their opinion but do not share it.

What bugs me about the supermarket thing is the way they went about it. They basically forced people to use the cards or pay higher prices. But most people don't think about their privacy until an event occurs that shows how dangerous these sorts of databases can be (being arrested on false charges, for example).

The data itself is not dangerous. The danger lies in who is allowed to use it. If you have a high degree of trust in your government, the police, companies who keep these databases, etc., you might be inclined to think they do more good than harm. I for one do not have a high degree of trust in any of those entities.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
> With respect to Costco - how did they do
> that before we had supermarket cards? They
> trust you, the shopper, to be honest

I think the answer to the question is that they wouldn't have been able to do it (except maybe by sending a letter to *all* members), and I can't figure out what the subsequent statement is trying to say.

Costco sent letters to members who had bought packages of almonds that Costco used to import and sell. Members who brought those packages back got refunds. How would Costco have managed it before they had cards, Costco would have depended on customers being honest, honesty would have been the way for customers to know that Costco was recalling the almonds, sorry I just don't get it.

Yes I understand the privacy concern, but I was just pointing out that it cuts both ways. If the store didn't have records then it would have been a lot tougher for them to notify customers.

When car manufacturers discover serious defects that need to be repaired, they're supposed to inform customers about recalls. Manufacturers other than Mitsubishi Motors obey this law. How could they do it if they didn't have records? Customer honesty wouldn't be a substitute. The honesty of customers of Mitsubishi Motors didn't bring them the information that Mitsubishi Motors was illegally neglecting to recall cars.

> The data itself is not dangerous. The danger
> lies in who is allowed to use it.

Half of a bingo for that. The other half is the danger from who is allowed to abuse it, who does not get punished for abusing it.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content: My local supermarket has the insidious habit of offering a deep discount on gasoline for "frequent shoppers", so I'm hooked. But I completely agree with your point. If the ChoicePoint scandal proves anything, it proves that personal information persisted in a database will eventually be used for some nefarious purpose.

entry.title: re: Supermarket cards
entry.content:
> I think the answer to the question is that
> they wouldn't have been able to do it
> (except maybe by sending a letter to *all*
> members), and I can't figure out what the
> subsequent statement is trying to say.

But they would. We simply haven't had Supermarket 'loyalty' cards that long, life went on before we had the cards, there were product recalls before we had the cards. In the 'old' days firms would have advertised in the press and put up posters in stores, we don't need loyalty cards for this, sure, it may make life easier in this particular respect, but we don't *need* loyalty cards to manage recalls.

> When car manufacturers discover serious
> defects that need to be repaired, they're
> supposed to inform customers about recalls.
> Manufacturers other than Mitsubishi Motors
> obey this law. How could they do it if they
> didn't have records?

I'm not sure this is realistic either. Does everybody own new cars? If not, how do manufactures contact those folks that bought second-hand cars? I would guess that the number of people that are contacted directly by manufactures is much lower than the total number of people that own the model that is being recalled. So how do manufacturers contact those people, same way Costco would, advertising and informational campaigns.

> I for one do not have a high degree of
> trust in any of those entities.

I'm with Keith, I would prefer to keep as much of my data as private as possible, which, unfortunately, seems to be getting harder each day,

entry.title: Writing Partially Trusted Code
entry.content:
...is hard.

I'm curious how many of you are doing it, and what challenges you've come across. The reason I ask is that I'm currently working on an article for the Smart Client developer center on the topic of writing managed applications that run with partial trust, and I want to make sure I'm addressing as many real world concerns as I can.

If you leave a comment describing your successes and difficulties, please also consider emailing me via my contact link (on the left pane of my blog). That will allow me to contact you if I have questions about your comment. Thanks!

entry.title: WSE2
entry.content: It's hard, and since we have to use web services with secyrity (WSE2), it means that our app has to demand full trust :(

entry.title: re: Writing Partially Trusted Code
entry.content: I've been writing almost exclusively partially trusted code for some time now, and I can't say that I find it to be all that difficult. Creating fully trusted proxies is a bother, but it's more slogging "hard" than tricky "hard". Then again, almost all of my work has been done on locally run code, so the partial trust is often by choice rather than enforced, and I can usually claim any permissions that my code needs. That said, I've rarely found the need to claim more than a handful of permissions for any given assembly, so maybe I just work on bizarre apps...

entry.title: re: Writing Partially Trusted Code
entry.content: I intentionally advised my client to *not* take the route of partial trust because IMO it adds complexity to little benefit.

entry.title: re: Writing Partially Trusted Code

Does that differ from exclusive almost trusted partial code?
Trusted partially almost exclusive code?
Partially coded exclusive almost trust?

Sorry, nothing personal, your wording just happened to be almost, but not quite, exactly unlike a distant memory of twisty little passages, some alike and some different.

entry.title: re: Writing Partially Trusted Code
entry.content: If you're using SSL, the headers of the message are protected as well.

entry.title: re: Writing Partially Trusted Code

entry.title: Another sad tale in the saga of software licensing
entry.content:
No more Internet product reactivation for Windows?

It's just bits, and when all you're selling are bits, it's very difficult to make people who don't want to pay cough up the dough.

The recording industry has the same problem. Ultimately this problem starts to affect legitimate users.

As Schneier keeps pointing out, security is all about tradeoffs, and this particular one is going to piss off an awful lot of system administrators.

Think this new policy will last? I have my doubts.

entry.title: re: Another sad tale in the saga of software licensing

entry.title: re: Another sad tale in the saga of software licensing

If the OEM copy of Windows is legitimately acquired from the authorized supplier, you won't need to activate. If you reinstall from the OEM's image disk, you shouldn't need to reactivate, is my guess.

entry.title: TechEd Security BOFs
entry.content:
Seeing as I'll be doing a Tech Ed preconference session this year and perhaps some talks during the week, I went ahead and submitted some BOF suggestions. The first is called Writing Secure Code, and it's all about developers getting together and sharing war stories and tips on building bulletproof systems. Here's the description:

Bring your questions as well as your experiences to this interactive discussion. Participants will share what techniques they are using to ensure bulletproof implementations, including third party tools. Also on the agenda will be the top threats that developers need to worry about when writing code. Remember, it's not just the guys calling security APIs that need to worry about this! Anyone writing code to access valuable assets should care about this topic, so let's have a big turnout!

The second is called Writing Partially Trusted Code, and is designed to help answer questions people may have when writing apps that run with partial trust. Here's the description for that session:

Writing partially trusted code can be tricky. But a lot of people feel that it's an important tool in our security arsenal: by running with only the permissions we need, the CLR puts walls around our apps to help ensure we can't be tricked into doing something we didn't intend to do. Come discuss the pros and cons of running under partial trust. There are a lot of gotchas, so if you've had experiences, we'd love to hear about them. And if you're just considering taking on the challenge of writing partially trusted code, you'll get a great head start by joining us.

Robert Hurlbut beat me to the punch and submitted a BOF on developing code as a non-admin. You can bet I voted for that one as well.

The thing is, none of these sessions will happen unless enough people vote for them. So if you think any of these would be useful for developers, please vote early, vote often, and I'll see you all at TechEd!

entry.title: re: SURVEY: Who is building or shipping .NET applications today?

For one customer, one of my colleagues is using C# to control two external pieces of equipment via serial ports, so he has had to do some threading and interacting with serial card drivers. I don't know his real application though.

One customer asked me[*] to write a DLL to be callable from VB, and subsequently it turned out to be for both VB6 and VB2003, so I gave sample client applications in both languages calling the DLL.

In fact in the case I worked on here is some feedback for the CLR people. 40 years ago PL/I let the programmer specify lower bounds for array indices. 10 years ago Microsoft allowed it too, though in VB not PL/I. And Microsoft allowed it in ODL files too. When Microsoft says that Microsoft has lost the technology to do it, Microsoft continues earning Microsoft's reputation. Sure programmers can put minus signs and constants (or variables) in every array access, just like we do in C. Microsoft never misses an opportunity to push people who are neutral (in some way or other) into enemy camps.

entry.title: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content:
Shawn Farkas recently posted an interesting note about impersonation. He points out that the following code...

WindowsImpersonationContext ctx = identity.Impersonate();
try { DoWork(); } finally { ctx.Undo(); }

... has a subtle hole - if an untrusted caller is above you on the stack somewhere, and if he can cause DoWork to throw an exception for some reason (perhaps by temporarily exhausting some resource that DoWork needs), he can run arbitrary code in the context of an exception filter (e.g., the Where clause in VB).

He's right. This is very subtle. But it applies to many more situations than just impersonation. If you are being called by untrusted code, then you have to assume that this trick can be used to run arbitrary malicious code in the middle of any of your routines. What happens if your state is inconsistent at the moment an exception filter runs? We often use finally blocks to clean things up before we leave the “safety” of a private function. Now we discover that our classes need to worry about reentrancy by potentially malicious code anytime they call a function that could throw an exception?

This is crazy. It seems to me that untrusted code should not be *allowed* to install exception filters in the first place. But the following code runs just fine under the "Internet" permission set:

' VB console application that attacks a C# class library using an exception filter
Imports ClassLibrary
Module Module1
    Sub Main()
        Dim victim As New Victim
        Try
            victim.Update(2, 3)
        Catch When ExploitCode(victim) = True
        End Try
    End Sub
    Function ExploitCode(ByVal victim As Victim) As Boolean
        Console.WriteLine("ExploitCode calling back into victim. IsConsistent returns {0}", victim.IsConsistent)
        Return True
    End Function
End Module

And here is the class under attack (totally benign, but it makes the point). Someone outside this class should never see FALSE returned from IsConsistent. But that's exactly what happens when the VB console app above calls into the code below, because it can reenter the Victim class whenever an exception is thrown (even a handled exception!)

using System;
namespace ClassLibrary {
    public class Victim {
        int a = 0;
        int b = 0;
        int sum = 0;
        public void Update(int newA, int newB) {
            try {
                sum = newA + newB;
                doWork();
                a = newA;
                b = newB;
            }
            finally {
                // ensure state is consistent before we leave
                sum = a + b;
            }
        }
        public bool IsConsistent() {
            return sum == a + b;
        }
        private void doWork() {
            throw new ApplicationException("whatever");
        }
    }
}

The problem here is that the attacker is able to run code between the guarded block and the finally block. The author of this class clearly didn't expect this. One solution is to use a catch block instead of a finally block. That would prevent the attacker's exception filter from running. I wonder if the BCL team thought about this? Time to break out Reflector and search for finally blocks in their code, because if they didn't think about this, there's very likely some vulnerabilities just waiting to be discovered by partially trusted code.

entry.title: re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content:
This makes me feel better about my usual model of "if you're in my process, I'm hosed anyway, so I only guard stuff from outside."

:)

entry.title: re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content:
This problem is noted is guidelines:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/dnnetsec/html/THCMCh21.asp

Do you use exception filters?
If so, be aware that the code in a filter higher in the call stack can run before code in a finally block. Check that you do not rely on state changes in the finally block, because the state change will not occur before the exception filter executes.

I think FxCop catches some if these problems.

entry.title: More on First Pass Exception Issues
re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content:
It's definately a problem. Of course, catching and rethrowing everywhere makes debugging a bear. In my code where I safely revert the impersonation, (http://blogs.msdn.com/shawnfa/archive/2005/03/24/401905.aspx), I use the same trick that the attacker uses. Namely, installing an exception filter so that I can revert state on the first pass of handling, yet not interfere with the exception state at all.

-Shawn

entry.title: re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content: Never considered using finally directly after try. Always went through the catch block. Good to know.

entry.title: re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content: One thing you could add to the post is the simple fix which is to add another try/catch block around the one you want to protect. This way, the malicious filter will get the state for the outside try/catch and won't be able to exploit it.

entry.title: re: Exception filters considered dangerous
entry.content:
shouldn't the feature be removed? seems a little silly to give access to a class that is in an inconsistant state (i.e. error thrown, 'finally' not executed).

you've basically allowed the insertion of a 'catch' block. Seems to break the idea of 'incapsulation'.

as to the impersonation (which i'm not that familiar with) issues, why does that request grant permission to all 'assemblies'. shouldn't it only grant that priveledge to the one requesting permission? at least by default? it would obviously also need to allow system assemblies...

or would there be a problem with this that I don't see? (or does it do this already and we are assuming malicious code is _in_ our assembly...)

entry.title: CAPTCHA enabled blogs
entry.content:
We've been getting a fair amount of comment spam, and we've got some heuristics on the server that allow us to detect and reject much of it automatically, but we've still had some bots that have managed to leak through. At a request from some of the bloggers at pluralsight.com, I've implemented a simple CAPTCHA solution to help us distinguish humans from spambots.

I'm dogfooding my own solution here, so if you have a moment, try it out by posting a comment on this thread.

This is opt-in for bloggers at pluralsight.com; for most of us the server-side heuristics are blocking spam just fine, so we won't need to turn on this feature. So far only Craig and Aaron have requested it, so you'll see it on their blogs as well.

It'll be interesting to see if any bots are able to break through our very simple image generation technique (I used the routine posted on codeproject.com for the image generation). Thanks to BrainJar for publishing this simple algorithm that works nicely in .NET.

Implementing this in .TEXT was rather interesting given that it doesn't support either session state or viewstate :-)

entry.title: re: CAPTCHA enabled blogs
entry.content: Works for me!

entry.content: A fair test of CAPTCHA would be to turn on CAPTCHA and turn off the heuristics (or at least log the rejects).

entry.title: re: CAPTCHA enabled blogs
entry.content: I also note that an accidental invalid code does not show the user an error, the post simply gets rejected. This is bad for real users for two reasons (1) It is confusing to a real user for they expect the comment to be accepted and it is not and (2) the time and effort composing the comment is immediately lost and therefore frustrating.

entry.title: Unhandled exceptions and finally blocks
entry.content:
This first example installs an unhandled exception handler to the default AppDomain, which catches any unhandled exceptions on any thread in any AppDomain in the process.

// test1.cs
using System;
using System;
class App {
  static void Main() {
    AppDomain.CurrentDomain.UnhandledException +=
      new UnhandledExceptionEventHandler(Handler);
    Run();
  }
  static void Run() {
    try {
      Console.WriteLine("Throwing.");
      throw new Exception();
    }
    finally {
      Console.WriteLine("Finally.");
    }
  }
  static void Handler(object sender, UnhandledExceptionEventArgs args) {
    Console.WriteLine("Unhandled exception handler, exiting process");
    Environment.Exit(1);
  }
}

And here's the results of running it:

215 C% test1
Throwing.
Unhandled exception handler, exiting process

Note that the finally block did not execute, because I terminated the process in the handler (it would have run if I had allowed the process to continue executing, but generally we like to fail fast when an unhandled exception occurs). The interesting point here is that the handler executes before any finally blocks get a chance to execute. This may surprise some people.

Note that if I used a using() statement, Dispose() wouldn't have been called either.

Here's a different approach that works fine for a simple single threaded app, and allows the finally blocks to run, and the application simply terminates by returning from Main.

// test2.cs
using System;
class App {
  static void Main() {
    try {
      Run();
    }
    catch (Exception) {
      Console.WriteLine("Main caught an exception, exiting process");
    }
  }
  static void Run() {
    try {
      Console.WriteLine("Throwing.");
      throw new Exception();
    }
    finally {
      Console.WriteLine("Finally.");
    }
  }
}

entry.title: Exception Handling Tricks
re: Unhandled exceptions and finally blocks
entry.content:
Not so related to your issue, but one must always include try...catch blocks in main method (example 1), because the unhandled exception handler may not be registered successfully. AFAIK this is only .NET v1.1 problem. Jason Clark blogs about this issue here.
http://wintellect.com/WEBLOGS/wintellect/archive/2005/03/30/941.aspx

Anyway, thanks for pointing this out!

entry.title: ransom-malware
entry.content:
http://wfmynews2.com/news/technology/tech_article.aspx?storyid=41656

“Washington, DC -- Computer users already anxious about viruses and identity theft have new reason to worry: Hackers have found a way to lock up the electronic documents on your computer and then demand $200 over the Internet to get them back.“

This is an interesting idea - reversible damage - encrypt the user's files then extort money from them to supply the decryption key. Given how most home users backup their files (never), it'll likely be a very successful venture.

Unfortunately the name the “experts“ are using, ransomware, has already been taken by the open source community. Hope they come up with a better moniker.

entry.title: re: ransom-malware
entry.content: Come up with a better moniker? Why would they bother? They already ruined the original meaning of the word "hacker". The media believes that it invents culture.

entry.title: re: ransom-malware
entry.content:
I was thinking about this attack on the way to take my car in for service. The beauty of this is that it requires so little network bandwidth, and is so inexpensive to perform.

The hard part is actually extorting the cash. Maybe a smarter attack would be to require payment of a much smaller fee ($25) via credit card, luring the victim into identity theft.

entry.title: VS.NET 2005 Code Snippets rock!
entry.content:
fix[TAB][TAB]Widget[TAB]widget[ENTER]

That's all it takes to pop the following code into a C# source file in VS.NET 2005:

using NUnit.Framework;
[TestFixture]
public class TestWidget
{
    Widget widget;
    [SetUp]
    public void Setup()
    {
        widget = new Widget();
    }
    [Test]
    public void MyTest()
    {
        |
    }
}

The pipe shows where your cursor ends up after you type that key sequence - you're ready to type your first test.

If you have Beta 2 of VS.NET you really should take a quick look at the snippet HOWTO and the snippet schema reference, so you can create these things yourself. They are trivial to build, and you'll save lots of time in the long run if you codify some of your more repetitive key sequences. The one thing that bums me out is that there are some features (like adding assembly references automatically) that are only supported in VB.NET - bah!
