entry.title: KerberosToken musings
entry.content:
I remember when I first heard about KerberosToken in WSE2, I wondered what all the fuss was about. I mean, I've always been a proponent of transport security wherever you can use it. I figure that unless you've got a really compelling reason to use WS-Security, you're better off using transport security, for several reasons:

1) Admins know how to deploy and manage it.

2) SSL (the spec as well as the many implementations) has been under public scrutiny for years - much longer than any of the WS-* stuff we've seen maturing over the last couple years.

3) You're a hell of a lot more likely to get good interop using plain ole' SSL. There are sooo many different schemes for securing messages using WS-Security. Without some basic profiles that give toolkit vendors direction, I can't imagine that toolkit X will have much of a chance of unwinding a message secured by toolkit Y. And that's just an interop problem; I'm not even talking about security now.

Given all this, I've been rather reluctant to give WSE's KerberosToken much of a look. But I now find myself considering using it on a project that I'm working on. You see, we're building an SOA architecture where virtually all of the endpoints are using Microsoft infrastructure. Kerberos is an incredibly natural fit:

1) Single sign on rocks. No bugging the user for her cleartext password.

2) Services don't see the client's password, or even a hash thereof.

3) Kerberos connections are much faster than SSL to establish, and we have very short lived sessions in this system.

So why am I thinking about using WS-* with KerbToken instead of relying on transport security? Here's the deal: when you use IIS to get Kerberos, you're only getting one very small benefit - the first request includes a header with a Kerb ticket and an authenticator. But the body of the request and subsequent requests have zero protection on them. No integrity protection. No replay protection. No connection hijacking protection. Not even any encryption. If you want any of that stuff, you have to layer on SSL, and to me that's just dumb, because Kerb is perfectly capable of providing ALL those features:

This is what KerbToken gives you - an all in one package that provides confidentiality, integrity, and authentication without requiring SSL, along with an opportunity for rich authorization on the back end, including the option to do constrained delegation.

The other benefit is that I believe I'll be able to bolt on support for UsernameTokenOverX509 when interop scenarios arise. And I will be able to do it without having to change anything significant for a given service. To do that with the current toolkit I'm using would take a bit of custom code on my part, but I'm hoping that'll change sometime soon. Even if it doesn't, that's code I only really have to write once.

I'll let you know how it turns out in about a month after we ship.

entry.title: re: KerberosToken musings
entry.content: cool :) so you are at the same point i was half a year ago - where you said i shouldn't use it :))

entry.title: ASP.NET 2.0 cryptic error message
entry.content:
A parser error has occurred.

Exception information:
    Exception type: HttpParseException
    Exception message: Could not create type 'Service'.

Oh man. This one had me pulling my hair out. I'm posting this so it'll google for me next time :-)

Problem? Simple, according to Fritz - ASP.NET 2.0 seems to assume that its App_Code directory is right underneath the vroot. Not realizing this, I had pointed my vdir one directory higher, so the URL to my service looked like this:

http://localhost/vdir/subdir/service.asmx

Now that I think about it, the /bin directory is the same way. Duh! Anyway, hope this saves someone out there some pain.

Oh and FWIW, look in the Application event log if you have ASP.NET 2.0 errors. If you look closely, you'll see there's a stack trace of the internal exception. That was helpful in tracking down the problem.

entry.title: re: ASP.NET 2.0 cryptic error message
entry.content: If you have more than 1 version of the .NET framework installed on the machine that the web service is being published to, make sure that the correct ASP.NET version is set for the application using the IIS Manager. You would think that Visual Studio .NET 2005 would automatically set this to 2.0, but it doesn't. It just leaves it at the default setting, which may not be 2.0 as it is dependant upon the order in which applications were installed on the machine.

Don't make the app_code or bin the subdir of the directory that the asmx is in, make it the subdir of the virtual root.

entry.title: Assert.IsEqualGraph(object a, object b)
entry.content:
Here's some handy unit testing code I put together to traverse two object graphs and assert that they are the same (at least their public properties). I didn't see anything like this in NUnit, and I wanted something like this to test the output of a web service. Seems to work OK so far.

I'm sure I'm not the first to build this, but I imagine someone might find it useful. Note this doesn't look for fields, only properties, but you could easily extend it if you needed to.

public void AssertGraphPropertiesEqual(object expected, object actual)
{
    AssertGraphPropertiesEqual(expected, actual, null);
}
public void AssertGraphPropertiesEqual(object expected, object actual, string parentDescription)
{
    if (null == expected || null == actual)
    {
        Assert.AreEqual(expected, actual, parentDescription);
        return;
    }
    Assert.AreSame(expected.GetType(), actual.GetType());
    Type t = expected.GetType();
    foreach (PropertyInfo pi in t.GetProperties())
    {
        object e = pi.GetValue(expected, null);
        object a = pi.GetValue(actual, null);
        string propertyDescription = (null == parentDescription)
            ? pi.Name : string.Format("{0}.{1}", parentDescription, pi.Name);
        if (pi.PropertyType.IsValueType || typeof(string) == pi.PropertyType)
        {
            Assert.AreEqual(e, a,
                string.Format("Expected {0} but got {1} for property {2}",
                e, a, propertyDescription));
        }
        else if (pi.PropertyType.IsAssignableFrom(typeof(IEnumerable)))
        {
            // some sort of list/array that we need to drill into
            IEnumerator it_e = ((IEnumerable)e).GetEnumerator();
            IEnumerator it_a = ((IEnumerable)a).GetEnumerator();
            int count = 0;
            while (true)
            {
                if (it_e.MoveNext())
                {
                    ++count;
                    Assert.IsTrue(it_a.MoveNext(), string.Format(
                        "Expected more items: actual {0} only has {1} items",
                        propertyDescription, count));
                    AssertGraphPropertiesEqual(it_e.Current, it_a.Current,
                        string.Format("{0}[{1}]", propertyDescription, count - 1));
                }
                else
                {
                    Assert.IsFalse(it_a.MoveNext(),
                        string.Format("Expected {0} items in collection {1}, " +
                        "but actual has more than that",
                        count, propertyDescription));
                    return; // all done enumerating
                }
            }
        }
        else
        {
            // just some random object - compare its properties
            AssertGraphPropertiesEqual(e, a, propertyDescription);
        }
    }
}

entry.title: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
I've been looking for a simple way to communicate exception information from a web service to its clients. The SOAP spec defines a reasonable way to do this, but the programming model (SoapException) really makes it painful. Here's what I'm trying to model:

try {
  int value = LookupSomething("some index");
}
catch (ItemNotFoundException) {
  // certain special exceptions I can recover from
}

This is a very common programming construct - in certain cases we can easily recover from an exception, so we create special exception classes (if they don't already exist) to signal these situations. In a web service, you might use the faultstring to signal these sorts of things (the faultcode is controlled by the SOAP spec, so that's not something I want to customize). Well, to do this, you use SoapException, and you can set the SOAP faultstring via the Message property:

throw new SoapException("ItemNotFound", ...);

and on the client, you'd expect to be able to read the faultstring:

catch (SoapException x) {
  if ("ItemNotFound" == x.FaultString)
       recover();
  else throw;
}

Here's the problem: there is no FaultString property on SoapException. And if you read the Message property, you'll find your faultstring interspersed with a load of other crap that you don't care about:

System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapException: ItemNotFound at Foo.LookupSomething(String index) in foo.cs:line 80

Well, that's just peachy. So I guess I can use the detail field to supply a DOM with details about the exception, and the client SoapException won't futz around with that, but my goodness, that's way overkill for what I want.

Am I missing something, or did Microsoft simply not consider the client exception programming model? Did they just assume we'd implement all our exception handling blocks with a message box?

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content: Have you tried grabbing the .InnerException to look at the original exception thrown?

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content: ASP.NET doesn't serialize the actual exception into the SOAP fault packet, so InnerException is always null on the client side. I should have mentioned that in my original post, because it was one thing I thought about.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
It is not intuitive, but you need to set the custom errors mode in your web.config to On, not remote only or Off. This controls how your web service errors are serialized as well as how errors are handled in asp.net apps. you'll actually get the exception message you want and if you have an inner exception, you'll get that message in the message as well (OuterMessage -> inner exception message).

This is the kind of great detail you can get if you have us come in and do a web services class for your company. :)

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
Keith,

One thing you can do is, supply just the XML as a string, and it works in a way very similar to supplying the DOM document (hey afterall it is all XML Serialized).

Not the ideal solution - but close enough.

- SM

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
Matt,

Good point, but would it be a good idea from a security perspective to change that error mode? Heck, I'd be perfectly happy with just a FaultString property on SoapException. Seems like an oversight to me.

Hey, I'll sit through your web service class if you'll sit through my security class ;-)

Sahil,

I solved the problem by creating a little class that maps enums onto nodes in a DOM tree that it caches. Makes it pretty easy to use the Detail field. Just silly that we have to go to this length, IMHO.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
I've been using a rather strict server-side exception mapping approach to avoid the security issues that stem from this problem, but I suspect that this approach might address your client-side issue as well. Here's the basic outline:

1. Define an marker attribute for client-consumable exceptions.

2. Create two new exception classes that inherit from SoapException and SoapHeaderException but that hide all the innards (e.g.: stack trace) that shouldn't be exposed to the client. Apply the attribute from #1 to both classes.

3. Create an exception mapper that is capable of mapping any server-side exception that isn't marked with the client-safe attribute to one of the exception types in #2, including massaging the message text as appropriate.

4. Wrap each web method body in a try-catch block that uses the method from #3 to map caught exceptions to their client-safe counterparts then rethrows the new exception.

Since SoapExceptions aren't re-massaged by the framework prior to insertion of their data into the response, whatever you choose to have exposed via the ToString method of the custom exception classes created in #2 will be what is sent to the client.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content: Interesting approach, Nicole. I ended up doing something very similar (but a bit simpler) to Aaron's suggestion.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
The SOAP spec says...
faultstring: "...It is intended to provide a human readable explanation of the fault and is not intended for algorithmic processing."
detail: "The detail element information item is intended for carrying application specific error information related to the SOAP Body . It MUST be present when the contents of the SOAP Body could not be processed successfully"

Interoperable SOAP services therefore more or less require you to follow the approach of providing a detail element complying with a schema defined as part of your service. WSDL has a syntax for defining the schema of detail elements in SOAP faults. However, I think you are right that there is currently no tool support from Microsoft for doing this: no way to emit the WSDL including fault definitions (unless you do it by hand); no server-side programming constructs for ensuring that any SOAP faults generated comply with the detail schema; and no client-side tools for generating code to map fault detail instances to specific client side exception types.

Currently you are more or less forced to catch all exceptions on the server side and construct a suitable SoapException "by hand" (setting faultcode appropriately; ensuring the faultstring doesn't leak sensitive information; and populating the detail appropriately), and on the client side you need to code an explicit mapping of SOAP fault context details to whatever client-side exception handling model your application has.

Such mappings are necessarily application-specific. While wrapper classes such as have been suggested can help, unless they are closely configurable for the application, they can't solve the whole problem. For example, even just to get the faultcode set correctly on the server side - to distinguish server from client errors - application-specific coding is hard to avoid.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
Chris,

Good point about the SOAP spec. Given that, it appears that not exposing the faultstring was probably a reasonable thing to do. So I guess it sucks a little less than I originally thought ;-)

Indigo has a much more robust way of dealing with faults. You can throw an exception on the server and catch it on the client. Indigo also differentiates between faults that should be thrown to clients and random exceptions that should be dealt with on the server. Looking forward to it...

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content: Great conversation. I've been looking for a good solution to this problem for some time now. Sounds like a great topic for an MSDN article!

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
You don't have to catch all exceptions by hand on the server side. You can build a SoapExtension that will inject the exception information into the detail node of the outgoing stream.

I've built an extension that does that. It even serializes the exception (base64encoded) and passes that along with human readable information. Not sure if the serialized exception is useful as I already pass the exception type and message.

I'll probably publish it on my blog sometime soon.

entry.title: re: SoapException sucks.
entry.content:
Am I missing something here?

The soap spec (1.1) also includes:
faultcode - intended for use by software to provide an algorithmic mechanism for indetifying the fault.
(for 1.2 see Value element of Code element)

I see the faultcode as the rough equivalent to an exception name while "detail" is the exception contents.

There are some predefined faultcodes - soap:Client, soap:Sender for instance - but you can define your own:
xmlns:my = "http://my.com"
faultcode = "my:ItemNotFound"
(see XmlQualifiedName)
and these can be passed as the code parameter to various SoapException ctors.

See some of the WS specs - like Web services Eventing - for examples of custom faultcodes.

-Mathew Nolton

TechEd 2005
entry.content:
I've been busy at TechEd all this week. Really busy.

We are hosting our first Pluralsight booth, which is so exciting - it's great to see everything coming together. We recently welcomed Matt Milner,  Ted Pattison, and Joe Hummel into our rank of instructors, we're doing some fantastic content development work for Microsoft, and our curriculum is shaping up to be the best in the industry.

(Dr. Joe Hummel is a college prof, an amazingly smart guy, and great fun at parties for anyone who ever took a VB class with him at our previous training company. He's also the fellow who taught me years ago that user authentication could be broken down into three questions: what do you have, what do you know, and what are you made of -- that was one of those “wow, I get it” moments in my career, Joe)

As I sat down to a great sushi dinner the other night with these fellows plus Aaron, Fritz, and Bill, I suddenly realized the impact of what we're doing here at Pluralsight. We are bringing together some of the most amazing folks in this industry, and so many of my old friends - it feels like a family reunion. It was a very happy moment for me. Of course the bottle of saki didn't hurt any, either ;-)

Anyway, it's Wednesday night, and I've finished up one of the most stressful and fun nights in my career. Stressful because I delivered a VSTS testing breakout talk that I'd been working on for several weeks on a build of the bits that was very far from being stable, and demoing integration with a third party tool that was also really quite unstable on that build. I had spent many hours of the previous week trying to get a couple portions of my demos to work consistently (even with the kind help of the VSTS team), but the build proved to be too unstable and those two demos failed as they had in the past. Fortunately the audience seemed to take it in stride (I'll see on the evals, I guess ;-) But this was the most stress I've felt about a talk in a LONG time.

Happily later on in the evening I moderated a couple security-related BOF sessions that went (IMHO) splendidly. In groups of about 15 folks we had very informal and intimate chats about writing partially trusted code, and writing secure code in general. Those were really fun sessions and helped me to decompress after the VSTS talk. Thanks to all who attended!

TechEd 2005 has been a thrill for me in so many ways; if you're here, please stop by our booth and say hello tomorrow. I'll be in the booth most of the day (we're on aisle 200 right across from the beanbag lounge).

Have a great TechEd!

entry.title: re: Password Minder 1.5.0.6 released
entry.content:
Frankly a lot of sites assume you'll never change your password, and probably have never tested the change password functionality (if it even exists). Sometimes what happens is you provide a long password and the site truncates it before storing it, not telling you what they are doing (they simply don't expect you to use a good password!)

I usually adapt the length and complexity of my password for the site I'm using. For a site that I really don't care much about, I just give it an 8 or 10 char password, with no punctuation. That seems to be acceptable just about everywhere. More secure sites seem to take passwords a bit more seriously, so I can use a longer password.

As for notifications, I always post to this blog when a new version comes out, so as long as you're subscribed, you should always be informed.

entry.title: Interview with Marcus Ranum
entry.content:
I've seen a lot of griping from the web service camp over standards committees, and here is the same thing showing up in the security space. In this interview, Marcus points out how IPSec is the poster child for how design-by-committee leads to overly complex security protocols.

“I don't think that the standards committees underestimate security threats; I just think they're too busy doing things that are more important to them -- like holding meetings and writing minutes, or whatever it is that they do all the time. The standards I've seen that try to address security all seem to be over-engineered and too late, while the standards that ignore security are usually rapidly adopted and full of security problems. It's a no-win situation either way.”

entry.title: Security standards complexity
Calling web services from within SQL Server 2005
entry.content:
Turns out dynamic use of XmlSerializer is one thing SQL Server doesn't like very much, and calling a web service using the standard web service proxy does just this.

Msg 6522, Level 16, State 1, Line 1 A .NET Framework error occurred during execution of user defined routine or aggregate 'GetCallerEmployeeID': System.InvalidOperationException: Cannot load dynamically generated serialization assembly. In some hosting environments assembly load functionality is restricted, consider using pre-generated serializer. Please see inner exception for more information. ---> System.IO.FileLoadException: LoadFrom(), LoadFile(), Load(byte[]) and LoadModule() have been disabled by the host.

entry.title: re: Calling web services from within SQL Server 2005
entry.content:
It's a feature. SQL Server 2005 will only load assemblies cataloged to SQL Server. You have to sgen the proxy assembly and catalog it using CREATE ASSEMBLY.

Cheers,
Bob

entry.title: C# foreach and Dispose
entry.content:
I've always known that C#'s foreach statement does implement a try/finally block internally, but today I forgot whether this was to dispose of items in the collection or what. Turns out that this is simply to dispose of the enumerator object, an intermediary object that you never see when you use foreach.

In summary: you've got to Dispose of individual objects when you get them from a foreach loop. To demonstrate this, the following program prints “Hello world” (note that “Dispose“ is not printed).

using System;
class Foo : IDisposable {
  public void HelloWorld() { Console.WriteLine("Hello world"); }
  public void Dispose() { Console.WriteLine("Dispose"); }
}
class App {
  static void Main() {
    Foo[] a = { new Foo() };
    foreach (Foo foo in a) foo.HelloWorld();
  }
}

To fix this program, you'd need a try/finally block in the foreach loop that explicitly calls Dispose. Makes me wish there were a foreach_using statement in the language :-)

entry.title: re: C# foreach and Dispose
entry.content:
So let me see if you've got this right: you want a construct that will iterate through a collection and destroy the contents as part of the iteration?

Ideally the collection containing the disposable objects would itself implement IDisposable, then you can just write "a.Dispose()" and clean everything up.

I really don't think that the foreach loop is the place for this.

entry.title: A quick reminder on Dispose and foreach
re: C# foreach and Dispose
re: C# foreach and Dispose
re: C# foreach and Dispose
entry.content:
Yes, that syntax works for me. Before I ran into this issue with System.DirectoryServices, I never realized you could put a raw object reference in a using block. I always thought you had to *acquire* the instance in the using block.

In other words:

using (Foo foo = new Foo()) // legal

Foo foo = new Foo();
using (foo) // also legal

...which makes the syntax you suggest really quite natural when consuming collections of short-lived objects like those from S.DS.

Thanks for pointing out the syntax.

entry.title: Attacking a digital signature with a hash collision
entry.content:
Here's a nifty article that tells a little story to demonstrate how collisions in hash functions can be used to attack cryptographic protocols such as digital signatures.

Some key points about the attack:

  • The attacker created both the original (signed) document and the forgery. It's a lot easier to engineer two messages that hash to the same value if you can vary both messages arbitrarily.
  • Some recent advances in attacks on MD5 were used in this attack.
  • If Caesar had made a trivial change to the document before signing it, he would have foiled the attack.

If you're building systems that rely on digital signatures, you'd be wise to consider this type of attack. In my early studies of crypto protocols, I recall learning that signing an untrusted document (i.e. a document that you or a friend did not create) is a really bad idea, and this attack is an example that proves that point nicely.

entry.title: Yukon and HTTP.SYS
entry.content:
You can sure tell that everyone is just getting started experimenting with this stuff, because while you can google to find how to *do* something in this space, you can't find the corresponding code to *undo* it :-)

What I'm talking about here is sp_reserve_http_namespace, which is a stored proc in Yukon that talks to HTTP.SYS and reserves an endpoint for its use. You need to use this if you want to expose a web service from the database directly (and your instance is running under LUA, good for you), something that I've been experimenting with for a project I'm currently working on.

So where's the sp_release_http_namespace? Or the sp_unreserve_http_namespace function? I poked around the master database but didn't see anything obvious. I just happen to be trying to move the web service to a different named instance of Yukon, and the old instance has a lock on the URL I need.

In any case, by searching the registry for a fragment of the URL I registered, I noticed that under the services key (HKLM\SYSTEM\CCS\Services), there's a key called HTTP. And under that, there's a subkey at Parameters\UrlAclInfo that has a list of named values, and there I found my registered pattern. I took a chance and deleted the entry with my pattern in it, and rebooted the system. Before rebooting, I tried net stop HTTP, but that just put it in a wacky state - apparently HTTP.SYS is the new RPCSS.EXE - I'll bet someday soon your system will melt if it's not running).

Ahh, my VPC just started back up. That's a good sign. Regedit shows the value I deleted is indeed still gone. Let's see if the pattern has been successfully unregistered, or if my machine is now toast. Bringing up SSMS and calling sp_reserve_http_namespace from my new instance again... WOOHOO it worked!

I'm sure Bob will be here soon with the official fix, but this seems to be working for now...

entry.title: re: Yukon and HTTP.SYS
entry.content:
Keith,

If you're running W2K3 or you have the adminpak installed on XP you can use httpcfg to manipulate the URLs in the HTTP.SYS list.

Use

httpcfg query urlacl

to get a list of reserved addresses (and their ACLs).

Use

httpcfg set urlacl -u <URL> -a <ACL>

to add a URL and ACL to the list (yes, you do need to specify an ACL). e.g.

httpcfg set urlacl -u http://192.168.1.111:8088/mystuff -a D:(A;;GX;;;WD)

Use

httpcfg delete urlacl -u <URL>

to remove a URL from the list. e.g.

httpcfg delete urlacl -u http://192.168.1.111:8088/mystuff

Hope this helps,

Gudge

entry.title: re: Yukon and HTTP.SYS
entry.content: Awesome - that's exactly the tool I was looking for. Thanks Gudge :-)

As long as you reserve a set of prefixes ahead of time, you should be able to use HttpListener from a non-privileged account. I've not yet played with HttpListener myself, but if you look at Gudge's post, he shows how to use httpcfg to manage reservations.

http://pluralsight.com/blogs/keith/archive/2005/06/23/11906.aspx#FeedBack

entry.title: Tip on using differencing disks in Virtual PC
entry.content:
I've been using differencing disks to test some deployment scripts: I have a base image that has the operating system and basic infrastructure (like BizTalk) on it, and I create a differencing disk off of that to test my deployment. Then I just delete the differencing disk when I want to try again. It works nicely (Undo disks would be another option here, but I often want to have more than one branch going at one time).

Anyway, last night at about 3am (well, this morning, I guess) I was pretty tired and I accidentally pointed my deployment VPC at the base disk image instead of the differencing disk. I deployed onto my clean image. It's not a huge deal, but it wasn't what I'd planned on happening, and it could have been really inconvenient if I'd not had a backup of the base image on another drive.

From now on, I'm setting the READ-ONLY flag on my base image. Just tried it and it works like a charm. Prevents you from accidentally using the parent VHD directly.

entry.title: Un piccolo TIP, a volte salva la vita... :-D
re: Tip on using differencing disks in Virtual PC
entry.content:
This is a reasonably common problem...

I think that the VPC Virtual Disk Wizard should offer to set the read-only flag on the base disk image when you create a differencing disk.

entry.title: Channel security in SQL Server
entry.content:
I've recently been looking into ways of securing the channel between a client and SQL Server. Given that SQL Server supports integrated authentication (integrated security=sspi) you'd think that the native TCP/IP library would be able to use SSPI to sign and seal the channel. But they don't, and I find that really odd.

Look, they tell you, if you want to use Kerberos to secure the channel, use the multiprotocol library. That puts another layer between you and SQL Server - now you're communicating over RPC, which can be configured to use SSPI to MAC protect and encrypt the channel. But why do I have to use RPC to get this? Why doesn't the native TCP/IP driver provide these basic protections?

And furthermore, I love the mysterious little caveat you'll find when you go read about using the multiprotocol encryption feature:

Use Multiprotocol encryption only for compatibility with existing systems. The Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) encryption that can be enabled using the Server Network Utility (after running Setup) is a more comprehensive encryption solution.

Oh, and this is a nice limitation as well:

The Multiprotocol Net-Library does not support named instances of SQL Server 2000. You can use the Multiprotocol Net-Library to connect to the default instance of SQL Server on a computer, but you cannot connect to any named instances.

Why am I bugged by this? Why don't I just use SSL and get in line with everyone else? Because setting up SSL connections is considerably slower than setting up Kerberos connections (think public key operations in SSL versus purely symmetrical operations with Kerb), and it requires certificates and PKI where Kerberos is already built right in to my domain infrastructure.

I want REAL Kerberos support. Not just authentication, but integrity and confidentiality too. And I want it built right in to the native network library for TCP/IP. Is that too much to ask? If someone can tell me this is coming in Yukon, I'd be a very happy camper indeed.

entry.title: SQL Channel Security, a half-glass problem?
entry.content: Keith Brown has a meaty posting on his blog talking about channel security for SQL Server. The highlight,...

entry.title: re: Channel security in SQL Server
entry.content: I do understand you pleading for a more consistent Kerberos story. What I don't understand is: Why would you want to encrypt and otherwise protect all traffic to/from the database server? In a busy datacenter you'll end up clogging the DB machine with a lot of overhead, but you're already inside the datacenter. What specific scenario are you targeting?

entry.title: re: Channel security in SQL Server
entry.content:
Joe,

I'm sure a lot of people agree with you; why would you ever want to protect data that's already protected by perimeter security?

The answer of course is defense in depth; there's a growing number of people who would like to build systems that are resilient to failures, including perimeter security failures.

As Ferguson points out in Practical Cryptography, "We already have enough fast, insecure systems. We don't need another one." Of course his viewpoint is just one of many. But for those that share it, a consistent Kerb story would certainly make it a lot less painful.

entry.title: July's winners for most popular blog post
entry.content: Blogging has it's rewards. Congratulations to Derek Ferguson and Keith Brown for winning a wireless optical...

entry.title: Microsoft's fragmented Kerberos story
entry.content:
If anyone was wondering why I got on the SQL Server channel security rant, I'm currently working on a talk that shows how to use integrated authentication across several Microsoft products, and when you look at how integrated authentication is used across this platform, you see how sadly fragmented the story is.

IIS: When you turn on integrated authentication, Kerb is used to communicate client credentials to the server (assuming Kerb is negotiated, which it should be if both client and server are in a v5.0 or greater domain). It is NOT used to provide integrity or confidentiality. Oh, you wanted that? You've gotta layer on SSL.

SQL Server: see my previous post. In short, Microsoft shies away from using Kerberos and recommends SSL.

SMB (file shares, printers, named pipes): Kerb is used to communicate client credentials to the server. You can further configure it (via security policy) to provide integrity protection of the channel. But encryption? Naw, you gotta layer on IPSEC if you want that. You'd think that this would be one of the highest priorities given that it's used by virtually everyone.

RPC and COM+: Fantastic support for Kerberos. Siimply adjust the authentication level to Packet Privacy, and you've got authentication, integrity, and confidentiality protection.

I remember how much Microsoft touted their use of Kerberos when Windows 2000 shipped. It would be soooo great if the use of Kerb was consistent across the platform. Give me the option to use Kerb's integrity and encryption features. Everywhere. Only then will we truly have “integrated security”.

entry.title: re: Microsoft's fragmented Kerberos story
entry.content: How about WSE? To get WSE to authenticate the caller I think we've got to pass a plain text username and password, and secure the communication with SSL. Would it be possible to use a kerberos ticket or something instead so confidentiality isn't dependent on a transport configuration?

entry.title: re: Microsoft's fragmented Kerberos story
entry.content:
As of WSE 2.0, you can use Kerb tokens - works like a charm. You can either use the current security context, or you can pass a user name and password to get a ticket in someone else's name. The beauty of this is that you can use Kerb to provide authentication, integrity, and confidentiality - you don't need SSL. I'd expect you'd see better perf, but you'd have to test to make sure since there's lots of other factors involved.

In an interop scenario you're unlikely to use Kerb, since it isn't typically used across organization boundaries. More likely would be SSL with a UsernameToken as you suggest.

entry.title: re: Microsoft's fragmented Kerberos story
entry.content:
I do concur that the evidence of Microsoft's all to typical proprietary aversion of standards is wrought yet another fragmentation. I have been studying their Kerberos implementation and found that you are their primary source of code examples for implementation of the standard.
While its true that their implementation does not share cohesiveness across the implementations; I am particularly under impresed by the "GSSAPI" psuedo-implementation. In heterogeneous domains this seems to over complicate the development of TGT passing across OS boundaries.
The lack of implementation direction in their documentation is probably the root of their fragmentation. In any large product and or suites of products missing examples with no real coding styles leaves them open to entropy. Though it could also be their marketing dept :)

I would like to extend my thanks for your open efforts and look forward to reading your book "Programming windows security" Though I have had to order it since there are no local copies.

entry.title: Remoting v2.0 authentication in Beta 2
entry.content: If you got a chance to play around with the Kerb support in System.Runtime.Remoting in Beta 1, you might want to note that there have been some changes to the config files in beta 2. Looks like the same basic options are there, only they've been renamed to make things more clear.

entry.title: re: Remoting v2.0 authentication in Beta 2
entry.content:
Thanx, that helped a lot. But... when I try to access my remoted server object from a web application, the wrong principal is passed.

I've got a web forms application authenticating against ADAM, so when i'm logged in to the web site the HttpContext.Current.User.Identity = my ADAM user. When I start a method on the remoted object, the Thread.CurrentPrincipal.Identity is set to the AD User I'm logged in to Windows with....

entry.title: re: Remoting v2.0 authentication in Beta 2
entry.content:
Authentication in System.Runtime.Remoting is based on Windows integrated authentication (negotiates between Kerb and NTLM).

ADAM authentication is nothing more than a password being sent across the wire to the directory service. ADAM does not use Kerberos to authenticate clients. ADAM credentials cannot be used with Windows integrated authentication, and therefore cannot be used to authenticate a Remoting client.

The only way to authenticate an ADAM user is to bind to ADAM with that user's credentials over LDAP.

entry.title: Kent responds to my SQL Server rant
entry.content:
Kent responded to my rant about SQL Server by pointing out how important SSL support is. Let me clarfiy - my post was not in any way meant to belittle SQL Server's SSL support. I also think that it's very important, for all the scenarios that Kent mentions. There are places where Kerberos simply doesn't work.

My point is that if you're going to support Kerberos, go all the way. Give me an option to encrypt and integrity protect the channel using my Kerberos symmetric key. For anyone who has ever worked with SSPI, it sure feels strange to say “integrated security=sspi“ and then have someone tell you that you need to layer SSL on top of that in order to get encryption.

Let's get that glass 100% full, instead of just half full!

entry.title: re: Kent responds to my SQL Server rant
entry.content:
I have to agree with you on this one. Even though I do like the fact that SQL Server offers so much out-of-the-box, I feel that this is an obvious omission (especially in homogenous environments, yes, they do exist).

Additionally, when Kent states:

So am I saying that Keith's desire better integration with Kerberos security is invalid? Not at all -- it has obvious value in many cases.

It says to me that they dropped the ball, being fully aware that this is a valid case, but they didn't want to address it.

entry.title: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content:
I've gotten a few reports from people that CPWLW is failing when run as SYSTEM. I confirmed this myself on Friday when I was hacking up some code for a client. Today I looked and found this in the docs:

Windows XP SP2 and Windows Server 2003:  You cannot call CreateProcessWithLogonW from a process running under the LocalSystem account. This is because the function uses the logon SID in the caller token and the token for the LocalSystem account does not contain this SID. As an alternative, use the CreateProcessAsUser and LogonUser functions.

When I first read this, I figured it was referring to the logon SID of the new logon, which is typically used to add a grant in the DACL of the winsta / desktop pair where the new process will live. But now that I reread it, clearly it's referring to the caller's logon SID. I wonder what that could be used for? Securing some temporary object used for communicating between the caller's process and the secondary logon service? Inquiring minds want to know, in case any of my MS readers were involved with this change.

In any case, if you're running your service as SYSTEM (tsk tsk tsk) and you want to migrate to W2K3 and XP SP2, I hope you're not calling CreateProcessWithLogonW. If you are and need another way, check out my 5 year old article (wow, has it been that long?) on doing this the old way using LogonUser / CreateProcessAsUser, etc. Note that since the article was released, (Un)LoadUserProfile was documented. So be sure to use that API instead of the rather complicated approach to bootstrapping the user's environment that I had to follow back in 1999.

The article comes with a tool called cmdasuser.exe from which you can grab all the code you need to get this going.

entry.title: re: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content:
Keith,

I found that this limitation in the new OS versions is fairly easy to circumvent: First do a LogonUser for the user whose credentials you want to pass to CPWLW. It worked for me with LOGON32_LOGON_NEW_CREDENTIALS and LOGON32_LOGON_NETWORK. Then impersonate the user and now call CPWLW.
I do not know up to now if this has any side effects, it seemed to work for me.

--
Stefan

entry.title: re: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content: Good point, Stefan. Given that you've got the user's password, and that LogonUser isn't a privileged call on the affected OS's, you could check to see which OS you're running on and impersonate the user before making the request.

entry.title: re: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content:
I think it goes somewhat like this. CPWLW used to tweak the DACL of the caller's winstation/desktop to allow the new process to access it. This wasn't very secure, and presented problems such as how to clean up the added ACEs when the process terminates.

So the new implementation leaves the ACLs alone, and instead injects the caller's LogonId SID into the new process' token, which has a side effect of allowing it access to the desktop.

The system logon session doesn't have a logon id SID so CPWLW fails.

If you impersonate some other account before you call CPWLW you can bypass this problem, but you will also not get automatic access to the desktop.

Finally, I'm not sure but I think that you might be able to use CPWLW from the system session if you specify a non-NULL lpDesktop, or if you use LOGON_NETCREDENTIALS_ONLY flag on W2K3 SP1 and later, because in these cases CPWLW doesn't care about desktop permissions.

entry.title: re: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content:
Hi Pavel,

you are right. When I did my first attempts to bypass the problem, I made the mistake to use the same credentials as those of the user who was interactively logged in. The service had interaction with the desktop enabled and therefore spawning processes with CPWL from the service worked. But as soon as I specify other credentials, the processes fail if they do UI. I think, in the case of the originating process running as SYSTEM, you now have to manipulate the ACEs of the winsta\desktop DACLS again.

--
Stefan

entry.title: re: CreateProcessWithLogonW from SYSTEM
entry.content:
Hi guys,

I am getting blocked by quite similar issue. My service is running under admin acount, not system account. It executes runas tool, which internally calls our famous API.

So, if user credentials are admins, everything works perfectly. However, if Iam trying to runas with non admin credentials, runas succeeds, but process fails to initialize with 0xc0000142. Has anyone faced that? Any ideas how can I fix that?

Thanks!

entry.title: New security book on the shelves
entry.content:
Mike Howard and David LeBlanc, authors of Writing Secure Code (the best security book for Windows coders) have teamed up with John Viega, coauthor of Building Secure Software (the best security book for Unix coders), to put together 19 Deadly Sins of Software Security.

I spoke with Mike recently and asked him how big this new book was going to be - I'm of the opinion that concise books on security are what developers need these days to lure them to learn about the subject. He assured me that the new book is much easier to consume than his previous tome :-)

I've ordered my copy,. and you should too.

entry.title: Password Minder v1.5.0.7 released
entry.content:
A number of people have been asking for a notes field, and I finally got around to adding it. Thanks to Jim Butts for taking the time to send me his mod (I didn't use his code verbatim, but the code I added is compatible with his mod). Use Ctrl-E to view or edit the notes field. The notes themselves are encrypted in your password file.

As a reminder, folks if you forget your master password, there's no way (short of a brute force attack against your own password file) to recover your passwords. There's nothing wrong with writing down your master password as long as you keep the written copy in a secure location! And now would be a fantastic time to reset that master password you've been using for more than a year, and back up your password file as well.

Please visit our tools page to download the latest version today. Enjoy!

Keith

However in the last week or so I have started to notice some very strange behaviour. If I reset any of my passwords or add comments or generally make some minor changes to entries after some indeterminate period of time the last change seems to disappear. This has just happened for the 6th time with my hotmail account when yesterday your app prompted me to change my password after the 72 days I had configured and duely did so. However I have just tried to register for a microsoft event which requires me to log in with my passport account and so as usuall I popped up Password Minder for it to again remind me to change my hotmail password with one day less that yesterday which I thought was funny as I had changed it yesterday but copied the password across to the website anyway only to be told it was incorrect. Any Ideas on whats going on here? I've tried to recreate the problem only to fail but its happenning every day pretty much now and getting a little tiresome. I always keep several backup copies in different locations on different hardware in case of a major loss sometime down the line, but havent done these after every little change - only once a month or so. Also I must confess I sometime leave the app running for long periods of time and over hibernates - could this be the problem? or previous versions somehow? I have tested this but havent found the problem.

Any help would be much appreciated!

entry.title: re: UPDATE: Password Minder v1.5.0.8
entry.content:
Mike,

I've not seen this before myself. Keep in mind that PWM only writes the password file when you close it (it was designed to be opened and closed each time you need it, so I didn't put a File|Save in there).

What might be happening is this: you make a password change in an instance of PWM that you leave open for a long time. The change hasn't yet been written to disk. Then you accidentally open another instance of PWM (forgetting that you already have one in the background). That new instance reads the password file, but doesn't see the change... You can see how this would be a problem.

My suggestion would be to close PWM whenever you make a change (although I'd recommend keeping it closed whenever it's not in use, but you know that ;-)

Try to make sure you never have two copies of PWM open at the same time (I guess I could add a check for that, but I'm afraid to think of what behavior people would want when the second copy starts - things might get complicated for a simple little program like PWM).

Anyway, give that a whirl and see if it clears up your problem.

entry.title: Thoughts on repudiation and surreptitious forwarding
entry.content:
Think for a moment about the security guarantees that two peers get when communicating using symmetric-key systems like Kerberos, or even SSL (where the actual messages themselves are protected using symmetric keys).

Let's imagine Alice sends a message to Bob, and her message is signed[1] then encrypted using symmetric keys that Alice and Bob share. Who can read the message once it's encrypted? Only Alice and Bob. Who can verify Alice's signature? Only Alice and Bob. This last point is important.

“Signatures“ formed with a shared (symmetric) key can only be validated by someone who knows the key. Later on, Alice can repudiate her message, “Bob, I never sent that message, you're trying to set me up!“ and Bob has no recourse - an independent adjudicator would simply look at the message and say, “How do I know who actually signed that message, Bob? Both you and Alice knew the signing key!“ For this reason, cryptographers carefully distinguish message authentication codes from digital signatures, but in most Web Service security scenarios, the terminology is rather muddied. XML Signatures can be formed not only with private keys, but also with shared keys (in which case the “Signature“ is really just a MAC).

On the other hand, if Alice and Bob use an asymmetric-key system, Alice would sign the message with her private key, and Bob (and anyone else, including the adjudicator from my last example) can verify the signature. Thus Bob gains some measure of “nonrepudiation“. But interestingly enough, Bob also may be losing a security guarantee. Systems that sign and encrypt with asymmetric keys are often subject to an attack called “surreptitious forwarding“.

In order to understand this attack, and the implications for Bob's peace of mind, put yourself in Bob's shoes when he receives a message that was first signed with Alice's private key then encrypted with Bob's public key. Bob decrypts the message, verifies the signature, and what does he know? Alice's signature was intact, so surely she signed the message, but has anyone else seen the plaintext? And was the message really addressed to him? If Alice didn't explicitly include “To: Bob“ in the message, how does Bob know that this message really came from Alice?

Consider this scenario: Alice signs the message, “I love you“, encrypts it with Chris's public key, and sends it to Chris. She loves Chris and wants to let him know. Chris, the villian in this story, decrypts the message, and decides to set up Bob for some embarrassment by reencrypting it with Bob's public key and sending it to Bob. When Bob receives “I love you“, signed by Alice and encrypted so only he can read it, he will very likely be fooled! Now, if Alice had thought ahead and instead signed the message, “Chris, I love you“, this “surreptitious forwarding“ attack would have been prevented.

There seems to be a common misconception that asymmetric cryptosystems are somehow better or more secure than symmetric cryptosystems, but this example shows that of course this is not true; you have to be very careful designing any type of cryptosystem. I'm glad there are people much smarter than I am doing this sort of thing!

Soooo, what does this have to do with anything? One interesting place where these ideas are applied is in WS-Security implementations. If you've ever used WSE to secure a web service, you may have wondered why all those headers are included in the XML signature and not just the body of the message itself. In particular, the WS-Addressing header - why would the sender take the time to sign that? Well, now you know at least one reason why that fragment is signed. That's the equivalent of including “To: Bob“ as part of the signed message. It helps prevent surreptitious forwarding.

If you're interested in learning more about challenges in building cryptosystems, my favorite book by far is Practical Cryptography. And for an in-depth look at surreptitious forwarding and the myriad of protocols that are susceptible to it, read Don Davis's paper on the topic. Don's point is that many toolkits (and protocols) don't bother to protect against this attack because they assume the user will be aware of the problem. I think he'd be happy with the WSE and Indigo implementations that implicitly protect against this attack by including the recipient information in signatures automatically.

[1] more correctly, the message is protected with a message authentication code (MAC), which you can learn more about here.

entry.title: Our newest instructor
entry.content:
Craig Andera, who has been blogging with us almost from the start, has decided to get back in the saddle and do some teaching again. We are very excited that he's joining the ranks of Pluralsight instructors, as he was one of the students' best loved instructors when I worked with him in a previous life ;-)

Welcome back, Craig!

entry.title: Transitions (Subtitle: Whore for Rent)
Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content:
This week we're busy teaching the .NET Campsight, so several of us from Pluralsight went out for dinner together at a popular sushi restaurant in Kirkland, WA. I won't name the restaurant, but what's interesting is that when Bill checked his receipt against the actual charge on his online bank statement, he found that the restaurant added 20% above what they charged us on the check (which included a 17% mandatory tip already).

The actual charge was exactly 20% above the *total* price of the check, including gratuity and tax. I wonder how often they get away with that little scam, because if this had happened to me, I'd never have noticed it.

I don't usually check the actual charges that come in against the receipts I bring home. But I think I'll start now.

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: Actually, I believe that this is a standard practice where, for reasons I don't know, restaurants initially charge 20% more than the price of the meal, but the actual final charge is the price of the meal. It'd be worthwhile looking at the statement again in a day or so after the transaction is finalized to see what the final price ends up being.

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: Josh - looks like you're right: I didn't notice on Bill's bank statement that this was still listed as a "Pending" transaction. Now I feel better :-)

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content:
The reason they do this is to make sure that the card will authorize for the full amount plus the amount of the tip. When you get a receipt to sign, it has already been authorized not knowing how much of a tip will be added when you sign it.

Gas stations take a different approach. They only authorize $1 when you insert your card before they know how much gas you'll actually buy.

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: Denis, what gas stations do varies a lot from company to company. Some stations may only authorize a dollar and take it off as soon as the transaction goes through; others may authorize $75 and keep the authorization for as long as three days.

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: Hotels do the same. Within a few days, the pending "extra" charges are removed. I nearly fainted the first few times I saw this -- how dare they charge me more! :)

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: However, I have tracked this carefully and while they may to the 20% pre-auth trick legitimately, I've also noticed that a number of restaurants will round up and do other little things. For example, I've seen a number of cases where a $12.20 charge becomes a $12.70 charge by the time it gets to my bank. And unless I still have my receipt, there is nothing I can do about it.

entry.title: re: Checking receipts against your credit card statement
entry.content: restaurants pre auth 10/15/20 percent so that they only have to auth one charge on your account, since they can't release the hold. They don't want you walking out of the restaurant until they are sure your card will be approved. Also they pay most waitress out in cash for tips received so they pre auth the tip so if they give the waitress money, when they try to get a tip it wont bounce since only the normal bill was approved if they didnt pre auth 20 percent.

entry.title: PDC Birds of a Feather Sessions
entry.content:
If you're free Tuesday night at PDC, stop by one of my BOFs and hang out with us. These are the same topics I hosted at TechEd, and they were a blast. Some great discussions came out of them.

Writing Secure Code, Tuesday 9:00pm

Bring your questions as well as your experiences to this interactive discussion. Participants share what techniques they are using to ensure bulletproof implementations, including third party tools. Also on the agenda are the top threats that developers need to worry about when writing code. Remember, it's not just the guys calling security APIs that need to worry about this! Anyone writing code to access valuable assets should care about this topic, so let's have a big turnout!

Writing Partially Trusted Code, Tuesday 10:15pm (BYOC)

Writing partially trusted code can be tricky. But a lot of people feel that it's an important tool in our security arsenal: by running with only the permissions we need, the CLR puts walls around our apps to help ensure we can't be tricked into doing something we didn't intend to do. Come discuss the pros and cons of running under partial trust. There are a lot of gotchas, so if you've had experiences, we'd love to hear about them. And if you're just considering taking on the challenge of writing partially trusted code, you'll get a great head start by joining us.

BYOC == Bring Your Own Caffeine ;-)

entry.title: re: PDC Birds of a Feather Sessions
entry.content: What would it take for you guys to present at http://www.cooug.org/

entry.title: re: PDC Birds of a Feather Sessions
entry.content:
We travel so much in our normal teaching regime that it's hard to justify (to our families) flying somewhere to do a user group talk - I'm sure you understand.

But I'll keep you in mind if I'm ever in town teaching. I'm happy to do a local user group talk if I'm in town that week.

entry.title: Gesticu Lame
entry.content:
New rule: if you wear one of those bluetooth wireless headsets for your cellphone, you must stand perfectly still and keep your hands at your sides while you talk.

Last week on my way up to Redmond, I was waiting in the security line at the Denver airport. A fellow in front of me was wearing one of these devices and as he was talking, he paced back and forth, throwing his hands into the air like he was in the same room with the person on the other end.

Besides convincing me for a moment that you have an imaginary friend, you just made me drop the ammo for my AK-47. Damn you!

(apologies to Bill Maher)

entry.title: re: Gesticu Lame
entry.content: I have run into this same thing. With the exception that I was looking in the direction of the person on the phone while he was talking. I thought that he was talking to me, of course some complete stranger would want to talk to me while waiting in line. So I responded that I had not heard what he said. Only to have the guy on the phone tell me he was talking to someone else. At that point I realized how slow the line I was standing in was actually moving.

entry.title: re: Gesticu Lame
entry.content: What's *really* scary is that these same people do this while they drive! :-)

entry.title: re: Gesticu Lame

It goes under the X-Ray machine, he grabs it on the other end and continues his conversation.

entry.title: PDC's DHCP screwed up my laptop's name resolution
entry.content:
Thanks for your post, Aaron. I was hit by the same thing - it was getting frustrating not being able to use machine names after getting home from PDC. Simple name resolution was simply not working.

If anyone else is having this problem, run ipconfig /all and check your Node Type. Mine was flipped to something like “Peer to Peer“. The following registry entry (followed by a reboot - bleh) switched it to Broadcast and made things work again. I've not spent much time studying the name resolution protocol that MS uses, but I know I don't have a WINS server at home, so I guess Broadcast makes the most sense for me (if you know better, please post a comment here :-)

Here's the registry key you need to tweak, assuming you're running XP:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Netbt\Parameters

Add a DWORD named value called NodeType and set it's value to 1. Reboot and check your node type again - it should be Broadcast, and name resolution should start working again for you.

For more info on this registry key, see kb article number 160177.

Thanks again, Aaron :-)

entry.title: re: PDC's DHCP screwed up my laptop's name resolution

entry.title: re: PDC's DHCP screwed up my laptop's name resolution

Thanks again for posting. You've made things all better!

(unless what, I don't know), but I do no that PC name resolution won't work on a home LAN with node type of peer-to-peer (P-mode) and no WINS server.

entry.title: SQL Server 2005 June+ CTP will not install on a DC
entry.content:
Dan Jones from Microsoft gives the story on the third page of this thread.

In the June CTP, SQL Server started using local groups to abstract the actual account you use to run SQL Server from the permissions granted. Remember how hard it was to change the user SQL Server ran as under SQL 2000? Well, with the groups, it becomes much easier. All ACLs, privileges, etc. are granted to the groups instead of to the individual user (standard best practices). That's the good news.

The bad news is that they haven't yet dealt with the case SQL Server is installed on a domain controller (Small Business Server is a great example of this). There are no local groups there, so they end up creating domain local groups. No big deal there, except that they then try to add NETWORK SERVICE into those groups, and on a domain controller you cannot add built-in identities or groups into domain groups (which in hindsight is probably a good idea even on non-DC machines - you shouldn't be changing the permission level of any built-in identities or groups that the OS depends on).

This wouldn't be a problem if the installer let you configure the identities for ALL the daemons that Yukon sets up. For example, I'm configuring the services to run as a domain account called SqlUser. That account clearly wouldn't have a problem being added to a group. But apparently there is some Active Directory helper daemon that they have hardcoded to run as NETWORK SERVICE, and that is where they run into trouble. And there may be others.

If you read Dan's post, you'll see that they plan on fixing this problem by RTM.

I'm posting this in the hopes of saving somebody a lot of hassle - Google shows an awful lot of threads that end with the unanswered question. The solution for now (if you can call it that) is to install Yukon not on the DC, but on a member server in the domain. That's not too bad if you're working with Virtual PC and have an extra stick of RAM laying around ;-)

entry.title: Wiki for .NET Versions
Cipher modes and plaintext redundancy
entry.content:
I just came across a neat graphical portrait of the difference between using electronic code book (ECB) for a block cipher (basically you encrypt each block of data independently of the others) versus using a cipher mode like cipher-block-chaining (CBC) which mixes things up between blocks, making the next block of ciphertext dependent on the previous blocks.

The picture clearly shows how repetitions in plaintext become apparent when you look at the overall message encrypted under ECB. Very neat! This should also make it clear how helpful it is to compress plaintext before encrypting it, in order to reduce redundancy. SSL does this, for example.

entry.title: re: Cipher modes and plaintext redundancy

entry.title: Security engineering for the rest of us
entry.content:
There's been a lot of talk coming out of Microsoft about SDL, the Security Development Lifecycle. I've been asked to add content about it in my own presentations at TechEd and PDC. But many people get confused about how SDL applies to them. Consider for example, this excerpt from the SDL document:

During the requirements phase, the product team makes contact with the central security team to request the assignment of a security advisor (referred to as the "security buddy" in the implementation of the SDL at Microsoft) who serves as point of contact, resource, and guide as planning proceeds.

Small- to medium-sized companies look at this and wonder, “Are we supposed to have a central security team?” Then later in the document they read,

During the release phase, the software should be subject to a Final Security Review ("FSR"). The goal of the FSR is to answer one question. "From a security viewpoint, is this software ready to deliver to customers?" The FSR is conducted two to six months prior to software completion, depending on the scope of the software. The software must be in a stable state before the FSR, with only minimal non-security changes expected prior to release.

Two to six months? After a bit of this, it's easy to get the impression that SDL (at least as presented in this document) may work well for Microsoft, but isn't appropriate for a typical ISV or smaller enterprises.

Recently I spent some time in Redmond, reviewing some of the new security content coming out of the Patterns & Practices group. During the three days I was up there, I spent about a third of that time chatting with J.D. Meier about his strategies and goals for publishing security advice for the rest of us, many of whom don't happen to have security buddies in their companies, or two months to wait before shipping a product.

The security engineering process that P&P recommends is designed to be tailored to your needs. It doesn't assume that you have a central security team or a huge security budget. It's all about prioritizing your work so that you can make use of the limited money and cycles that you have to do the best possible job of securing your applications.

If this whets your appetite, let me help you get started finding your way around the oodles of content that's available to you today.

Start by surfing to http://msdn.com/securityguidance and focus on the table of contents in the tree view. As I write this, here's what you'll see:

  • Security Engineering
  • Guidelines
  • How Tos
  • Checklists
  • Practices
  • Views

Security Engineering is all about process. This is where you'll find advice for building security into your own software development lifecycle, no matter if you use a waterfall, agile, or other approach to developing software. Here you'll learn how to overlay security tasks onto existing processes: requirements, design, implementation, testing, etc. so that no matter where you do these things in your current lifecycle, you'll know what sort of security tasks need to be done in that phase. You'll also find specific guidance on performing each of these tasks, from Security Architecture & Design Reviews and Threat Modeling, to advice on performing your own Security Code Reviews.

Guidelines give specific advice on secure design and implementation issues, including input validation, secret encryption, authentication, and more. The guidelines focus more on the WHY than the HOW. I'm the kind of person who would prefer that you teach me to fish as opposed to handing me a couple salmon because I look hungry. The goal of the guidelines is to teach you to fish, if that analogy makes sense :)

Howtos on the other hand simply focus on HOW to get the job done in a step by step manner. Each of the guidelines should have an associated howto, and I'm hoping in the future there will be more back-and-forth linkage between the two; this was one of the many suggestions I gave during my three day visit. Howtos are great for those of us who already understand the issues and just need a reminder of how to implement a security feature. And for someone who doesn't understand the issues and doesn't have time for the WHY, a howto just might close a vulnerability they otherwise might have left open.

Checklists are a quick way to make sure you've not forgotten anything. If you run through a checklist and find you've missed something, you should whip open the guidelines and read about the issue, then follow any howto links for a step-by-step guide.

Practices are something that sit in between guidelines and howtos, and are useful for people who don't need the detailed step-by-step instructions found in the howtos. If you're already an expert ASP.NET programmer, you might want to read the Guidelines and then use the Practices document as your guide to implementing security features.

Views show you indexes that are filtered based on a few simple criteria. If you're doing ASP.NET 2.0, you probably don't want to see 1.x advice. I'd recommend drilling down into the views just to see if they can help you get to the content you need more quickly.

Right now the preponderance of advice is in the ASP.NET space, which isn't surprising since that's J.D.'s background ;-) But it's a good start, because web applications are often the most risky applications because they are typically available to remote, anonymous attackers.

P&P is actively working to provide advice for other types of appliations as well, but look, don't be put off if today's advice isn't targeted at the particular type of application you're building today. A lot of the advice given in the guidelines for ASP.NET applications is generally applicable to other types of applications as well.

If you want to get the very latest & greatest info that's coming out of P&P with respect to security, check out the wiki that J.D. maintains on channel9. This is where his team floats new ideas and new views of content. It's easy to find at http://channel9.msdn.com/security. And since it's a wiki, you can leave feedback about what you'd like to see from these guys in the future.

entry.title: Detecting duplicate SPNs
entry.content:
I was just talking with Craig about a Kerberos problem he's having, and one of the possibilities that came up was that he might have a duplicate service principal name registered for a web server. I hacked up a little app to help him find if he's got any duplicate SPNs registered; you might also find this useful.
 
Here's what an entry in the listing will normally look like. The SPN is listed first, followed by the user account onto which it maps. I sort the output by SPN to make it a bit more readable:
 
PayrollSystem/MAIN --> CN=BtsUser,CN=Users,DC=nwm,DC=local
 
When you have a duplicate SPN, I'll call it out. This example shows the PayrollSystem/MAIN SPN has been mapped onto two different domain accounts, which means anyone who tries to authenticate with it using Kerb will fail.
 
PayrollSystem/MAIN --> CN=BtsUser,CN=Users,DC=nwm,DC=local
PayrollSystem/MAIN --DUPLICATE-->  CN=Alice Wu,CN=Employees,DC=nwm,DC=local
 
To fix this, you'd run the following command to remove the erroneous SPN mapping to Alice:
 
setspn -D PayrollSystem/MAIN NWM\Alice
 
I'm having trouble posting the code directly to the blog, but you can get it here.

entry.title: re: Detecting duplicate SPNs
entry.content: How do you get this app to run?

entry.title: W2K3 SP1 IIS6 Service Unavailable NOT fixed with latest patch
entry.content:
I just got hit with this today, and a bit of googling shows that lots of folks have been running into problems with IIS6 application pools after installing SP1. My lab box is a W2K3 domain controller.

While I've been running SP1 for awhile in the lab, my app pools were running as Network Service and everything was swell. But when I switched to a custom user account, I started seeing some incredibly odd behavior.

First of all, the user account has all the right privileges - it's a member of IIS_WPG, for example. And running FILEMON shows no problems accessing files.

When the AppPool first starts up, keeping a close watch on TaskManager, I can see W3WP.EXE start up, but the user name says which is really odd. And get this - if the user account was recently created, looking at Active Directory shows that the account has *never*  been logged in. IOW, W3WP.EXE is being launched, then its dentity is being changed to the custom identity (maybe that's how IIS works, but it sure feels odd).

Looking at the security event log (I log both success and failed logon events) shows nothing. It doesn't appear as though any attempt is being made to log in the custom user (and later scouring the user account with ADSIEDIT shows that it's never been logged on). The SYSTEM event log shows about five attempts to start the application pool, then the pool is disabled (I'm sure you've seen this before). This is the typical thing you see when you get the dreaded “Service Unavailable“ error. Tip for those new to this - you need to manually restart the application pool once you get this error - refresh the Application Pools folder in IIS manager and you'll see which pools are disabled -  you need to right-click the disabled pool and choose “start“ to reenable it, otherwise you'll continue to get “Service Unavailable“ even if you've fixed the underlying problem.

The user accounts I'm using are initially created using System.DirectoryServices. I will post the steps I'm taking to create these accounts at the end of this entry. Get this - if I use the AD Users & Groups snapin to create the user instead of my own code, the IIS application pool runs just fine. I can also call net user /add to add the user (and then add it to the IIS_WPG group), and that also works just fine.

I compared the programmatically-created user account with the snapin-created account using ADSIEDIT, and only found one very small difference - an esoteric hidden flag on the account (ADS_UF_PASSWD_NOTREQD) was set on the account I created in code, but not in the snapin-created account. So I tweaked my code to turn off this switch, created a new account, and I'm still having the same problem.

As I'm writing this blog entry, I'm also installing the October security patches for W2K3 (there are oh, about 8 of them). I'm hoping that one of these patches will fix the problem.

UPDATE: After letting the bits in my VPC cool a bit after installing the patches, sure enough, the problem reappeared. And now it's not just with my programmatically created user accounts - it's happening even with user accounts I create via AD Users & Groups. Looks like it's back to the googleboard for me :(

AND SURE ENOUGH... after installing the latest security patches (just came out this week on MS Update), the problem appears to be fixed.

Well, I hope this helps somebody - writing this post gave me something to do while the new patches installed, I guess. I'll update this post if I find that I'm just hallucinating, but it does indeed look as though the problem is fixed now.
