entry.title: Red Cell
entry.content:
An article from the Washington Post talks about some of the funky advice the Dept. of Homeland Security is paying for these days (the group that generates these reports is called Red Cell). While it's a great idea to hire people to think “out of the box”, there's got to be a more efficient way. Looking at some of this advice clearly shows that it lacks consideration of security tradeoffs.

Oh, and watch where you take your pressure cooker these days...

entry.title: Calling HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl from managed code
entry.content:
Here's some sample C# code that sets up a namespace reservation by calling HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl. Note that by switching a flag in the code, you can remove the namespace reservation, so this class would work well during installation as well as removal.

using System;
using System.Xml;
using System.Security.Principal;
using System.Runtime.InteropServices;
//
// No dependencies
//
// Package configuration:
// 
//
public class ReserveHttpNamespace {
    static void Main(string[] args) {
        if (args.Length != 2) {
            Console.WriteLine(
            "Usage: reserveHttpNamespace " +
            "prefix account");
            return;
        }
        try {
            ModifyReservation(args[0], args[1], false);
            Console.WriteLine("Success!");
        }
        catch (Exception x) {
            Console.WriteLine(x.Message);
        }
    }
    static void ModifyReservation(string urlPrefix,
                                  string accountName,
                                  bool removeReservation) {
        string sddl = createSddl(accountName);
        HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET configInfo;
        configInfo.Key.UrlPrefix = urlPrefix;
        configInfo.Param.Sddl = sddl;
        HTTPAPI_VERSION httpApiVersion =
            new HTTPAPI_VERSION(1, 0);
        int errorCode = HttpInitialize(httpApiVersion,
            HTTP_INITIALIZE_CONFIG, IntPtr.Zero);
        if (0 != errorCode) throw getException(
            "HttpInitialize",
            errorCode);
        try {
            // do our best to delete any existing ACL
            errorCode = HttpDeleteServiceConfigurationAcl(
                IntPtr.Zero,
                HttpServiceConfigUrlAclInfo,
                ref configInfo,
                Marshal.SizeOf(
                    typeof(HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET)),
                IntPtr.Zero);
            if (removeReservation) {
                if (0 != errorCode) throw getException(
                    "HttpDeleteServiceConfigurationAcl",
                    errorCode);
                return;
            }
            errorCode = HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl(
                IntPtr.Zero,
                HttpServiceConfigUrlAclInfo,
                ref configInfo,
                Marshal.SizeOf(
                    typeof(HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET)),
                IntPtr.Zero);
            if (0 != errorCode) throw getException(
                "HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl",
                errorCode);
        }
        finally {
            errorCode = HttpTerminate(
                HTTP_INITIALIZE_CONFIG,
                IntPtr.Zero);
            if (0 != errorCode) throw getException(
                "HttpTerminate",
                errorCode);
        }
    }
    private static Exception getException(string fcn, int errorCode) {
        Exception x = new Exception(
            string.Format("{0} failed: {1}",
            fcn, getWin32ErrorMessage(errorCode)));
        return x;
    }
    static string createSddl(string account) {
        string sid = new NTAccount(account).Translate(
            typeof(SecurityIdentifier)).ToString();
        // DACL that Allows Generic eXecute for the user
        // specified by account
        // see help for HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_PARAM
        // for details on what this means
        return string.Format("D:(A;;GX;;;{0})", sid);
    }
    static string getWin32ErrorMessage(int errorCode) {
        int hr = HRESULT_FROM_WIN32(errorCode);
        Exception x = Marshal.GetExceptionForHR(hr);
        return x.Message;
    }
    static int HRESULT_FROM_WIN32(int errorCode) {
        if (errorCode <= 0) return errorCode;
        return (int)((0x0000FFFFU &
            ((uint)errorCode)) | (7U << 16) |
            0x80000000U);
    }
    // P/Invoke stubs from http.h
    const int HttpServiceConfigUrlAclInfo = 2;
    const int HTTP_INITIALIZE_CONFIG = 2;
    [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)]
    struct HTTPAPI_VERSION {
        public HTTPAPI_VERSION(short maj, short min) {
            Major = maj; Minor = min;
        }
        short Major;
        short Minor;
    }
    [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)]
    struct HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_KEY {
        [MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.LPWStr)]
        public string UrlPrefix;
    }
    [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)]
    struct HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_PARAM {
        [MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.LPWStr)]
        public string Sddl;
    }
    [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)]
    struct HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET {
        public HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_KEY Key;
        public HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_PARAM Param;
    }
    [DllImport("httpapi.dll", ExactSpelling = true,
            EntryPoint = "HttpSetServiceConfiguration")]
    static extern int HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl(
        IntPtr mustBeZero, int configID,
        [In] ref HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET configInfo,
        int configInfoLength, IntPtr mustBeZero2);
    [DllImport("httpapi.dll", ExactSpelling = true,
            EntryPoint = "HttpDeleteServiceConfiguration")]
    static extern int HttpDeleteServiceConfigurationAcl(
        IntPtr mustBeZero, int configID,
        [In] ref HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_URLACL_SET configInfo,
        int configInfoLength, IntPtr mustBeZero2);
    [DllImport("httpapi.dll")]
    static extern int HttpInitialize(
        HTTPAPI_VERSION version,
        int flags, IntPtr mustBeZero);
    [DllImport("httpapi.dll")]
    static extern int HttpTerminate(int flags,
        IntPtr mustBeZero);
}

entry.title: Aaron's HTTP.SYS transport running as LUA
entry.content:
Aaron forgot to mention one rather important issue that he probably didn't notice because he runs as admin :)

It turns out that HttpListener only works out of the box if you're running with high privilege (e.g., as a member of the BUILTIN\Administrators group). This is because security wonks don't want just anybody doing this magical port sharing thing (imagine the malware that would love to hide on port 80 on an XP SP2 box!)

So if the process that tries to use HttpListener is running under a least privilege user account (LUA) (in other words, if it's running as a normal user), it's not going to be allowed to listen unless a namespace reservation has been made by an administrator beforehand that grants the user permission to do so.

A namespace reservation is simply a record that sets an access control list (ACL) for an HTTP prefix (e.g. the URL you'd normally pass to HttpListener.Prefixes.Add). This allows the administrator to say which users are allowed to register that prefix with HTTP.SYS. If you have a daemon that's doing this, you can simply register the SID for the user account of that daemon as being authorized to register the prefix. An easy way to do this is to run HTTPCFG.EXE (note that this must be done on each machine where HttpListener is to be used):

httpcfg set urlacl -u http://*:80/foo -a D:(A;;GX;;;S-1-5-20)

The odd looking code at the end is security descriptor description language (SDDL) that represents an ACL with a single entry, granting the SID S-1-5-20 the generic execute permission, which is the rather arbitrary access permission that HTTP.SYS looks for in order to grant permission to listen. Just replace the SID with the one you're using (later on I link to an example with some code that simplifies forming this SDDL - you only need to know the account name, not the SID to use it).

If it's not just one identity that needs to be allowed to use the HTTP.SYS transport (maybe a smart client is using it), then you should grant the namespace reservation to a group and add whatever users you want to be allowed to use it into that group. If all users on the machine should be allowed, you can grant the permission to the BUILTIN\Users group (S-1-5-32-545).

If you have an installer for your application that uses HttpListener, you should have your installer add the namespace reservation, because installers normally run with enough privilege to do this. If you are deploying to a wide audience, you will likely not know which user account or group should be granted this right, so you'll need to ask the administrator as part of your setup. Your installer will then need to call the Win32 function, HttpSetServiceConfigurationAcl (which is all that httpcfg does when you use the set urlacl command with it). I just posted some sample .NET code to show how this can be done programmatically in C#.

entry.title: SQL Server logins and SIDs
entry.content:
I just spent about 30 minutes debugging something really dumb and I thought I'd post here in case I can save someone that time.

I'm working on some deployment scripts, and part of what they do is create user and group accounts in Active Directory and SQL Server logins for some of those users and groups.

I found myself at a place where I had a login for a group Foo, and I was logged in as a user with that group (I checked with W2K3's convenient whoami /groups to make sure). But for some reason I could not log in to the database. I then created a new login manually for another group, and sure enough that worked fine.

There seemed to be some difference between what my script was doing (create login Foo for windows) and what SQL Management Studio was doing, but here's what was really happening.

When you create a SQL login for a user or a group, the *name* is not used to resolve the login. Rather the SID for the account is used. It turns out that while my AD code was always deleteing and recreating users at each deploy, my database script had code like this:

if not exists(select * from master.sys.syslogins where name='Foo')
begin
  create login [Foo] for windows
end

In other words, I wasn't creating the login if it already existed. So after running the deploy two times, the system was broken - the login didn't get recreated so it was using the old SID (when you delete a user or group account and then add it again, even if you use the same name, it gets a unique SID).

I could see this breaking in other scenarios as well. Just keep in mind that if you delete a user or group and readd it, you need to do the same thing to your SQL logins so they can get the new SID!

entry.title: re: SQL Server logins and SIDs
entry.content: Would sp_change_users_login work in this case to match the SIDs back up?

entry.title: re: SQL Server logins and SIDs
entry.content:
Good question. I've not tried it before, but looking at the documentation, it appears to be designed to affect the database user, not the SQL login.

So my guess would be no, but I've not tried it myself. Let us know if you find out differently.

entry.title: Finding the .NET Framework library path
entry.content:
I recently had a need to find the path to the .NET Framework binaries. Here's the official way of finding it, using a function exposed from mscoree.dll:

const int MAX_PATH = 256;
public string GetNetFrameworkDirectory() {
    StringBuilder buf = new StringBuilder(
        MAX_PATH, MAX_PATH);
    int cch = MAX_PATH;
    int hr = GetCORSystemDirectory(
        buf, MAX_PATH, ref cch);
    if (hr < 0) Marshal.ThrowExceptionForHR(hr);
    return buf.ToString();
}

[DllImport("mscoree.dll",
         CharSet=CharSet.Unicode,
         ExactSpelling=true)]
public static extern int GetCORSystemDirectory(
        StringBuilder buf,
        int cchBuf,
        ref int cchRequired);

This returned the following string on my 1.1 box:

C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.1.4322\

entry.title: re: Finding the .NET Framework library path
entry.content: I've always just referenced System.Web.dll and then read the static HttpRuntime.ClrInstallDirectory property. It's documented, involves less typing, and it saves me the hassle of having to have enough permissions to use p/invoke. But then, I'm lazy at my core :-)

entry.content: Ahh, I like that even better. Thanks for the reference, Mike.

entry.content: Or you can use System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeEnvironment.GetRuntimeDirectory()

entry.title: How to strip (or change) an XML namespace with XmlDocument
entry.content:
Part of the deployment scripts I'm working on must programmatically munge .NET config files. And I want to be able to use xpath expressions to index into them, but xpath is more painful (for what I'm doing at least) when namespaces are involved.

Sometimes config files look like this:

<configuration>...</configuration>

But they often also look like this:

<configuration xmlns='...'>...</configuration>

I needed a way to strip out the namespace before doing my queries. I found a solution and thought I'd share it here. XmlElement.SetAttribute can be used to change the namespace declaration (this is some special case code in the .NET DOM for this). But the change doesn't seem to take effect right away - I had to serialize the DOM tree and reload it, then things worked nicely. Here's a little function to do this:

XmlDocument stripDocumentNamespace(XmlDocument oldDom) {
    // some config files have a default namespace
    // we are going to get rid of that to simplify our xpath expressions
    if (oldDom.DocumentElement.NamespaceURI.Length > 0) {
        oldDom.DocumentElement.SetAttribute("xmlns", "");
        // must serialize and reload the DOM
        // before this will actually take effect
        XmlDocument newDom = new XmlDocument();
        newDom.LoadXml(oldDom.OuterXml);
        return newDom;
    }
    else return oldDom;
}

entry.title: re: How to strip (or change) an XML namespace with XmlDocument
entry.content:
Dan Sullivan (an authority on XML that I highly respect) points out that this is a very dangerous thing to do in the general case because it can lead to problems like duplicate names, etc.

I should probably have made it more clear that stripping namespaces is not to be taken lightly. I posted this to show not only how to strip namespaces, but how to *change* namespaces if necessary. Be careful that you know what you're doing if you strip. Here was my response to Dan:

This is a case where it's all the same namespace, which is why I pointed out that namespaces don't really matter in my case. I definitely thought about your concern, but from a purely practical perspective, the only reason the namespace is used in <configuration> is to get intellisense. So it seems pretty clear to me that stripping is very much appropriate in this case.

I'd never do this with a SOAP message, for example, where namespaces are used quite regularly, and are important for the meaning of the message.

entry.title: re: How to strip (or change) an XML namespace with XmlDocument
re: How to strip (or change) an XML namespace with XmlDocument
entry.content:
Allan,

I actually went down that path first. But with xpath there is no way to define a default namespace for use inside expressions. So I'd have had to define a prefix for Microsoft's default config namespace, then used that in each location step of each xpath expression. Oh, and then I have to get everyone else I'm working with to agree on the namespace prefix we're all going to use in the xpath expressions. Ick!

Another option (Dan suggested this) would be to explicitly use local-name() in my xpath expressions. Both of these options clutter up the xpath expressions, which in this *particular* application would reduce the readability of what I'm doing enough that I figured it simply wasn't worth it.

Given MS's penchant for backwards compatibility, and given that it was only recently that we've seen namespaces in config files, I'm not worried that my code is going to break for the lifetime of this app.

It was a purely practical decision that really simplifies things. And it was soooo worth it in this case :-)

entry.title: re: How to strip (or change) an XML namespace with XmlDocument
entry.content:
It is also possible to strip all xmlns:* references from the XMLDocument using Regular Expressions:

XmlDocument stripDocumentNamespace(XmlDocument oldDom)
{
// Remove all xmlns:* instances from the passed XmlDocument
// to simplify our xpath expressions.
XmlDocument newDom = new XmlDocument();
newDom.LoadXml(System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex.Replace(
oldDom.OuterXml, @"(xmlns:?[^=]*=[""][^""]*[""])", "",
System.Text.RegularExpressions.RegexOptions.IgnoreCase | System.Text.RegularExpressions.RegexOptions.Multiline)
);
return newDom;
}

This one gets rid of all "xmlns:{alias}" occurencies in the document, but you can limit it by making the Regex more restrictive if needed.

Regards, Robert

entry.title: Computing SHA1 hashes on files
entry.content:
Last night I downloaded the SQL Server 2005 Developer Edition DVD ISO image, and as you can probably tell from my last post, I'm trying to get it installed in a VPC. Not having much luck so far. VPC can't mount the ISO image directly, so I burned it to a DVD+RW and tried installing, which gave me an error while installing the .NET Framework 2.0 (I couldn't repro it because after running it a second time the install got past that step smoothly).

Anyway,I wanted to make sure that the image I downloaded matched the ISO that was up on the MSDN site, so I hacked up a little SHA1 hash calculator. I tried using both the managed and unmanaged SHA1 implementations and found (not surprisingly) that the unmanaged version was considerably faster, so I stuck with that.

Anyway, here's the code for the SHA1 calculator if you want one of these for yourself. Post comments if you have improvements, especially perf improvements!

using System;
using System.IO;
using System.Security.Cryptography;
class ComputeSha1ForFiles {
    // this seems to be the sweet spot for perf on my box
    const int BUF_SIZE = 4096 * 10;
    const int PROGESS_INTERVAL_MS = 1000;
     static void Main(string[] args) {
        if (0 == args.Length) {
            Console.Error.WriteLine("Usage: sha1 fname [fname ...]");
        }
        foreach (string fname in args) {
            processFile(fname);
        }
     }
    static void processFile(string fname) {
        SHA1 t = new SHA1CryptoServiceProvider();
        
        using (FileStream fs = File.Open(fname,
            FileMode.Open, FileAccess.Read, FileShare.Read))
        using (CryptoStream cs = new CryptoStream(fs, t,
            CryptoStreamMode.Read)) {
            pumpStream(cs, fs);
        }
        foreach (byte b in t.Hash) {
            Console.Write("{0:X2}", b);
        }
        Console.WriteLine();
    }
    static void pumpStream(Stream s, FileStream fs) {
        DateTime begin = DateTime.Now;
        DateTime beginInterval = begin;
        byte[] buf = new byte[BUF_SIZE];
        for (;;) {
            int c = s.Read(buf, 0, buf.Length);
            if (c != buf.Length) break;
            DateTime now = DateTime.Now;
            if ((now - beginInterval).TotalMilliseconds >
                PROGESS_INTERVAL_MS) {
                double bytesPerSecond = (double)fs.Position /
                    (now - begin).TotalSeconds;
                beginInterval = now;
                Console.Error.WriteLine(
                  "{0}% done ({1:N0} bytes/second)",
                  fs.Position * 100 / fs.Length, bytesPerSecond);
            }
        }
    }
}

entry.title: Work that's unfit for computers
entry.content:
http://www.mturk.com

I remember Douglas Adams's keynote at the 1996 PDC, where he talked about how computers do certain things well, but humans are much better at many tasks. He emphasized that human-computer interfaces should take advantage of this, describing a tool that was used to figure out the cheapest path for a road through a mountainous area that was ultimately calculated by a human and a force-feedback joystick. The pressures in the joystick represented costs and other tensions for building the road in a certain area, and the human guided the joystick according to those pressures, quickly finding the optimal route for the road.

I've probably decimated the story, but damn it was a great keynote, and I was really happy to have been able to see Doug in person, being such a big fan of his work. Anyway, this new service from amazon.com allows companies to parse out work (looks like a lot of pattern-recognition work at first glance) that computers simply don't do well.

And there's a web service interface if you want to wire your apps into it. Cool stuff.

entry.title: What is a claim?
entry.content:
Just happened across this post by Kim Cameron, with a really clear reasoning behind the word “claim”. Claim is a term which you've heard a lot about if you've paid much attention to the WS-* security specs, and I think you'll be hearing a lot more about it in the future with InfoCard coming down the road:

In the interests of completeness, now that we have defined "digital subject", let's define "claim".  At the same time I will explain why I have used the word "claim" where others might have said "security assertion" or just "assertion".

Again, according to the OED, an assertion is a "confident and forceful statement of fact or belief".  On the other hand, a claim is "an assertion of the truth of something, typically one which is disputed or in doubt".

It is interesting that systems deriving from the X.500 and X.509 standards - including LDAP - have employed the word "attribute value assertion" (abbreviated AVA) to describe the mechanism by which the attributes of an object are presented.  Those systems were thought out from the vantage point of the "administrative domain" making the assertions;  Active Directory's LDAP engine was built along this model.  So indeed, information is stored in the directory, which later "confidently and forcefully" presents it to the digital subjects of the domain, either through queries or associated protocols like kerberos.

When all subjects subscribe to the same administrative authority, and the trust boundaries are extremely clear and well defined, it makes sense to employ a metaphor based on confidence and force.  But in evolving from a closed domain model to an open, federated model, the situation is transformed into one where the party making an assertion and the party evaluating it may have a complex and even ambivalent relationship.  In this context, assertions need always be subject to doubt - not only doubt that they have been transmitted from the sender to the recipient intact, but also doubt that they are actually true.  We need to incorporate the insights of SPKI.  We must always favor the vantage point of the relying party.

The word "claim" - taken as "an assertion of the truth of something which is ...  in doubt" - grasps the subtleties of the federated world by adding the right dose of doubt to any assertion being made, and effectively reminding us to surface this doubt in our implementaiton.

entry.title: Trust is such a loaded word
entry.content:
"The data server trusts the application server."
"Domain B trusts domain A."
"Bob validates the ticket and develops trust in the client."

What does any of that mean? I've seen way too many instances where the word trust really just muddies the water.

For example, does the first statement imply that the data server trusts the validity of the input it's getting from the app server? Or does it imply that client authorization occurs in the app server and that we have a "trusted subsystem" (the word crops up again and again, doesn't it?)

Domain trust in Windows is often misunderstood. The second statement is typically shorthand for saying that domain A has a Kerberos trust relationship established with domain B such that domain A is allowed to issue a TGT for domain B to a user that domain B does not have the ability to authenticate. But often people read more into it than that, assuming that there's more going on, perhaps granting special privileges or access permissions. Trust is a confusing term, especially when left unqualified.

In the third statement, what exactly does Bob trust about his client? Maybe Bob has received a signed statement (such as a Kerb ticket) from his security authority that helps prove that the sender is indeed the legitimate bearer of the credentials she's using. But does that mean Bob should trust her actions? Just because someone is authenticated doesn't mean they won't act maliciously. But the statement doesn't really convey that, does it?

I've always tried to be very specific about my use of the word trust. For example, in the third statement, I would typically say, "Bob validates the ticket and develops trust in the identity of the client." But perhaps I shouldn't even use the word at all. Maybe, "Bob learns the client's identity" would be better.

This post by Jamie Lewis reminded me of my own trouble with the word, and really helped clarify the problem.

entry.title: re: Trust is such a loaded word
entry.content:
> This post by Jamie Lewis reminded me of my
> own trouble with the word

How do you know it was really posted by Jamie Lewis? I don't believe you.

entry.title: Thoughts on &quot;reauthentication&quot;
entry.content:
Steve asks the following question:

 

Is there any reason to develop a login form for my vb.net windows application (to be run by a dozen or so users, all XP, with SQL 2005 backend) such that the login form prompts again for userid and password?

 

Advantage of at least prompting for userid again is to add a little bit more security to the login process - I suppose it may hinder an "evil doer" from walking by someone's computer and launching my application.  

 

It also seems to be overkill - if the user's logon already verified credentials, I ought not do that again it seems.  Comments?

 

It's good that you are thinking of these sorts of things. Some highly secure enterprise applications do require the user to reauthenticate, on a regular basis.

 

But I understand your feeling of discomfort at doing this. There are some significant downsides to doing this sort of thing.

 

For one thing, you are training the user to type in her password whenever she is prompted by an application. I'd rather see the user only enter the password when prompted by WinLogon, which runs on a secure desktop and is harder to spoof.

 

Also, you must collect the user's password in your memory space. This makes your app a target for attackers. You're painting a bullseye on your back.

 

There's a really good reason why Windows requires you to press Control-Alt-Delete to login. This is a "secure attention sequence" that only very privileged code can respond to. This "gets the attention" of the real operating system, which then switches to a secure desktop (the WinLogon desktop) and asks the user for her password.

 

Note that WinLogon prompts the user for her password *after* she's initiated the SAS. WinLogon doesn't pop up password dialogs at random times - this was very carefully designed by the folks who built the core OS, and was designed to train the user that it's only safe to type her password after she performs the SAS and sees the WinLogon desktop.

 

Of course, other groups in Microsoft and other application vendors have subverted this (in the name of convenience) over time. But the idea remains valid.

 

In wild-west environments where the users are all admins of their own machines, this breaks down, because any malware that the user runs will also run as admin, allowing it to replace parts of the OS if it wants (including WinLogon). So this mechanism only really provides guarantees in well-managed secure environments. But I'm sure you don't want your app to be the weak link in such an environment!

 

There is a very simple way to force the user to reauthenticate. Call LockWorkstation. That locks the user's workstation and forces them to go through WinLogon to reauthenticate and get back in. Of course if you do this every time the user launches your app, people aren't going to like your app very much. And you're making your own security policy, which is not a good idea. Much better is to let the security officers at the site make these sorts of decisions, and they can already do that without your application's help - Group Policy can be used to configure screen saver options, including password protection and idle time, locking the user's workstation for them if they walk away for a certain period of time (http://tinyurl.com/53txz).

entry.title: InfoCard terminology
entry.content:
As I delve deeper into InfoCard, I'm concerned that we're not loose with terminology. In order for the Identity Metasystem to succeed, we need to make sure that we don't confuse people into thinking it's just another Passport. That would be a disaster.

An InfoCard is an identity selector. In fact, an “InfoCard” doesn't have any identity information in it, only some metadata that helps the secured identity selector GUI determine which identities would be accepted by a given relying party (RP), so the user can select from a subset of her identities that will work with the RP. This metadata includes things like:

  • Token type (e.g. this identity is represented by a SAML token)
  • Claims supported (given name, email, age, etc.)
  • Address of identity provider

The actual values for these claims (name, email, age, etc.) aren't stored with the InfoCard itself. The identity provider (IP) holds this data, which is why under the covers, InfoCard makes a round-trip to the IP in order to get the token that is ultimately sent to the RP. The token is the credential. The InfoCard is just a way for you to select which token you want to send. It prevents an end user from ever having to see the word “token“, which is a good thing. But the InfoCard itself is never transmitted to anyone.

Yet if you read the documentation surrounding InfoCard today, you'll find that the wording gets a bit loose in places. Here's an excerpt from the Samples_Walkthrough.doc file in the Federated Identity and Access Resource Kit (emphasis is mine):

·         Resource STS – The Web service from the basic sample is modifed to require a security token issued by a Security Token Service (STS). The STS requires requestors to authenticate using a self-issued “InfoCard” and issues a security token that contains an email address claim retrieved from an account database.

·         Identity Provider STS – The Web service from the basic sample requires a security token issued by an Identity Provider. The Identity Provider STS requires the requestor to authenticate using a username and password and submit a managed “InfoCard,” and issues a security token that contains an email address claim retrieved from an account database.

Granted, the above text also talks about security tokens (which is really what gets passed around between the user's system and the IP and RP). But saying we “submit an InfoCard” is misleading.

Here's another example. What impression do you get when you look at this config excerpt?

<wsHttpBinding>
  <binding configurationName="myBinding">
    <security mode="Message">
      <message clientCredentialType="InfoCard" />
    </security>
  </binding>
</wsHttpBinding>

To be fair, the “InfoCard” credential type is really just an alias for a self-issued SAML token that contains an email claim. But someone new to this technology could easily look at this and think that InfoCard itself is a credential. Besides being confusing, this can lead people into thinking that InfoCard is an identity system, when really it's just an abstraction to make the selection of identities easier for a user. It's the part of the identity metasystem that is surfaced to the user.

I hope that going forward the guys working on InfoCard will be sensitive to this. I'm really excited about the potential for the identity big bang, and I don't want misconceptions to derail it!

entry.title: Looking for a new blog aggregator
entry.content:
Over the last couple of years I've relied on NewsGator, a plugin for MS Outlook to read my news. It works like a charm, and I've been very happy with it, but frankly I'm getting tired of Outlook and I want to start moving away from that beast. Outlook must do many really neat things that I don't need, because it takes a hell of a long time to load, and it often doesn't want to go away even when I want it to.

Besides, my PST file is getting HUGE with all those feeds going into it. Frankly, once I read a news item, I don't need it stored on my hard drive after that. That's what Google search is for.

So I downloaded a trial of FeedDemon (FD) so that I could try something new. I like a lot of things about it - the way it allows me to organize feeds into groups and gives me a little newspaper view over each group. The view isn't all that sophisticated, and sometimes it looks kinda weird, but it works well enough. (FWIW, looks like FD is now owned by NewsGator).

FD has a tabbed browsing option - I guess they figured you'd use it for your web browser as well. But for web browsing, I'm used to FireFox. With all the plugins I've got that block ads, etc. my view of the Internet has changed significantly. I can customize it so that it suits my needs, and I like that. But FD uses the IE browser control. So when I click a link from someone's blog, I'm back to ad city. Maybe I'm getting old, but I just cannot read web content with flashing ads in the middle of it anymore. I'm too used to my custom view of the Internet, and I'm not willing to give it up so easily.

Well anyway, my trial period for FD is about to expire, so I need to make a change. I sure wish there were a way to piece together a blog aggregator, allowing me to choose which browser I'd like to use, etc. Maybe someone reading this blog has some ideas - please share!

And for the folks working on Outlook and similar products, guys, please consider revisiting the “less is more” school of thought. Give me something that I can piece together based on my needs, not some monolithic beast that wants to bend me to its will.

entry.title: A security countermeasure that isn't all that
entry.content:
This morning James Sievert emailed me an interesting story. I'm sure most people reading this have had a similar experience. It's a great example where blindly throwing countermeasures at a system can weaken it.

Our security people here distributed a group policy that Enables "Interactive logon: Do not display last user name". So, everytime you log into your machine, you have to provide your user name. Fine.

When your workstation is locked either manually or automatically (through a screen saver), you're required to log in again to display your desktop. In the logon box, your user name is pre-entered for you. Throughout the day, you end up logging into your machine to unlock it. You do it so much in fact, that you get quite accustomed to simply entering only your password.

Now, let's say you lock your workstation and go home for the night. Let's also say that from home you VPN into work and Remote Desktop (RD) to your locked workstation. You complete your task and log out of your workstation.

The next morning you get to work and give your workstation the 3-finger salute. Before the monitor has warmed up, you enter your password to unlock the workstation. You hit Enter, and hear a beep. Seems that your login was rejected. That's because your desktop wasn't really in "locked" mode. The RD session from the previous night changed the type of login that is required the next morning. The password that you just entered went into the user name text box of the login dialog. When you hit enter, you attempted to log into your workstation using your password as the user name and a blank password. Because this login failed it's logged in the Event Log. Guess what's in there? Yep, it's your password!

So in the interest of making your machine more secure, it is actually compromised. You might say that I'm a bonehead because I should have remembered that I used RD the previous night. I contend that the day-to-day operations actually condition one to expect the password-only login. It's also tough to remember over the course of a long weekend or vacation that you used RD. After all, it only takes one of these incidents to compromise your machine security. This is especially true when your normal user id runs as administrator. ;-) I'm not sure who deserves blame here. To some extent it's the security administrators, me, and also Microsoft...

The sad thing about this is that if James makes this "mistake", you just know that lots of other, less savvy users are doing the same thing. The way the system is configured pretty much forces this to happen from time to time.

As Schneier constantly reminds us, security is all about tradeoffs. What do you gain by turning on the DontDisplayLastUserName feature? Given that it only takes effect when you're logged out, not when your workstation is simply locked, not much! There are an awful lot of people who rarely log out of their machines (me included), and rather lock their workstations instead.

Even if everyone did log out regularly, how does it help? You're forcing an attacker to find some other way to discover user names. It certainly doesn't prevent remote exploits; you need to be standing in front of the console to take advantage of this "vulnerability" (this includes remote desktop - even without the DontDisplayLastUserName feature, remote desktop doesn't show the last user who was logged in at the console). And think to yourself, how easy would it be for someone to simply guess my user name anyway? If the attacker is standing in my office, she's got all the information she needs to figure out my user name. It may take a few guesses, but it's not a hard problem. In James's case, coupled with the strict screensaver policy, this makes his life significantly harder. If a countermeasure makes things harder (and more risky) for legitimate users, and doesn't provide any real impediment for an attacker, it's a bad tradeoff.

Security features should be transparent or users will balk, or worse, make mistakes like these. I hope the administrators at James's company read this. If they happen to be reading, I'd suggest picking up a copy of Jesper & Steve's book, which provides really practical advice for securing Windows. It'll help prevent these sorts of mistakes in the future!

entry.title: Yet another reason to run as non-admin
entry.content:
I found this link from Jesper's blog. Not surprisingly, running as non-admin tends to prevent malware and other crap you don't want from installing itself on your machine.

Using fully patched Windows 2000 Professional and Windows XP Professional clients, we visited a series of less-than-savory Web sites in an effort to install various types of adware and spyware bundlers.

We performed the same tests on separate but identical virtual machines, varying only the user's group membership—with users representing Administrators, Power Users and Users.

After attempting to install the various applications, we rebooted the client, logged in with an approved Administrator account and installed anti-spyware software.

Using this software, Sunbelt Software Inc.'s CounterSpy 1.5, we scanned each system, totaling the number of threats found as well as the grand total of threat instances detected.

We found a vast degree of difference among the three user memberships. On our Windows 2000 Professional client with User permissions only, none of the malware installed completely and two threats actually warned that the user had insufficient privileges.

entry.title: InfoCard API
entry.content:
So far all the examples of InfoCard have been centered around WCF. But I was curious how one would access InfoCard directly and request a token from a non-WCF service requestor app. Sure enough, in Microsoft.InfoCards, there's a class called InfoCardClient that has a few interesting static methods (I'm using the latest November CTP):

void Manage();
void Import(string filename);
GenericXmlSecurityToken GetToken(
   EndpointAddress endpoint,
   IEnumerable policyElements,
   XmlElement requiredRemoteTokenIssuer);

Manage() brings up the Digital Identities control panel applet.

I assume that Import() takes an InfoCard XML document and imports it.

GetToken is the interesting one. There's even some sample code here that describes how to use it. The policy you submit is basically what the relying party needs (token shape and claims required). The third argument can be null if you don't care which issuer the token comes from. I'm pretty close to actually making this call work; I just need a live endpoint (which I'm trying to fire up now using WCF, but the ServiceHost<T> class appears to have disappeared and been replace with a non-generic ServiceHost that I'm having difficulty getting working).

But anyway, if you were wondering how to use InfoCard directly, now you know. This will be a useful API to experiment with to learn more about how InfoCard works under the covers.

entry.title: Settling on a new aggregator

I like it's recursive folder structure and the fact that you can view a newspaper at any level. You can also tell it to auto-delete read posts after they get to a certain age (I'm trying 30 days for now). It seems very fast and stable (I've seen an exception dialog pop up when I surfed to a wiki edit page from a link, but the program recovered flawlessly). It doesn't allow you to integrate FireFox, but from what I've read, it's pretty much impossible to integrate FireFox into any product because there's no control based on the FireFox code base, only Mozilla. Oh well; maybe I'll take the time to write a "View Link in FireFox" browser helper object (BHO) one of these days.

entry.title: WS-Policy in Ruby
entry.content:
Don's post listing the Ruby canon prompted me to invest in a set for myself. Last weekend I studied the Programming Ruby and fell in love (it didn't hurt that Dave Thomas is the author - he's eminently readable). Perl and Smalltalk have always been a couple of my favorite languages, and Ruby feels a lot like Perl++ with Smalltalk extensions.

The only way to learn something is to use it, and I've been wanting to make a closer study of WS-Policy (which is used pretty extensively in InfoCard), so I looked around and not finding any existing implementation in Ruby, I wrote a Ruby model for representing policy over the weekend. So far, it parses a policy into its model (with REXML parsing the XML), and provides a function to normalize compact policies.

I spent the vast majority of my time on the normalization procedure, which was an excellent exercise in learning Ruby. So it doesn't even serialize policy yet, but I'll get that added in the next round. Currently it uses a placeholder to represent the assertions; I've not yet decided the best way to carry around the details of each assertion. The next logical step would be to intersect policies to weed out alternatives whose policy vocabularies don't match. I'd also like to add a more friendly enumerator over a normalized policy that simply gives you the choices (a normalized policy consists of one ExactlyOne containing a set of All elements with all the possible variations of alternatives, flattened out).

Where is all this going? If I have the time, I'd like to eventually flesh out enough of a WS-* library in Ruby that I can implement an InfoCard relying party. Pretty ambitious, but if anyone wants to help, I think it'd be a valuable service to the community.

Anyway, if you're a Ruby expert, I'd love for you to look at my code and let me know if I'm following modern idioms in the implementation and especially in the design of the library. If this ends up being more than a weekend project, I'd like to eventually publish it for others to use.

You can download the library here. You'll need to put it somewhere on your RUBYLIB path, or tweak your path to run the test suite.

Flame away!

entry.title: Updated WS-Policy in Ruby bits
Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
Pardon my rant, but does anyone use this feature more than once a year? It'd sure be nice if it were optional (and turned off by default). Is it just me, or are you also fed up with accidentally whacking that Insert key and then playing with undo/redo until you find the exact spot where you turned on this “feature“? And what fun for a non-technical person using Word who accidentally puts himself in that mode...

A few years back, I physically tore off my CAPSLOCK key and threw it in the trash can. I'd had all I could take with that <vulgarLink>stupid key</vulgarLink>. But removing the Insert key isn't something I want to do. There are occasions when even I use overwrite mode, but they are few and far between.

Google searches for "turn off" "overwrite mode" "Microsoft Word" and the like haven't been very fruitful for me, so if you feel the way I do, and you've figured out a way to disable overwrite mode in Word, VS.NET or any other product, I'd love to hear from you.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: The key can be remapped to anything you'd prefer. If you don't feel like mucking about with the registry settings yourself, you might want to take a look at SharpKeys (http://www.randyrants.com/sharpkeys/).

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
I'd suggest the delete key - that's a fairly common typo for me.

And I'll be sure to make the feature toggleable if I ever finish writing my World's Greatest Text Editor Control. :)

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
I use the Caps Lock key sometimes. If coding calls to Win32 APIs that need data structures defined in PSDK headers than I might even use the Caps Lock key several times in one day.

The Insert key I could do without, with one exception. It seems I'm the only one who persuaded a version of Grub (no longer current though) to work properly with a Japanese keyboard. Since BIOS translation of scan codes doesn't cover enough keys, I had to abuse the scan code for the Insert key. No wait a minute, I STILL don't need the Insert key for that, I just need its scan code. Yeah I agree, let's rip that key off the keyboard.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: I typically disable the CAPSLOCK key entirely. I hate that damn thing. And I think the keyboard designers in the sky agree with you about the INS key, because on many new keyboards, they've moved it up as an F-LOCK key on the top row.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: I know Eclipse has an option to disable it buried somewhere, so it must be a fairly common need...

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
I couldn't live without it, but them I'm probably one of the few wierd people who use SHIFT+DELETE, CTRL+INSERT and SHIFT+INSERT for Cut, Copy and Paste rather than the usual ^X ^C ^V keys.

I find it more natural to use these keys because when editing my hands are naturally close to the SHIFT, CONTROL and ARROW keys for selecting text/code before copying/pasting it.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
This blog entry is the first result for the Google query "disable overwrite word." The second has a solution: http://www.annoyances.org/exec/show/article08-105

Seems to work for me. Good luck.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: Also, you can still enable it by double-clicking "OVR" on the taskbar.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: Works like a charm, thanks for posting, Marcus.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional

Thankyou so much for telling me about the insert key. I'm from England and I didn't even know the insert key had anything to do with overwrite, I just knew about the double clicking "OVR".
I now know how to disable overwrite when I'm entering info online. Y'ou have save dme alot of typing!

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: Im from Eng;land too but i don't know how to undo ovr if im online1 please somone tell me! or ill go spare! i can do it on word clicking ovr nt he taskbar!

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: I've got the exact opposite problem in Word 2003 - overwrite is disabled, and the option to enable it is disabled too. The insert key and double-clicking on the 'OVR' indicator have no effect. But I want to use it!

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content: I just figured it out. If you are online, and you begin to overwrite, just hit the delete button then hit the insert button. It worked for me.

entry.title: re: Overwrite mode should be optional
entry.content:
Thank you so much

For Delete and Insert.

it probably saved my 5 hours today.

entry.title: Workarounds for disabling overwrite mode in various apps
entry.content:
Thanks to Marcus for the comment pointing to this post, showing how to disable the Insert key in Word. It's a nice workaround, if the app you're using allows you to assign a macro to the Insert key, as Word does.

I tried the same thing in VS 2005, but it doesn't recognize the Insert key in the “shortcut key“ edit box. I wonder if this is just a UI limitation? Running FILEMON while saving a key assignment in VS 2005 shows it writing to two files in the profile: Current.VSK and User.VSK, but the VSK files are binary (bummer, here I thought VS was moving all its config to XML).

I've started a wiki page so folks can post workarounds like this to share.

entry.title: re: Workarounds for disabling overwrite mode in various apps
entry.content:
Why not use the Scan Code Mapper, which is built into Win2K+? You can just reassign INS to do nothing and some out-of-the-way key to be your INS. The syntax is cryptic and the UI tool seems to have disappeared from the Microsoft site. But a cryptic API has never stopped you before? :) Just a thought.

http://www.annoyances.org/exec/forum/win2000/n1019911460

entry.title: InfoCard and least privilege
entry.content:
Kim has a great post on how the InfoCard identity selector might work with a credit card. It's neat how this interface can enable all sorts of interesting scenarios like one-time credit cards.

But there's a parallel discussion we should be having.

You may notice the Identity Selector appears on a desktop that I hope will look "grayed out".  This represents the fact that applications running on the normal desktop cannot "see" into (read "steal from") the identity selector: deep in the operating system the two desktops are segregated so the InfoCard surface is, compared to conventional programs, secure. 

The key phrase here is compared to conventional programs. As much as I love the idea of the identity metasystem, I can't help but have dark thoughts about the potential for abuse. Even Kim pointed out that this system will be deployed with a bullseye painted on its back.

We knew that if we were successful, the Infocard system would be one of the most attacked systems in the history of computing.

The more we automate access to identity data from a user's machine, the more we need to worry about the ease of which that machine can be compromised.

A segregated desktop is no match for an attacker who has root compromised your machine. And it's incredibly easy to root a user's machine today because you're virtually guaranteed that the victim will be running as an admin. So when you convince her to launch your malware, it'll also run as admin. It's not even a challenge at that point! That's how Sony managed to install a rootkit on Mark's machine. Even in many corporate environments, users are allowed to run with high privilege because so much software fails to run well under LUA, and the IT department doesn't have the resources to deal with every app that breaks. Ironically, those who are most vulnerable often run with the highest privilege. My neighbor (the least tech-savvy guy on the planet) logs in as Administrator to browse the web and read his email.

The InfoCard representations are "metadata" pointing to the URL where an identity provider is located, the types of technologies it supports, what kind of authentication it employs, and the like.  So there is not really anything tangible or worth stealing in the InfoCard metadata itself.

This is true, but a rooted machine ultimately won't be able to stop the attacker from dereferencing the InfoCard. The attacker calls GetToken to initiate the dereference, then uses SendKeys to drive the identity selector interface that pops. Even better: decrypt an InfoCard and use the metadata there to request a token from the identity provider via WS-Trust. Of course, decrypting and dereferencing an InfoCard might require credentials like passwords. But remember, we're talking about a rooted machine here. The clever attacker will already know the user's passwords, via the keystroke logger she installed when the machine was originally compromised.

Let me be clear - I don't expect the InfoCard guys to build something that's robust enough to work as designed on a rooted system. All the attacks I've postulated against InfoCard work equally well on most other “secure“ credential management systems, even the one I wrote for my own personal use. But what I do want to see is real motion toward comprehensive security measures that prevent the user's machine from being rooted in the first place. XP SP2 was a good first step, but it's not nearly enough.

One of the most effective countermeasures against malware is to run with least privilege. The Windows Logo program was the first effort by Microsoft to get devs to start writing code that runs well with least privilege. But as of yet, Microsoft hasn't taken the next step and actually encouraged users to run as non-admins. Even today, when you create a user account on WinXP, it's an admin account by default. Who would ever choose the “Limited User“ option? It sounds so, well, limited.

Microsoft is working to address this in Vista. They even use terminology that sounds appealing: user protection! But will Microsoft have the courage to turn this feature on by default when Vista ships? Will they persuade users to create least privilege accounts in the first place? And what about people who will continue to use Windows XP?

I'm cautiously optimistic about the future. And I think InfoCard is brilliant. Let's not lose sight of the big picture as we think about it.

entry.title: Re: InfoCard and least privilege
entry.content:
Agreed. I'm wondering if swinging the pendulum in the other direction (going from "this machine isn't secure by default" to "you can't do everything you might need to on this machine") might have some lashback.

However, I'd rather have a machine that warns me when I might be doing something that could cause a virus than to leave me alone and let someone else take over my machine.

I wonder how the market will respond. I'm still getting used to the idea of "run elevated" as an option.

entry.title: See you at VSLive!
entry.content:
It's been ages since I gave a talk for Fawcette, but I'm back in the saddle in February at VSLive! in San Fransisco. Here are the abstracts for my talks, in case you're interested. Be sure to come up and say hi if you're at the event!

Inside ASP.NET 2.0 Security Features
Keith Brown, Pluralsight
In this talk, we'll drill down into a host of new features in ASP.NET 2.0 that make building secure web applications much easier than in the past. Some examples of what we'll cover include the new HttpOnly feature for cookies, web.config file encryption in single-server and web farm configurations, and the Role provider model for role-based security. By understanding how these features work and the problems they were designed to solve, you'll be much better prepared to use them effectively to secure your own applications!

Attack and Defense: Securing ASP.NET 2.0 Applications
Keith Brown, Pluralsight
Building secure ASP.NET applications involves much more than calling security APIs. It takes careful design that considers threats and applies countermeasures that solve real problems instead of just making the application harder to use. It takes a development team that knows how to write bulletproof code, with the foresight and funding to review that code and eradicate security flaws before they can be exploited. Ultimately, it takes education and a good process. This talk will introduce you to many resources you may not have been previously aware of: guidelines for threat modeling ASP.NET applications, howtos for eliminating common security vulnerabilities, and many others. You’ll find that even a small shop can afford to build security into the software development lifecycle.

entry.title: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
I remember awhile back wishing I had a good book on directory services programming from .NET (System.DirectoryServices, etc.). On a whim, I pinged ADSI wunderkind Joe Kaplan about it, and it turned out he and some other folks had already been tossing the idea around. Joe recruited Ryan Dunn and together they have done it - they are in the final phases of delivery of their new book, The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Service Programming, which I'm excited to say is part of the top-notch .NET Development series. You can preorder your copy today - and after you read it, if you like it, please leave feedback on amazon.com. This pair worked really hard on this book, and deserve our gratitude for what at times I'm sure felt like a thankless job.

Ryan and Joe used a similar format for the book that I used in my security book, thus the similar title. If you ever do any work with System.DirectoryServices, this book is a must have.

Guys, I'm so happy for you! Congratulations!

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content: I hope it's better than Apress' "Pro .NET Directory Services Programming" or, as it's known here, "The Directory Services Book of Lies"...

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
While I can't say I've read it from cover to cover, the chapters that I have read seem to be right on the money. In fact, I've been using one or two chapters as a reference in my own work over the last few months (that's the benefit of being a reviewer :)

I believe enough in it that I'll probably be writing the forward, if that helps any.

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
Hi Chorlton,

I hope you'll be pleased with the book. I feel confident in saying that Ryan and I are pretty deep and have shipped a LOT of code that actually works. We also are both MVPs and spend quite a bit of time in the trenches helping people make this stuff work every day, so I think we have a pretty good finger on what gives people trouble.

Additionally, our book is probably going to be at least 2x as long as the APress book (not totally sure about final page counts yet), so you can expect more details.

Addison Wesley will post a free chapter online once all the editing and layout is done (a few more months), so you'll be able to judge for yourself.

The book we had originally wanted to write would have been at least 2x as long as what we ended up with, so we had to pick out battles. However, we do plan to follow it up with a really useful website.

We are also exceedingly easy to get a hold of online (MS newsgroups or www.asp.net forums) in case you have questions.

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content: Joe and Ryan, Can you provide the Online version of your book as Keith did for his guide book?

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
Just pre-ordered mine on Amazon. This is something that I really need. May seems so far away...

gert

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content: I needed this book yesterday. How can we up in Canada get our hands on it today?

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
Hey Naz,

From talking with our publisher, the book should be available any day at their website:

http://www.awprofessional.com/title/0321350170

and within 1 week at Amazon, Bookpool, etc. and within 2 weeks at brick and mortar stores.

I don't believe there is any exclusivity to the US, so Canada should be online at the same time - only minimal translation necessary ;)

Depending on what you are looking for, one of our more practical chapters is already available online as a sample here:

http://www.awprofessional.com/title/0321350170#info3

This chapter is about managing users. It really should be any day now...

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
Hey Ryan,

Thanks for you prompt response. I need to know how to move a User from one Organizational Unit to another. Unfortunately, this chapter doesn't cover this. Any suggestions, while I start hunting down your book?

I did try to reach the publisher by phone to try to get some quick answers, but was given an 800 number that cannot be reached from out here on the west coast.

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content:
Hi Naz,

Quickly, I will say this is very easy to do with the DirectoryEntry.MoveTo() method. We cover this in Chapter 3, I believe. Essentially, you just create a DirectoryEntry that represents the object to be moved and another one that represents the new container. Pass the container to the MoveTo() method on the object to be moved and with proper permissions, it will be moved (you can rename at the same time as well).

If you have further questions, I would suggest posting a message to either the ASP.NET LDAP and Active Directory forum (where I tend to hang out), or to the microsoft.public.adsi.general newsgroup where Joe tends to hang out.

This way we won't clog Keith's comments either. Thanks!

entry.title: re: The .NET Developer's Guide to Directory Services Programming
entry.content: Does anyone know if this book covers IIS in any detail? Enumerating and creating websites, etc.?
