entry.title: Question to Software Designers: IUser
entry.content:
Even as Web Single Sign On is gaining more and more traction, there’s still churn. I would much prefer to isolate my application developers from the details of whatever library I happen to be using today to get details about my user.

ASP.NET developers are used to getting an IPrincipal (and from that, an IIdentity) from HttpContext.User, WCF’s SecurityContext, etc. But modern web SSO libraries offer more than just the Name and IsInRole() query that these interfaces deliver. And as much as Microsoft may claim that IClaimsIdentity from the Windows Identity Foundation (WIF) is the LAST identity interface we’ll ever see, I’m doubtful. There’s a LOT of churn in the identity space right now. And even if there weren’t a lot of churn, I don’t think I’d want to have my developers worrying about which URI (ClaimType) they should search for to get the user’s email claim. What if there’s more than one? What would that mean?

I’m still of the opinion that an application would benefit from having a custom interface that encapsulated all of the identity needs for that application. It might be as simple as this:

public interface IUser
{
    string Name { get; }
    string Email { get; }
    bool IsInRole(string role);
}

I threw IsInRole and Name in the mix for convenience; these are also available on the default IPrincipal/IIdentity pair that you get from ASP.NET, WCF, etc. Email is the interesting addition here.

The question I have for you, readers, has nothing to do with the structure of IUser itself, but rather, how would you suggest *getting* to a concrete implementation of it? Is this the sort of thing you’d want in an Inversion of Control Container, for example? Or would you prefer to hang this off of a custom principal object that you’d hang off of HttpContext.User?

Seems like using HttpContext.User makes it less unit-testable because then your code depends on HttpContext.

While we’re at it, does it offend you that I didn’t derive IUser from IPrincipal? If I had done that, it would imply that you could get to an IClaimsIdentity in order to get to extra stuff without changing the IUser interface. But that wasn’t the intent.

I’d love your feedback! Keep in mind that comments are moderated so it may take a day or so for your comments to appear here (blame the spammers for this annoyance, sorry!)

entry.title: re: Question to Software Designers: IUser
entry.content:
My advice would be to avoid the singleton patterns (like HttpContext) like the plauge as they are inherently untestible without a big context build-up.
You could use something like a repository class Repository<IUser> to do CRUD and a service class like UserAuthenticator.AuthenticateUser(IUser, IProvidedCredentials) for that problem.
And in both cases, yes, I would use an IoC to inject those into your worker class, for instance an MVC controller.
This would allow testing of the service class, the repo, and the user implementation each in isolation.</IUser>

entry.title: re: Question to Software Designers: IUser
entry.content: Ian and I have been using MEF to provide this sort of thing. Works well, ships in the box, makes testing fairly straightforward. So I guess that's another vote for IoC, although really it's a vote for "Use infrastructure that sets properties on the consuming object".

entry.title: re: Question to Software Designers: IUser
entry.content:
I totally agree with the custom route. It's pretty clean to create a custom singleton pattern for obtaining a custom interface based user context. Under the hood, the singleton calls into a provider pattern which returns the user context. Different providers handle different authentication mechanisms, i.e. unit-test provider, emulation providers (for debug), web-forms, ntlm, etc. (and soon claims for sso in my case.)
The only problem with this route can be third-party components that rely on standard Auth. So if the plumbing isn't coupled correctly, it's gonna spring a leak.

entry.title: re: Question to Software Designers: IUser
entry.content:
I would agree that using httpcontext.user within you code makes testing much harder.
But to help the issue, I would rather extend the IClaimIdentity and use repository pattern. That way I get the best of both world.
Scott has some interesting read for ASP .Net MVC to help testing by using a Model Binder. http://www.hanselman.com/blog/IPrincipalUserModelBinderInASPNETMVCForEasierTesting.aspx
Also you could use WSFederationAuthenticationModule_SecurityTokenValidated event to inject you own custom principal in an ASP .Net App.

entry.title: How to programmatically change the physical directory for a web app in IIS 7.x
entry.content:
There’s lots of info out there on using Microsoft.Web.Administration to configure IIS programmatically. I personally found most of it rather confusing, and I spent way too much time trying to figure this out, calling GetApplicationHostConfiguration, etc.

There’s a dead simple way to do this that I finally found.

Notes about this code:

  • The collections return null if they don’t have the thing you are looking for. I’m not checking for that in this sample code.
  • Don't forget to include a slash in front of your app name.

Edit later same day: Updated code to be more robust by not assuming first vdir is root. Now the code searches for a vdir named "/" under the app. 

using Microsoft.Web.Administration;
class Program
{
    // add reference to System.Web
    // and %WINDIR%\system32\inetsrv\Microsoft.Web.Administration.dll
    static void Main()
    {
        const string WebsiteName = "Default Web Site";
        const string AppName = "/test"; // Note: starts with slash
        const string NewPhysicalPath = @"c:\temp\newDir";

        using (var serverManager = new ServerManager())
        {
            var site = serverManager.Sites[WebsiteName];
            var app = site.Applications[AppName];
            var vdir = FindAppVdir(app);
            vdir.PhysicalPath = NewPhysicalPath;
            serverManager.CommitChanges();
        }
    }

    private static VirtualDirectory FindAppVdir(Application app)
    {
        return app
            .VirtualDirectories
            .FirstOrDefault(vdir => vdir.Path == "/");
    }
}

entry.title: Dynamically Structured ViewModels in ASP.NET MVC
entry.content:
We started building our website back in 2004, when ASP.NET WebForms were all the rage. I’ve finally bitten the bullet and started integrating MVC into our website so that going forward, we’ll have a cleaner architecture that allows for better testability, separation of concerns, etc. This transition has been a fun and challenging one.

As part of this effort, I’ve done a lot of experimenting with different ways of implementing testable, maintainable views. There are a lot of good threads out there that touch on this. Here are a few that I happened to read this morning:

http://codeclimber.net.nz/archive/2009/10/27/12-asp.net-mvc-best-practices.aspx
http://geekswithblogs.net/michelotti/archive/2009/10/25/asp.net-mvc-view-model-patterns.aspx
http://www.arrangeactassert.com/asp-net-mvc-view-best-practices-keep-logic-out-of-your-views/

A comment in the last thread by Jaime prompted me to write this post. I’m still not completely settled on the details of the techniques I think will work best for us at Pluralsight, but some ideas are definitely crystallizing, so I figured I’d jot them down here.

For one thing, I’ve come to the conclusion that using ViewModels is pretty critical for us, since I want to be able to write automated tests that assure me that the dynamic data I want rendered is likely to actually be rendered. And I want those tests to be exposed to precisely the data that’s going to be rendered in the view – no more and no less. Using domain models directly in views feels like a nice shortcut, but doesn’t lead to this outcome except in very simple cases.

Another goal of mine is to eliminate *all* logic from the views themselves so the views become simply a way to interleave HTML tags with dynamic content.

One of the first habits I worked on breaking was including “if” statements in views to manage optional sections. I used a lot of asp:Panel controls in my WebForm days, and it felt pretty natural to replace those panels with “if” statements in the view. After writing a couple of views this way, I quickly realized I was not going to get the level of testability I wanted. So instead of an “if” in the view checking a flag to see if an optional section should be rendered, I now take that section of the view and make another view model for it. Here’s a view model for showing a pencil with an optional erasor:

namespace SampleViewModels
{
    public class ShowPencil
    {
        public string Brand { get; set; }
        public Erasor Erasor { get; set; }
    }

    public class Erasor
    {
        public string Color { get; set; }
    }
}

Once ShowPencil is constructed, my automated tests can walk over the structure and assert that Erasor is null or not based on the scenario I’m testing. To render the Erasor, I use a partial view, but I don’t use an “if” statement, as you’ll see later.

I used a lot of asp:MultiView controls in my WebForms days. Now if I have a section of the view that needs to render one thing or another depending on business logic, I use a very similar approach to the Erasor, except I more loosely type the link to the child view model, such as I do with Mechanism below:

namespace SampleViewModels
{
    public class ShowPencilSharpener
    {
        public string Brand { get; set; }
        public object Mechanism { get; set; }
    }
    
    public class ElectricSharpeningMechanism
    {
        public int Voltage { get; set; }
    }

    public class MechanicalSharpeningMechanism
    {
        public double ArmLength { get; set; }
    }
}

These techniques allow me to easily test right under the surface of my views. I say “easily” because it’s conceptually easy, but as business logic gets more complicated and views have more optional features, tests get more complicated as well, but that’s the price you pay for complicated business logic.

Now the only trick is to build a set of views and partial views that can render these dynamically structured view models. It turns out the templating features[1] introduced in ASP.NET MVC 2 work very nicely for this. For example, here’s a what a partial view for ShowPencilSharpener might look like:

<%@ Control Language="C#" Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewUserControl<SampleViewModels.ShowPencilSharpener>" %>

<div>
Brand: <%: Model.Brand %>
</div>

<%= Html.DisplayFor(model => model.Mechanism) %>

DisplayFor won’t show anything if model.Mechanism is null. But if there’s something there, it will use a well defined template resolution strategy[2] to find an appropriate partial view to use. And the view selected depends on the type of object that my controller (or better yet, my view model builder) put into the Mechanism property.

Let’s say my view model used a MechanicalSharpeningMechanism. I write a custom display template (which is really just a partial view) so I can control how that section of the view should look. Another nice feature of breaking things up like this is that if any other view model uses MechanicalSharpeningMechanism, I can easily reuse that partial view for rendering that part of the view model, if it makes sense to do so. Here’s what that partial view might look like:

<%@ Control Language="C#" Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewUserControl<SampleViewModels.MechanicalSharpeningMechanism>" %>

<div>
Arm length: <%: Model.ArmLength %> inches
</div>

This sort of view model composition seems really powerful to me. This morning I’m experimenting with new ways of generating forms based on this idea.

Huge kudos to Brad Wilson for taking the time to walk us all through MVC 2 templates. His lucid explanation made my life much easier when I went searching for a way to render these dynamically structured view models.

[1] http://bradwilson.typepad.com/blog/2009/10/aspnet-mvc-2-templates-part-1-introduction.html
[2] http://bradwilson.typepad.com/blog/2009/10/aspnet-mvc-2-templates-part-3-default-templates.html

entry.title: Controlling TemplateDepth in ASP.NET MVC 2 Templates
entry.content: In my last post , I talked about how convenient it is to use MVC 2 templates to display data. I’ve

entry.title: Controlling TemplateDepth in ASP.NET MVC 2 Templates
entry.content:
In my last post, I talked about how convenient it is to use MVC 2 templates to display data. I’ve been trying to use similar ideas to construct generic forms, but I’m running into a problem that I’m hoping there’s an easy way to fix.

I’ve built a very simple example to demonstrate what I’m seeing: a Widget controller that allows you to Create new Widgets. I’m using the default route, nothing special. But I’m using view models, not domain models. Here they are:

public class CreateWidgetPage
{
    public string SummaryOfExistingWidgets;
    public CreateWidgetForm TheForm;
}

public class CreateWidgetForm
{
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public string Color { get; set; }
}

The page I display when you GET /Widget/Create includes more than just a form. I’ve got some display-only details that I want to show the user when she’s about to create a widget. It doesn’t matter what it is, the point is that it’s not something that’s logically part of the form that I want posted back.

Here’s the interesting part of the Create view, which relies on Brad’s tabular Object.ascx editor template to display a simple editable table for Name and Color:

<div>
<%: Model.SummaryOfExistingWidgets %>
</div>
<h2>Create</h2>
<form ...>
    <%= Html.EditorFor(m => m.TheForm) %>
    <div>
        <input type='submit' value='Create' />
    </div>
</form>

And the controller’s Create method that processes the form:

public ActionResult Create(CreateWidgetForm formModel) 
{
   // ...
}

The ViewModel that is posted to Create has null values for both Name and Color. Why? Because the EditorFor helper is encoding the scoping element, “TheForm”, as a prefix on the names of the properties on the view model. If I inspect the HTML that is rendered with a GET to /Widget/Create, the Name property is represented like this:

<input name="TheForm.Name" ... />

Clearly this isn’t going to bind well to CreateWidgetForm, which knows about a “Name”, not “TheForm.Name”.

In an effort to divorce CreateWidgetForm from its scope, I tried this:

<% var theForm = Model.TheForm; %>
<%= Html.EditorFor(m => theForm) %>

This didn’t help. The variable, “theForm”, ended up being used as the scope:

<input name="theForm.Name" ... />

I could see how someone using domain models directly in their views wouldn’t run into this problem. GET on the controller’s Create would return a Widget, say, and POST to the controller’s Create would send that exact same thing back. There’s no need for nesting the way I’ve done it here.

It feels like what I need is a way to tell EditorFor that I want a new root. Don’t pay attention to the fact that TheForm is a property on some bigger object. I want TemplateDepth = 1 when we drill into EditorFor in the above examples. There’s probably some super easy way to do this that I’m just not finding.

Indeed what I’m trying to achieve with ViewModels goes beyond the simplified example I’ve used above. I’m thinking it would be quite nice to have a very generic template for a create form. Something like this:

public class CreateForm
{
    public string PrettyNameForTheThingWeAreAboutToCreate;
    public object FormModel;
}

Coupled with a display template that looks something like this:

<%@ Control Language="C#" Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewUserControl<CreateForm>" %>
<h2>Create <%: Model.PrettyNameForTheThingWeAreAboutToCreate%></h2>
<form ...>
<%= Html.EditorFor(m => m.FormModel) %>
<div>
    <input type='submit' value='Create' />
</div>
</form>

I searched quite a bit to see if anyone else had posted about this issue and didn’t find anything, but I can’t be the first to run into this. What am I missing?

PROBLEM SOLVED (Thanks Brad :-)

The solution in my case is to use the overloaded version of EditorFor which allows you to control the prefix:

 

<%= Html.EditorFor(m => m.FormModel, null, "") %>

 

Worked like a charm!

entry.title: re: Controlling TemplateDepth in ASP.NET MVC 2 Templates
entry.content:
The reason for the prefix is that you might have several editors on the page, so we always assume that the expression governs exactly what you want the name to be, unless you say otherwise.
You have a few ways you can fix this:
1. Name the action parameter "theForm". The names line up then.
2. Decorate the action parameter with [Bind(Prefix="TheForm")].
3. Use the overload of EditorFor which allows you to specify the HTML field name to be used:
<_ html.editorform=""> m.TheForm, null, String.Empty) %>
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee407399%28v=VS.100%29.aspx</_>

entry.title: Types vs. Strings to identify controllers and simplify Areas in ASP.NET MVC 2
entry.content:
Ever since I started working out the RESTful routing strategy we’ll be using for our MVC apps at Pluralsight, I’ve been trying to avoid identifying controllers with strings in places like HtmlHelpers.ActionLink. It occurred to me early on that I’d much rather use type names to identify resources and controllers rather than string.

If you have a WidgetController, why pass controller=“Widget” when you could specify the type of the controller instead? Then you’d see compile errors early, as opposed to having links with empty href elements because the HtmlHelper couldn’t find a matching route because you misspelled a controller name.

You could solve this particular problem by using constants (controller = Controllers.Widget), I suppose. But then when you look at how Areas work, it sure would be nice having the type as part of the route.

I suppose the reason controller names are passed around as strings so much is because of the default routes that ASP.NET MVC gives you when you run the wizard: {controller}/{id}/{action}. But for someone who wants to take a more RESTful approach, you don’t want this style of routing anyway, and you’ll be adding a bunch of custom routes instead of trying to use one generic URL pattern for routing.

In large systems, {controller} isn’t enough to identify a controller anyway. You need to add areas to ensure uniqueness of controller names. Which leads me to the subject of this post (finally!) I’m wondering if anyone can think of any major drawback to simply removing {controller} from the values used in RouteData.Values and replace it with {controllerType} in RouteData.DataTokens. In one fell swoop you eliminate both controller names and area names from the equation.

In large systems where you care about testing, you’re likely to be using ViewModels and modeling links to make them testable. So you won’t be using Html.ActionLink anyway, and it’s very natural to use controller types to build the models for links to controllers that you depend on.

I’ve got a prototype of this working now, and it allows me to put my controllers wherever I like (they don’t have to be in the Controllers folder). My unit tests for resolving incoming requests and outgoing URL generation are all green.

My next step is to build a custom view engine that looks for views based on the controller type. Once that’s wrapped up, I should have very natural support for “areas” that’s based on the types of the controllers, with a hierarchy that follows the namespace structure of the controllers, which should naturally resolve any naming conflicts that could arise. My initial thought about view resolution is that it’d be nice to be able to map an arbitrary prefix of the controller type (e.g. the first bit of the namespace) onto a root folder for the “area” then have the namespace-driven search algorithm take over from there, following the rest of the namespace down the folder tree from the “area” root. Might also be nice to have the view engine be able to pick up shared views from anywhere up the hierarchy.

Request to the MVC team: I had to make one minor change to MvcHandler to be able to get ASP.NET MVC 2 to work this way. I changed MvcHandler.ProcessRequestInit from [private] to [protected virtual]. This allowed me to reuse the vast majority of MvcHandler (the async stuff would be a bitch to reimplement). This seems like a really useful extensibility point.

Update (3 Jun 2010): My view engine is complete, and it's working like a charm. No more worrying about "areas" - I get a nice hierarchical site based on the structure of the namespaces of the types that I use in my application. If I run into any problems I'll post them here, but it looks like this is a feasible way to implement a RESTful routing scheme.

entry.title: re: Types vs. Strings to identify controllers and simplify Areas in ASP.NET MVC 2
entry.content: Great Idea! Do you think that you can share a bit of you the source code?

entry.title: Dynamically emitting types for unit tests
entry.content:
I’m building a view engine for ASP.NET MVC 2 that locates views based on the type names of the controllers. To unit test the bits that construct a path from a namespace, I needed to have a bunch of different types of controllers, and using actual types was clearly going to get messy, so I synthesized my own dynamic types using Reflection.Emit. This particular example is hardcoded to produce classes that derive from System.Web.Mvc.Controller, but it’s a great start for anyone who wants to synthesize types for whatever reason. It was well worth 15 minutes of research and coding. Kudos to the .NET team for making it so easy!

Here’s an example of usage:

var factory = new ControllerTypeFactory();
var type = factory.MakeControllerType("Foo.Bar.MyController");

The output from this call allows you to avoid having to write this:

namespace Foo.Bar
{
    public class MyController : Controller { }
}

If you want an instance instead of just the type, call MakeController instead, which simply adds a call to Activator.CreateInstance() on the dynamically created type.

Here’s the code. Note that it creates a “RunAndCollect” assembly, which is great for simple cases like this because the assembly will be unloaded from the domain automatically once everything in it is collected. It’s making my unit tests green, which is making me smile.

public class ControllerTypeFactory
{
    private readonly AssemblyBuilder assemblyBuilder;

    public ControllerTypeFactory()
    {
        var assemblyName = new AssemblyName(Guid.NewGuid().ToString());
        assemblyBuilder = AppDomain.CurrentDomain.DefineDynamicAssembly(assemblyName,AssemblyBuilderAccess.RunAndCollect);
    }

    public Type MakeControllerType(string controllerTypeName)
    {
        var moduleBuilder = assemblyBuilder.DefineDynamicModule("module");
        const TypeAttributes typeAttributes = TypeAttributes.Public | TypeAttributes.Class;
        var parentType = typeof(Controller);
        var typeBuilder = moduleBuilder.DefineType(controllerTypeName, typeAttributes, parentType);
        return typeBuilder.CreateType();
    }

    internal ControllerBase MakeController(string controllerTypeName)
    {
        var controllerType = MakeControllerType(controllerTypeName);
        return (ControllerBase)Activator.CreateInstance(controllerType);
    }
}

entry.title: Keith Brown’s TechEd NA 2010 Session Demos
entry.content:
I was fortunate to be able to tag team a talk at TechEd New Orleans with Aaron Skonnard this week, and I wanted to post my bits from the demos we did.

There were three parts to my demo. The first part was where Aaron added in an attribute on his Presentation Feed service to require a claim before granting access to the feed. You can get the code for his service and my WCF behavior attribute from his demos here. The code for the client that authenticates with ACS to get a token to send in the Authorization header to Aaron’s service can be found in my demos (below). It’s in the PresentationFeedClient folder.

The second part of my demo used a simple string reverser service that I built in ASP.NET MVC. Once again, I simply authenticated directly with ACS, got a token, and sent it to the service as part of the Authorization header.

The third part of my demo simulated an enterprise single sign on. I used Justin Smith’s “mini ADFS” simulator to issue a SAML token to my client, simulating a logon request to a real ADFS federation server in a domain. I then sent this SAML token up to ACS and got back a SWT (Simple Web Token) which I sent to my string reverser service, which allowed me in.

The service and client for these last two parts can also be found in the StringReverser folder of my demos (below). I also included a copy of Justin’s MiniADFS server as part of the solution. I hope he doesn’t mind! You’ll need to install the Windows Identity Foundation SDK to run this third demo, as that’s where the SAML and WS-Trust support comes from.

I used the sample ACS Management Browser from the Azure AppFabric SDK to set up a very simple policy in ACS to issue the tokens needed by the services. I included a copy of the policy in the policy.xml file. Nothing fancy here – just simple rules based on issuer claims.

Download my demos here.

Thanks to those who turned in evaluations. Our talk was number three in our track thanks to you!

entry.title: Pluralsight Website Update, 7/31/2010
entry.content:
You may have noticed some changes on our website. We made a number of updates last Friday, which I’ll summarize in this post.

We’ve been advertising the new Ultimate subscription, which gives you three vouchers for virtual classroom training. It’s now live, and you can purchase it on our website, or upgrade to it if you already have a subscription.

We’ve received a lot of feedback from our customers, which we take to heart. As a result, we’ve simplified the structure of our On-Demand! content so it’s easier to navigate and find what you are looking for. We’ve broken up several of our larger courses into smaller, more focused courses. This makes the content in those courses more discoverable (before this was done, for example, I didn’t realize we had a module on jQuery, but now it’s much easier to find). We’ve also restructured some of our HOWTO series of videos into courses, which should make them easier to navigate using our course viewers. Please note that we’ve not taken any content away. We’ve simply reorganized it for consistency and ease of navigation.

If you’re wondering where “Tutorials” went, they are still around, they’ve just been incorporated as “Beginner” content in our main course library. Now there’s just one page to visit to list all of our courses and tutorials. Oh, and “Beginner” is one of three levels we’ve added on each of our courses to help you more easily find content appropriate to your level of experience with any given subject.

We’ve recategorized the content a bit so that you’ll get better results when you use the “Browse the library” control and search for technologies (we still need to prune that list down a bit, so bear with us). We’ve also restructured our course listing page, categorizing courses so that they are easier to find. We’ve got a brand new search engine in the works that will only search content in the On-Demand! library, and I expect to see that going live either this week or next, so watch for the “search” box to reappear soon and be a *lot* more useful to you.

Another cool feature we’ve added is progress checkmarks. From now on, a checkmark will show up in the course table of contents once you watch a clip. And when you’ve watched all of the clips in a module, a checkmark will show up next to that module so that you can track your overall progress. Our Silverlight player shows these checkmarks next to clip titles as well. Keep in mind that these won’t show up immediately when you click on a clip to start watching it, but the next time you refresh the table of contents page or launch the player, you’ll see that they are updated. We plan on adding some script to hasten their appearance in the future. [EDIT: 8/16/2010 - I've run a script to scrape though our logs and add checkmarks to all user accounts for all content you've watched in the past. Hope this helps!]

We hope you like the new structure and look of the library. Our goal with all of this work is to make it easier for you to navigate and digest our growing library of content. Thanks go out to those of you who took the time to share feedback with us. Keep it coming!

entry.title: Min, Max, Between, Limit
entry.content:
Call it what you will, often times you just want to limit the value of something. In the .NET Framework, you might write code like this to do it:

var submmittedValue = 15;
var limitedValue = Math.Max(1, Math.Min(12, submittedValue));

I personally don’t like this approach, because I have a hell of a time remembering the order of the minimum and maximum value. Makes me think too much.

What I’d really rather have is a “Between” method that lets me pass the min and max as an argument. Fortunately I searched the web before I wrote one myself, because I found a sweet generic solution that uses IComparable. Here’s what I ended up with:

public static class IComparableExtensions
{
    public static T Limit<T>(this T value, T minValue, T maxValue) where T : IComparable
    {
        if (value.CompareTo(minValue) < 0)
            return minValue;
        if (value.CompareTo(maxValue) > 0)
            return maxValue;
        return value;
    }
}

I hope someone else finds this helpful.

entry.title: re: Min, Max, Between, Limit
entry.content:
I think the implementation should avoid assuming the CompareTo implementation it's interacting with returns exactly -1 or 1. Per the docs:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/system.icomparable.compareto.aspx
it would probably be safer to test for < 0 (first if) and > 0 (second if). I know I've certainly implemented IComparable such that my CompareTo method returns negative and positive numbers other than exactly -1 and 1.

entry.title: re: Min, Max, Between, Limit
entry.content: Good catch, Mike. I'll update the post.

entry.title: re: Min, Max, Between, Limit
entry.content:
Another reason to prefer the < 0 and > 0 when dealing with CompareTo, is that it makes the code easier to understand. a.CompareTo(b) op 0 is the same as a op b whether op is <_> or ==
(Now HTML encoded, just in case)
Another reason to prefer the < 0 and > 0 when dealing with CompareTo, is that it makes the code easier to understand. a.CompareTo(b) op 0 is the same as a op b whether op is <, > or ==</_>

entry.title: VisualSVN Rocks!
entry.content:
For about a year, I used ankhsvn to get some Visual Studio integration with Subversion. There were some major pain points, such as when I'd move folders around in VS, I'd end up with a really hosed working copy that would take some time to clean up.

I recently started using VisualSVN and it's worth its weight in gold. It has very clean integration with TortoiseSVN, so virtually all of the dialogs you see are actually Tortoise dialogs, and since I've already been using TortoiseSVN for so long, I'm finding this much more natural.

I encourage you to give it a try if you're using Visual Studio and SVN, especially if you use TortoiseSVN already. Excellent product!

entry.title: re: VisualSVN Rocks!
entry.content: Amen. I've been using the VisualSVN plug-in, along with their free server product, for several years now. It's well worth the small price for the plug-in.

entry.title: re: VisualSVN Rocks!
entry.content:
Keith, I've been using VisualSVN for over a year and I, too, think it's worth its weight in gold. VisualSVN might not be as sexy as some other source control apps, but its seamless integration with Visual Studio and Tortoise makes for a powerful solution.
I've installed the VisualSVN server on two VPS's in both Windows 2003 Server and Windows 2008, and for both it works flawlessly.
Have a good one, Dave
